PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Michael Beahan) took the chair at 2.00 p.m., and read prayers.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I inform the Senate that I will be absent from question time from tomorrow the 17th to the end of this week and from 23 to 26 of October due to official government business overseas. I will be flying tomorrow to attend the annual meeting of the non-aligned movement in Colombia to promote Australia's candidacy for a seat on the United Nations Security Council and also the current resolution before the general assembly on nuclear testing. I will be attending the special commemorative meeting of the General Assembly of the United Nations to mark its 50th anniversary; a meeting in New York of the Carnegie Commission on Preventing Deadly Conflict of which I am a member; and making an address in connection with the Grawmeyer award. In my absence Senator Robert Ray will represent the Prime Minister during question time and Senator McMullan will take questions on foreign affairs.

—by leave—This is totally over the top, if I might suggest. Today the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans) has come in and said that he is going to be away for the next fortnight, bar one day. Forget the parliament, forget the responsibilities of the government and ministers to this parliament because he has better things to do. He wants to go to Colombia to a meeting of the non-aligned movement. You might ask these days what is the significance of the non-aligned movement internationally. But the practice of the government always was, Senator Ray, that it sent the chairman of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade to meetings of the non-aligned movement. Why does the foreign minister have to go to Colombia as a priority ahead of his responsibilities to this parliament?

PARA.TAB: Secondly, he wants to go back to the United Nations again. He was in the United Nations in New York only a fortnight ago. Why do it again now?

TALK.START.PARA: —He wants to go there full time.

—We know that. He can aspire to his job in New York—that is one thing—but his responsibility to the parliament is another thing. He sits in that chair as the Leader of the Government principally responsible for the government's program and he is abdicating that responsibility by wanting to head off to another conference in New York.

PARA.TAB: Thirdly, he has another conference of some other commission. And then, fourthly, he wants to go to Louisville to give a speech.

TALK.START.PARA: —What's Louisville ever done wrong?
—Very true. Why should Louisville get Senator Evans? But that is beside the point. Senator Evans, do you want to finish your discussions with Senator Bolkus? Is this a little cross-factional meeting?

PARA.TAB: Government senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Hill has the floor.

—This is not just a repeat of past speeches. A tired government ought to recognise its responsibility to the Australian parliament. This minister puts his other activities ahead of that responsibility and for that I think he should be condemned. Apart from his role as Leader of the Government in this place, there are a number of important issues on foreign policy before us at the moment. There is the issue of the East Timorese that he has brought into the public debate. That is a matter that is going to be pursued within this parliament during the course of this week. And where is he going to be? He is going to be on the plane to Colombia! In the view of the coalition this is unsatisfactory and he should meet his first responsibility and that is his responsibility to the Australian parliament.

—by leave—I support Senator Hill's comments. I cannot recall previously criticising ministerial leave arrangements but I believe these are unreasonable. For the first 2 1/2 years that Senator Evans combined the important roles of Minister for Foreign Affairs and Leader of the Government in the Senate he was rarely absent. He almost killed himself in the process but he took both jobs very seriously.

PARA.TAB: But given, Minister, that you have just missed, I think, almost two weeks of the last sitting, and given that, as Senator Hill said, there are very important foreign affairs issues on the national agenda, and without any reflection on Senator Ray in representing you, we would prefer and we have a right to ask you as the Minister for Foreign Affairs to be here. I believe that you should be here. I believe that it is by choice that you are juggling these two important responsibilities and you need to give equal weight to your role of Leader of the Government in the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I am deeply touched by the concern that has been expressed around the chamber for my presence here. I have been conscious in the past, as Senator Kernot has said, of the extreme desirability of being here. I do not think anyone has had any criticism in the past of the extent to which I have torn myself apart in trying to get back from overseas trips in time to be here at session times. I did not bother to produce the statistics on this occasion but I am happy to do so if it has become an issue.

PARA.TAB: The particular reason why I am going back overseas again is simply the extraordinary significance this year of these particular meetings given Australia's candidacy for the United Nations Security Council—point one; and, point two, the necessity for us to make the maximum possible effort to extract the maximum possible support for the nuclear testing resolution now before the United Nations. When I was in New York the week before last, in a period of 6 1/2 days I spoke to over 70 foreign ministerial colleagues. There are 185 members of the United Nations, so there are still quite a few more to go. My colleagues are intensely concentrated on occasions like the non-aligned movement. It is true that for a number of years I have not been to a non-aligned summit and would not have been doing so this year had it not been for the combination of issues that we are presently pursuing.

It is an extraordinarily productive occasion, as will be the 50th anniversary session of the UN starting next week. If I make any kind of an effort to be there for the 50th anniversary session, there is no point in trying to come home before the end of the week because I could not be here before Friday morning, accordingly, I am also staying in New York, as I indicated, to attend the meeting of the Carnegie Commission on Preventing Deadly Conflict which takes place on Thursday and Friday next week. I am sorry but I am also going to the University of Louisville to accept the prize of $US150,000—$A200,000—which has been given to me and which I am about to fork out for scholarships and things of that kind on the subject of ideas for improving world order.

I think that under the circumstances the trip is perfectly explicable. The main point of the trip is the point that I have described. If Senator Alston or Senator Hill think that they can make any difference, or that Alexander Downer—God help us, that galumphing fathead—can make any difference to the way in which we are regarded internationally, they should be sent there too, to assist in this national effort that we are embarked upon at the moment. I frankly do not think that there is anyone who can do quite the sort of job that I can do, simply because of my knowledge of the people concerned and the personal relationships that I have built up over this particular period.

That is the truth of the matter. It depends a lot on who you know and the circumstances in which you can relate to people by virtue of long association with them. There are many, many people who need to be spoken to concerning these important objectives and I think it is extremely churlish that the opposition and the Democrats should have taken the view that they have on this occasion. It just reinforces me in my view of this place, Mr President.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I think Senator Gareth Evans's last comment said it all. Ever since he made that fatal mistake and decided to go and have a run in Holt, and then found when he was out of the country that Senator Robert Ray actually moved in and insisted that the vote for the deputy prime ministership be brought on in his absence, he has known he is going nowhere in this country, and that is why he wants to get out. Even when Senator Button was leader, and he was pretty much asleep on his feet for the last couple of years, he was always prepared to be here. And you were too; you used to take this place seriously.

PARA.TAB: If there is one thing you can say about Senator Gareth Evans it is that he has always had an infatuation with the United Nations. He has always thought it was tremendously important. Presumably he still has the same view. But that did not stop him from attending to his duties for some years. It just happens that, all of a sudden, everything is so important over there; nothing is important here any more. We know that the Prime Minister is going feral because he thinks there is something important happening here but, when you have someone who is so disengaged from domestic politics that he can regard tripping around the world as the best way in which he can make a contribution, it really tells you what his priorities are. In other words, he has given up here; he is not interested in domestic politics any more—he is making a run overseas.

If he has a department to support him, presumably they can do all of the work, they can make the representations. We have ambassadors around the world; we have a permanent representative to the United Nations. All these things can be done by others, otherwise, why would we ever have a foreign minister attending the parliament? He would always be doing those fundamentally important things that are so interesting to him offshore. But no; the fact is, when you look at his track record, he has had less and less interest in this place ever since he lost out. What he is basically doing—as Senator Cook did before the last election, in that case in relation to the ILO—is putting in his job application. He is going around watering it, seeing if he can drum up a bit of support.

That is not the way to represent Australia's interests. They see through you; they want people who are focused on the job in hand, which is representing the national interest. We want someone here who is going to be directly responsible. You are being paid real money to account to this parliament. You are not here when it suits you; when, because you feel like doing something, you will call in here occasionally. You are not honouring your responsibilities to this parliament, and I think you ought to stand condemned by your colleagues as much as by the people of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr President, I would ask you to ask Senator Evans to withdraw the unparliamentary and uncharitable comments in relation to a member of the other place.
—That was quite inappropriate Senator Evans, and I would ask you to withdraw it.
—I withdraw it, Mr President.

—My question is to Senator Cook, representing the Treasurer. I might have asked Senator Gareth Evans but he has given up the 763,000 Australians who are out of work under Labor policy. My question concerns that, Senator Cook, the rise to—

PARA.TAB: Senator Gareth Evans interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —There is not much point; you are not going to be here for the next fortnight. My question concerns the rise to 8.5 per cent of unemployed in this country after 14 years of Labor government, and also reports today of Access Economics that the unemployment rate is expected to top nine per cent next year—in other words, rising again. Minister, is this not predictable, given that economic growth has now fallen below the figure which your government said was necessary to sustain ongoing falls in the unemployment rate? How do you justify this policy failure which is contributing to the development of an underclass of Australians left without hope of a better tomorrow, or is it just, as Mr Keating said on Saturday, that Labor governments are good for the wealthy?

—Mr President, there are several erroneous assumptions that Senator Hill has supported in framing his questions before he got to his questions. Let me correct a couple of them before I go to the actual questions he has put. The first one is about an assumption he made regarding Access Economics. Access Economics is one forecasting organisation in the private sector. It is one of many forecasting organisations in the private sector. On this occasion its forecasts do not agree with the official forecasts of Treasury, nor do they agree with the forecasts of several other forecasting agencies in the private sector.

PARA.TAB: Let me give you one example. BIS Shrapnel, publishing its report in the BRW about six weeks ago, said that Australia looks forward to six years of continuous, sustainable economic growth. That is not what Access Economics has said. If you compare the track record of Access Economics to the actual outcomes on their forecasts, you will see that they have been wildly off the point as well. So that is one of the pillars on which you have based this question, Senator Hill. You ought to go back and re-examine the performance and the facts, because it is not a reliable pillar. I throw in as well the comment that it was Access Economics that worked with the Liberal Party to bring down the GST in Australia and the Fightback package. That proved a dismal failure. I would not rely on it if I were you, Senator Hill.

The second point is in terms of unemployment, particularly youth unemployment. In March 1983, when Labor came to power, there were more than 158,000 young people looking for full-time work. Now the number of teenagers looking for full-time work is at its lowest since April 1990. In September, it fell by 2,000 to 88,500. In other words, at the moment there are 88,500 teenagers looking for work. When we came to power in 1983, there were 158,000 teenagers looking for work. That is nearly 80 per cent more under you, when John Howard was the Treasurer of Australia, than under us at the present time. So don't you come in here lecturing us about economic performance.

The third point I make is that we have an accord in Australia with the trade union movement. We have been able to reduce taxes, lift the level of the social wage and provide an economic safety net for those who are in positions where they cannot defend themselves, are out of work or are in some other circumstance. You have never done that; we have done that. That is part of what protects Australia and prevents the formation of an underclass. Your whole policy, your list of things that you will not do—provided by Mr Howard to ACOSS—do not stack up with the things that you will do when you talk to other audiences. Would the real Mr Howard please stand up? You can lie to one group and lie to another group, but sooner or later the lies catch up with you.

The economic policies that this government has embarked on through Working Nation—to provide training opportunities and to provide employment incentives for young people and for long-term unemployed—are regarded in the Western world as a model of economic policies. It is what the United States Secretary of Labour, Robert Reich, has referred to as missing in the United States but present here and a model for the OECD.

The level of unemployment is still uncomfortably high, and we sympathise with those in the situation of being unemployed. The question here is: which party or which government will fix it? The policies that we have will deliver about a five per cent level of unemployment within the grasp of the Australian economy by the year 2000. You do not have any policies. You have no policies whatsoever, and when asked to reveal them, you will not. Your credibility is shot to pieces, and on your record you have no legs to stand on at all. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, the minister either does not understand the facts or deliberately misleads. I ask him: doesn't he realise that the record of his accord, this accord we hear of so often, has actually been to reduce average weekly earnings in Australia and to produce 763,000 Australians still out of work? After nearly 14 years of Labor government, 763,000 Australians are out of work. Twenty-seven per cent of young people are seeking work, are out of work, and the figures are rising again. That is why my question was: what hope do you give for three-quarters of a million Australians who are out of work when your projected level of growth is going to be insufficient to reduce unemployment? Surely it must logically follow that there is no hope for these people. This legacy of unemployment of the new underclass that you have created will only continue if you maintain the same policy parameters that you have to date.

—When the opposition were last in power and when John Howard was Treasurer, youth unemployment was 80 per cent higher than it is now. If that is the record you want to go to the Australian people about, tell me about it. The economic policies of this government put the level of unemployment within the grasp of the Australian economy at about five per cent by the year 2000. We do not know your policies—other than that you will engage in the biggest union bashing exercise that this country has ever seen since Jobsback was released and take on the Western Australian government's second wave of industrial regulation, which is creating divisive industrial behaviour in that state and undercutting the ability of that state's economy to grow.

PARA.TAB: That is your contribution to economic management in this country—engage in labour market policies which fracture the fragile consensus that has introduced harmony into the Australian workplace, that has enabled productivity growth and, with productivity and economic growth, that has enabled jobs growth to occur so that people can look forward to employment. Your approach is to engage in a unilateral declaration of war on the union movement and undercut the economic growth of this country. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Trade. Minister, you have just returned from a trip to Japan, where I understand there was discussion of the APEC agenda for Osaka. There has been considerable speculation in this country about the attitudes that Japan and Korea are taking in terms of working for an exclusion of agriculture from an APEC trade liberalisation program. Is this a response to the rural gerrymander within Japanese politics and the need for Liberal Democratic politicians to maintain the support of rice growers? In view of the importance of agricultural exports to the welfare of many Australians, particularly in rural communities, and those employed in industries, especially those relating to food, and given the power of Japan in APEC, could you advise the Senate on the prospects for achieving a comprehensive outcome at the forthcoming APEC meeting in Osaka, that is, an outcome that includes liberalisation of agricultural markets?

—I note that the opposition thinks that it is probably not a good idea that we go to Japan to try to solve this problem but I think most Australian farmers do. If you believed the sometimes fevered interpretations of the discussions that are going on in the lead-up to APEC, you would think there was a crisis every time there is a meeting that does not solve every element of the package we need to present at Osaka. That is far from true.

PARA.TAB: The process we are undertaking is a cumulative and a progressive one. There are not going to be any quick fixes, but we are making substantial progress. It is very important for the Australian people to realise, as Australian farmers and their organisations and the food industry and their representatives understand, that Australia currently faces a real labrynth of trade distorting quotas and subsidies as well as very high tariffs in the agricultural sectors of a number of APEC members. Each step we can take in rolling back these barriers through APEC will mean improved export returns for Australian producers and the Australian food industry and increased employment opportunities for workers in that industry.

As a result of the discussions which I have had in the last week it is my view that it is now almost certain that Australian agricultural and food exporters will secure some degree of new market opening as a result of the APEC free trade process. What is currently under way is the process of maximising these opportunities within the time frame set down by leaders at Bogor. You would expect—and I did put this to the ministers and others I met with in Japan and Korea, but particularly in the case of Senator Carr's question in Japan—Australia's case for comprehensiveness to be unqualified, undiluted. We put that position fairly clearly and forthrightly, publicly and privately.

I believe that Japan recognises it has benefited greatly from an open international trading system and that this would hold true for liberalisation within APEC—that APEC is as much in Japan's interest as it is in Australia's. The leadership there are intelligent enough to understand that at least as well as we do and to want to have the opportunity of those benefits. Therefore, I expect that Japan will provide the necessary leadership in the remaining weeks leading up to the Osaka meeting. While a resolution of the comprehensiveness issue may need to be found by the leaders at their meeting in Osaka I think possibly even before that there are real prospects to bridge the gap between APEC members on comprehensiveness in a way which will not compromise the interests of Australian farmers. The government will, I can assure you, be keeping in close contact with Australian food and agricultural industries as well as other interested groups during the countdown to Osaka.

With regard to the question that Senator Carr raised about the implications of the electoral gerrymander that has traditionally existed in Japanese politics and the capacity of it to distort priorities, the electoral system has been substantially changed and this will start to come into effect from the next election. But there is no doubt that over the last 40 years there has been a massive over-representation of agricultural interests in the parliament as a result of the electoral boundaries and the electoral system. This has reinforced other factors within the Japanese economy and the Japanese society, which has inhibited the process of agricultural reform and their preparedness to open up their markets, even though it is clearly in the interests of Japanese consumers.

The Australian government has tended to put it fairly plainly to the public in Japan and to the politicians. It is our view that it is the obligation of government to try to deliver cheap, good quality food to citizens. We find it hard to understand governments with policies focused on providing expensive food and keeping out cheap, good quality products, including those from Australia. Overall, I think we have a good chance. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Treasurer to explain the Prime Minister's statement on radio 3LO on 5 October that `The housing affordability index' is `very good now'. Isn't this at odds with Treasury, the Real Estate Institute, the Commonwealth Bank and Housing Industry Association indexes of housing affordability, which show a massive decline in home loan affordability under your Labor government? Given that, according to the REIA, home loan affordability is now 36 per cent lower than in March 1983, which index of housing affordability was the Prime Minister referring to on radio 3LO? Does Mr Keating mean housing has become more affordable for him, personally, while becoming less affordable for most Australians?

—The question of housing affordability is a question I am very surprised that you in the opposition would want to open up in this place for the very reason that all of the comparisons refer to a record that flatters us and damns and condemn you. What the Prime Minister said about housing affordability is right. The main reason why there have been changes in housing affordability in the period of our government is that consumers have become more confident about the type of house they want and they now choose a house which is 19 per cent bigger in capacity and size than the house that they would have chosen under you. I can give you the figures in squares. The house that they now buy is 198 square metres, whereas the house that they bought in 1983 was 167 square metres. So, of course, the price is higher because it is a bigger house.

PARA.TAB: The second part of the answer is that people do take out bigger home loans now because the market is much more flexible. Let me go to a couple of comparisons which demonstrate the point of flattering us and condemning you. Interest rates today in a growth economy are lower than they were in a recessed economy under John Howard. Anyone who knows anything about interest rates knows that in recession they fall and in growth they rise, but with a growth economy, they are now lower than they were in the recession period of John Howard.

For example, interest rates from the Howard era applied now to the Australian house would mean a 30 per cent higher cost to Australian home buyers than currently is the case. In the Howard era banks rationed and regulated home loans and their interest rate was 12.5 per cent—but with a cocktail in order to fund part of it. This meant that the real cost was more like what the building societies were charging in the Howard era—13.9 per cent, which reflected real interest rates.

Under us, they are much lower than that and you do not have all the cocktails. You have, in fact, true competition for housing loans. So you will now find that people can borrow not only from banks but also from new home loan agencies like Aussie Home Loans, the AMP Blue Line and a number of other sources as well. The cost of the loan in terms of the price you pay for borrowing money is now much lower than it was when you were in power.

As I have said, there is now a more innovative home loan products market. Fixed rates can be negotiated for up to five years. Those fixed rates are at amounts much lower, in many cases, than the variable home loan rate. If you shop around,even with the variable home loan rate—look at what the Business Review Weekly magazine said about this in its most recent addition—you can save $35,464 on a $100,000 loan, which is the variation between the highest market rate and the lowest market rate available.

So we have a much more contestable loans market. This means that the price of money to buy the house is cheaper and that people buy and build bigger houses. The flexibility in a financial market has meant that they sometimes buy a car, put in a swimming pool, buy furniture or go on an overseas trip out of their home loan and do not have to finance that out of other loans from other sources at higher rates. All up, the cost of servicing a home loan, including the real value of the house, is larger today. However, Australian consumers buy bigger houses because they have greater confidence in the economy and in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, this champagne socialist minister has obviously missed the point. In the 11 years between 1984 and 1995, the government's home loan affordability has reached a level in only one quarter that equalled the previous coalition record. I ask the minister to answer the question responsibly and to reconcile the Prime Minister's dilemma. How can the Prime Minister afford to spend twice as much as an average house on the carport at the Lodge or $2 million on his retirement income home at Woollahra when you cannot reconcile home loan affordability, about which the Commonwealth Bank, the Real Estate Institute and the Housing Industry Association all say you are wrong?
—Just understand this very simple point: the home we are talking about now is 19 per cent bigger than the home under you. The cost of buying it is higher because people choose a bigger house size.
—If you can afford to buy one.

—I am talking about the average home. Therefore, the cost of that home is bigger. That is the reason why those figures show an upward trend. That demonstrates that consumers have greater confidence in the future, opt for bigger homes than the ones their parents used to own and decide to take out a loan that can afford to buy the car, the swimming pool, new furniture and the international trip. That is in a more competitive finance market that offers better financial packages for lower levels of borrowings than the one under you. The comparison is that battlers in this economy do better under us than they ever thought of doing under you. As far as the rest of the stuff about the Prime Minister is concerned, that is in the basket headed `Cheap shot'. Have a go at him if you want. (Time expired)

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. He would be aware of the considerable community interest regarding the implementation of the government's living on the coast policy. Can the minister provide the Senate with information on the progress in establishing memoranda of understanding with other governments for the implementation of a coastal action program?
—Last Friday, with Mr Bilney, the honourable member for Kingston, I visited Noarlunga beach in South Australia. I went there to sign the first memorandum—
—It's a very nice place.

—It is a very nice place. They had the good sense to throw you out. I went there to sign the first memorandum of understanding on the coastal action program together with the South Australian Minister for the Environment and Natural Resources, Mr Wotton, and the President of the Local Government Association of South Australia, Mr John Dyer.

PARA.TAB: In May this year, I released Living on the coast, the Commonwealth's blueprint to change the way that coastal areas are managed and used. As part of the living on the coast policy, the government provided $53 million in the last budget for the coastal action program. The MOU that was signed last Friday makes South Australia the first state to finalise arrangements for all levels of government to cooperatively deliver the coastal action program.

Effective action on coastal issues does rely on a very strong degree of cooperation. Coastcare is a key element in the coastal action program. It is a very good illustration of the cooperation and commitment that is needed for a practical coastal program. Coastcare will fund direct hands-on community action on coastal problems around Australia. Coastcare will allow community groups to work cooperatively with local government to do things such as protect or rehabilitate sensitive areas like dunes, estuaries and wetlands; monitor coastal environments and control weeds and pests; or develop coastal management plans to set our future management directions.

For Coastcare to work, the Commonwealth, state and local governments and local community organisations and local communities all need to play their part. The agreement I signed in South Australia will see around $15 million of Commonwealth, state and local government resources flow to coastal projects in South Australia over the next four years.

In addition to Coastcare, activities will be undertaken in strategic coastal planning, preparation of local water quality management plans, preparation of regional coastal heritage assessments and professional development and training. I hope that we will see similar memoranda of understanding signed with other states and also the Northern Territory in the near future.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I ask: how could the government earlier this year argue to the International Court of Justice that Portugal has no moral or legal sovereignty over East Timor and then argue this week that East Timorese refugees have no legitimate status to remain in Australia because they are under the legal or moral sovereignty of Portugal? Does the minister agree that this appears to be very expedient or has the government at long last rejected Indonesia's brutal military invasion and subsequent illegal occupation of East Timor?

—I am glad that someone has at least asked me a foreign affairs question after more than half of question time. I am perfectly happy to answer this question, as indeed I have been answering it all week even though it is Senator Bolkus's responsibility, because the arguments and the issues are really extremely straightforward.

PARA.TAB: For a start, there is no relationship whatsoever between the question of what country currently exercises sovereignty over Indonesia and who may be nationals of that country pursuant to dual nationality principles and whether or not someone who is a national or a citizen of Indonesia might not also be a national of Portugal by virtue of Portugal's prior sovereignty over that country. That is the only matter in issue: whether or not some, at least, of the nearly 1,400 East Timorese in Australia presently seeking asylum are to be regarded as Portuguese nationals by virtue of having been born in that country during the period when Portugal had sovereignty over it, and whether or not that nationality is enjoyed alongside the nationality which they unquestionably have, we would recognise, as Indonesian.

I might just add in parentheses at this point that the advice that was given earlier this year to the RRT from the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs to the effect that the people in question were Indonesian nationals was in response to a specific question that had arisen as to whether or not, by virtue of an argument that the incorporation of East Timor into Indonesia was illegal, East Timorese were to be regarded as Portuguese and not as Indonesians at all. It was in response to that particular query that came forward that specific advice was given earlier this year that the people were to be regarded as Indonesian citizens, and that status was not affected in the way that had been claimed.

Whatever might be the point about that, the relevant question that has to be addressed is whether there is a dual nationality status available to these particular people and what follows from that. The important point to appreciate is that if someone does have dual nationality status as Portuguese as well as Indonesian, which seems likely to be the case for quite a number of these people, the responsibility of the person in question if they are unhappy with the situation in the first country—in this instance Indonesia—is to avail himself or herself of his or her other nationality.

That is what the refugee convention requires—someone who is unhappy with nationality A, argues that they are being persecuted and should enjoy refugee status, has a responsibility to avail themselves of their other nationality before seeking refugee status in any third country. Moreover, from Australia's point of view, as such a third country where that status is now being sought, we not only have no obligation to deal with those cases or to offer protection when Portuguese protection is available, but we also have a positive lack of capacity to do anything about it.

It is a matter of the proper interpretation of the refugee convention and the relevant international law. If someone is able to avail themselves of another nationality which they possess by virtue of international law and, in particular, the law of that other country, then they cannot avail themselves of the refugee process in Australia. It is as simple and as straightforward as that.

Therein lies the problem for those people who can avail themselves. Whether they can avail themselves is a mixed question of law and fact. That is what has to be resolved by the tribunal. What we have said is that those people who are not Portuguese nationals or who cannot for whatever other reason avail themselves of that nationality can then of course go before the refugee tribunal, and will do so, and have their cases assessed. We have also said that, whatever may be the situation about their Portuguese nationality or their capacity to go before the refugee tribunal, there are other discretionary avenues available for their admission to Australia anyway under humanitarian discretion. Any which way you look at it, we will do the right thing. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. The minister would be aware of assertions reported in the media recently that the drought exceptional circumstances assistance provided to drought affected farmers and their families is a lottery that they would be better off without. What is the government's response to these assertions?

—The assertions are quite bizarre, but they have to be responded to because the person making them is in fact a frontbencher from the coalition. Among his other duties, he is assistant shadow minister for primary industry. The member for Maranoa, Mr Bruce Scott, the assistant shadow minister for primary industry, has made statements to the effect that the 10,400 farm families who are receiving millions of dollars in drought exceptional circumstances assistance would have been better off without it because it makes predicting their income for that year more difficult.

PARA.TAB: Government senators—Ha, ha.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is what he said.

PARA.TAB: Senator McMullan interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is correct, Senator McMullan. I do agree with that last statement because it is a lot easier to predict your income when your income is zero. Only the opposition would consider that this predictability is better than being able to feed your children and keep your farm going.
—That's not what the farmers are saying.

—No, it is not what the farmers are saying. What he is really complaining about is that some farmers who have received the interest rate subsidy, which is worth about $17,000 to eligible farmers—that is, $17,000 in direct assistance from the government to subsidise their loans at the banks—and are getting the drought relief payment as well, which is worth up to $560 a fortnight per couple and more than that if there are dependent children, may have to pay income tax and may have to have their children's Austudy entitlements reduced.

PARA.TAB: I did say that this is a bizarre complaint. It is for two reasons. Firstly, this assistance is being provided to farmers who are in desperate need. The suggestion that they should forgo this help as a tax minimisation ploy would be laughable if the implications were not so serious and if the person making the suggestions was not such a senior member of the coalition's frontbench in terms of primary industry. Secondly, Mr Scott fails to mention that the only way that anyone who has received this assistance will have to pay income tax is if they have also received significant income from other sources.

The RAS interest rate subsidy is fully offset for tax purposes against interest rate expenses and the drought relief payment attracts a tax rebate. The government also ensures that farmers who may have a tax liability can arrange to have tax instalments taken out of the DRP before they receive it. The Australian Tax Office helps farmers work out their potential tax liability if they need that assistance. If some farmers' income is so high that they are paying income tax, this is good news and indicates that they are recovering from drought and that their income stream has recommenced.

Mr Scott also complains that some farmers' Austudy entitlements have been reduced because their income has increased. Farm families receiving the DRP are excluded from the Austudy assets and income test for the time they are on drought relief payments—that is, for the period of the drought—and for a further six months after the drought revocation is officially lifted. This is a more generous arrangement than applies to other sections of the community.

In summary, the government has provided millions of dollars of assistance to now between 10,000 and 11,000 farm families that were desperate for cash to support the family and assistance to meet interest repayments. Mr Scott's comments reflect the complete lack of understanding that the federal opposition has of severe drought, its impact on farmers and their families, and how best government can help rural Australia.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Australian Industry Development Corporation: Executive Pay Rises

TALK.START.PARA: —My question without notice is to Senator Cook, Minister for Industry, Science and Technology. Minister, can you explain why pay rises of up to 200 per cent have been awarded to executives of the 80 per cent government owned AIDC Ltd? How can you, as minister responsible for the AIDC, face the workers of Australia when you have demonstrated a clear and contemptuous double standard in allowing an executive of AIDC to have an annual salary of $1.8 million—10 times that of the Prime Minister and more than 50 times that of the average Australian worker.
—Part of this question asks why have I allowed—and on goes with the question with the massive condemnation. Well, I have not allowed anything.
—You are responsible.

—I have not allowed anything. The AIDC Ltd is a listed company on the Stock Exchange. It is independent of government and it does not make decisions with reference to the government. In the case of the AIDC, I might say I, too, was astonished at the level of wage increases that they gave their executives. I have inquired of the AIDC board—
—Did you know?
—I will come to that in a minute, Senator Hill. I did not know the amount.
—Why not?

—If you will just wait and behave yourself for a minute, Senator Vanstone, you will get told the full story. This is a private sector board. This private sector board, which I have inquired of because of our shareholding, did not consult the government about the level of its salary fixation. It did not consult the government as to whether the government approved of those amounts. It acted according to the dictates of any private company and fixed its own salaries.

PARA.TAB: Do I think the salaries are high? Yes, I do, but I do understand that the salaries reflect the payment of salaries in a very highly paid sector of the economy—the Australian merchant banking sector. The salaries in that sector are universally high, and I think all are excessively high. The AIDC called on a private sector consultant to advise them as to what the appropriate going rate was. It received that report and, as a consequence of that report, fixed the salary.

The salary is made up of a base salary with bonuses upon performance—and the bonuses are varied according to how the performance of the enterprise has gone—and, in the most recent period, a payment for retention allowance to senior executives. It is the retention allowance that pushes the salaries to a high level. The retention allowance was negotiated by the board of the AIDC upon receipt of two private sector consultants' reports as to the appropriate level of retention allowance for this industry, and as a consequence they set them when the two government members of the board were not present and the government had no knowledge of the level being set.

The government knew that a retention allowance would be negotiated because it was related to maintaining one of the key assets of the AIDC. The AIDC had two key assets. The first one was its government guarantee; the second one was the quality and standing of its staff in the industry sector. As a consequence of the government's decision in the 1994-95 budget to sell down its 80 per cent shareholding in full, it was believed by us and by the board that, in order to retain the most senior executive staff, retention payments were necessary. We agreed to that but we did not agree to the amount. The amount was negotiated privately and only informed to me the other week when it was reported in the report of the company to the Australian Stock Exchange.

I heard an interjection from Senator Hill saying that the government should have intervened. It would be, I might say, a very peculiar thing for a government to intervene in the setting of a privately listed company's salary levels. It would not be proper conduct by the government at any time to do that. It shows just how far out of touch with the realities of this market you people are since you have been in opposition for so long. But that does not mean, however, that the government thinks these salaries are acceptable; it does not.

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, is it not true that a year ago the highest salary paid by AIDC was $600,000—a salary already higher than that of the highest executive of the Commonwealth Bank, which is 25 times the size of AIDC? Is it not also true that the profit of AIDC was 40 per cent less last year than the year before?

—I cannot confirm the accuracy of those figures. The figures seem to be in the ballpark of what the AIDC salaries are, although my recollection is that the salary of the chief executive was more like a figure of $460,000 than $660,000. That said, and not being able to confirm those figures, I say once again that this is a privately listed company. This company set its salaries based on a report by a reputable private sector executive search company, which recommended to it what the level of salaries should be for an excessively paid sector of the economy.

PARA.TAB: The merchant banking sector is not the same as the retail banking sector. The comparison between the AIDC and the Commonwealth Bank therefore does not hold. Salaries in the merchant banking sector are excessive by any measure. But that is the sector of the economy that the AIDC competes in for high quality staff and that is the sector of the economy that AIDC surveyed through a reputable agency in order to assess what the going rate was and to determine the amount. We did not interfere; we had no right to interfere. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, Senator Bolkus. I refer the minister to the government's declaration that East Timorese seeking refugee status in Australia are Portuguese nationals and the government's intention to send these people on to Portugal. I ask: will these people subsequently be eligible to apply to return to Australia under the special class 208 migration category; if so, why does the government intend to place these people under the further trauma and stress involved in yet another dislocation and another bureaucratic procedure; and, if not, why not?

—The government has declared nothing. What the government has declared is that we have a process in place, a process placed there by a law of this parliament. That process ensures that the process is independent of us and of the government, that people are treated individually and that people will be assessed for refugee status in accordance with the internationally accepted definition of `refugee'—that is, the UN definition of `refugee'—which has been in place for some 40 years now.

PARA.TAB: In assessing these people, the Refugee Review Tribunal some seven or eight months ago, in February this year, raised the issue of nationality, raised the issue of citizenship and raised the issue for the government to consider whether the domestic law of Portugal would impact on these people's rights under the international definition of `refugee'. That is when it came up. The government did not trigger this exercise. This exercise was triggered by the RRT, independent of government, in its deliberations.

The government was asked to make submissions to the RRT for it to consider. Requests were made in February, June and July. Submissions have been made to the RRT on the particular point of nationality and citizenship. As you would know, Senator Chamarette, for some 40 years or so the internationally recognised definition of `refugee' has allowed for situations where people may have, as Senator Gareth Evans quite rightly said, duality of citizenship.

In terms of fairness, what that definition provides is that if someone does have the right to enter and to be protected by a country or more than one country, then he or she has to seek the protection of those countries before seeking asylum status anywhere else. I think that is something that Senator Chamarette full well appreciates. It is something that I must say was appreciated by the support groups with whom I met some four or five months ago in places like Darwin where this issue was raised.

As I say, nothing has been raised by the government. The government has not interfered in the process. The relevant officers have responded to requests of the tribunal and that is how the matter has gone. I think the criticism, particularly last week of my colleague Senator Evans for interfering, is something based on no fact at all and has been totally unfair.

I just go to the second part of your question: what do we do with these people and do they qualify under the special assistance category? Raising that question, I think, is also important because not only has the government been prepared to treat people and assess them on a case by case, individual basis but it has also introduced a special humanitarian category to handle people from East Timor, whether they come through Macau or Portugal. In fact, it was only less than 12 months ago that I extended the operation of that humanitarian category and, as a consequence, increased the number of people entitled to come to Australia under it. I must admit that at that time I got criticised for so doing by the opposition; let me just place that on the record.

That special assistance category operates with time lines. The time lines are there to ensure that we do not, for instance, use it as a backdoor migration program and that we do use it effectively as a special humanitarian program. My understanding is that the time lines will probably prevent people going into Portugal from accessing that, because I think their nominators have to be in Australia for a certain period and so on. But, Senator, I will take on board your question in respect of those time lines and see to what extent these people may be covered or not covered by it.

But I do stress that final point: we have not interfered; we will not interfere; and international laws will be applied. Not only will they be applied because we feel it is a good thing; they will be applied because section 36 of the Migration Act passed by this Senate ensures that the Refugee Review Tribunal has no capacity but to apply that law. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister for his answer. I would like to ask: will any guarantee of return to Australia be given to the East Timorese as was provided to Cambodian asylum seekers? If not, why has the government decided to single out the East Timorese for less favourable treatment?

—It is a bizarre follow-up question, because Senator Chamarette spent the last couple of years accusing me of acting disfavourably against the Cambodians. Senator Chamarette, I think this really stresses the point that we are trying to make here: that unless you apply the international convention in a non-discriminate way, you will leave yourself open to this sort of attack and you will also leave yourself open to acting unfairly in the interests of some people as opposed to the others.

PARA.TAB: All I have said and all the foreign minister has said in respect of this is that people will be assessed individually. We have got the process there and that process will be allowed to continue. In respect of the SAC, I am going to take that question on board at this stage.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: United Nations Security Council: Australian Special Envoys

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Gareth Evans. I am indeed fortunate to have chosen the one day in the sitting fortnight when Senator Evans will be here. I refer to the appointment of Mr Stephen Loosley as special envoy to five Middle East and southern Asian countries to lobby for Australia's bid for a seat on the UN Security Council. Mr Loosley's sole qualification for this position appears to be his former chairmanship of the Joint Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Committee and four overseas parliamentary delegations. Why was no statement made announcing this appointment? Why is Mr Loosley a better qualified candidate for this position than the five ambassadors to those countries and the presumably vast numbers of Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade staff with specialised expertise in this area? Is it not the case that this is just another example of nepotism in the Labor family?

—The point about special envoys is that they are not people normally accredited to the country in question, but they go there wearing some special hat to identify the significance of the particular message they are being tasked to convey. We have had a large number of people—some retired diplomats and some current diplomats—working in countries to which they are not accredited and so on, playing that particular role.

PARA.TAB: There have been about a dozen of them in total going off to make these representations on behalf of me and the Prime Minister directly to the governments in question. By and large, it has been an extraordinarily successful part of the campaign which is currently being waged, with the support, as I understand it, of the opposition, for us to take a seat again on the Security Council in the election next year.

About a dozen, in total, envoys have made those visits to over 80 countries so far. Stephen Loosley was asked to be a special envoy in the Middle East and South Asia because of his earlier contacts with and experience in those regions in his former capacity, as Senator Troeth says, as chairman of the joint committee. He does have very valuable contacts in both parliament and government in Iran and India in particular. He was also an international election monitor in Nepal in 1991. Moreover, as you know in the opposition, because you have had occasion to congratulate him on his effectiveness in the role, he has been a very successful leader of all-party delegations to Russia in December 1993; to Bougainville—a particularly significant exercise—in April 1994; to Rwanda and other parts of Africa in January and February 1995; and to Vietnam in April 1995.

As the special envoy, he carried letters from Mr Keating to the President of Iran, and the Prime Minister of India and Nepal, and a letter to me from the foreign minister of Sri Lanka; he had a large number of other high level meetings and private discussions with President Rafsanjani in Iran and the Prime Ministers of Nepal and Sri Lanka; he also made a series of calls coinciding with a meeting of the Arab League in Cairo enabling him to meet with high officials of the league and the delegations from, among other countries, Kuwait, Comoros, Somalia and Saudi Arabia.

The terms and conditions of his contract were the same as those for the other two non-departmental officers who have acted as special envoys. They have all been paid a travelling allowance of $300 a day in addition to a consultancy fee in the grand sum of $266 per day. Absolutely nobody in private enterprise would work for that amount—and nobody in the legal profession either, to my knowledge. It is equivalent to the fee that has been set by the Remuneration Tribunal for consultations at this level. It bears no resemblance to what is payable on the market for similar exercises of this kind.

My understanding, on the basis of the reports I have had, is that his representations in Cairo at the Arab League meeting, his bilateral representations in Teheran, New Delhi, Colombo and Kathmandu, all at a senior level, were very successful and I am grateful for the contribution that he has been able to make.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Senator Evans, could you inform the Senate as to whether the following qualities are required for that particular position: the ability to lose the New South Wales branch of the Australian Labor Party millions of dollars of debt; the fact that he took a $100,000 payout when he resigned as general secretary of that, $80,000 of which was for holiday pay; and double dipping when Mr Loosley came into the Senate on 1 July 1990 and continued to receive a salary of approximately $8,000 for that month. How can this appointment enhance Australia's reputation overseas?
—I do not propose to dignify that further question with an answer.

—My question is directed to the minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to press reports of the bid by French conglomerate Compagnie des Eaux for Australian Medical Enterprises which owns nine hospitals in New South Wales and Western Australia and 60 per cent of private pathology services in Western Australia and ask: does the government consider it appropriate that a foreign company be given responsibility for a major slice of health services for the Australian community? Was the proposed takeover by the French company approved by the Foreign Investment Review Board and by the Treasurer? If the answer is yes, is the minister satisfied that the performance record of the French company justifies that decision and what investigations were in fact carried out?

—There are two questions in the first question, although it is not obvious when you listen to it. The first question is about foreign ownership and the ability to deliver services. The question about the ability of a company, foreign owned or domestically owned, to deliver health services in Australia goes to the right of the state health authorities—in this case the New South Wales and Western Australian health authorities—to licence that company to deliver those services to Australian quality standards.

PARA.TAB: So its ownership, whether it is foreign or domestic, is not relevant, I would suggest, to the question of whether this company is capable of delivering those services. It really is a question of whether it can meet the standards at the state level. My understanding is that it is regarded by the state authorities as certainly able and certainly capable of meeting their requirements under their own health laws to deliver a quality service to the Australian community at that level.

Senator Spindler's second question concerned whether or not the FIRB and the Treasurer approved of this matter. My advice is that both the FIRB and the Treasurer approved of it and that the investment was, in that sense, in order. Senator Spindler and I both know that we debate the question of foreign ownership regularly in this chamber. The Australian government has a view that foreign investment in Australia helps to grow the Australian economy and creates more jobs for other people. That is a process of economic management that Senator Spindler apparently disavows. Let us have that continuing argument as to who will be right and who will be wrong. In essence, the answer is yes, we did approve it at the FIRB level, the Treasurer approved it, and it is a significant investment in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because we are beggars in our own country.
—I can hear an interjection coming from Senator Kernot but I cannot actually hear the words of it. Perhaps I had better wait.
—I said we are economic beggars in our own country.

—I am trying to answer your colleague's question. The third question asked whether we were aware of complaints about this company. Yes, we are aware of complaints about it. Those complaints have been referred to the relevant state health authorities for investigation. One area of those complaints was referred to the Australian Federal Police for re-investigation. I am advised that the state health authorities have conducted an investigation and have advised us that the complaints are unsubstantiated. That is also the advice I have received from the Australian Federal Police. As we know, people make allegations. However, the making of an allegation does not make it true. There is an obligation upon a government to see that the proper authorities are alerted. We did that on this occasion. My advice is that the complaints were investigated and the response is as I have given the Senate.

—I thank the minister for his answer. I note that the minister admits that the federal government pays no attention as to whether a foreign company will provide the services that a federal government should take some interest in and simply passes the ball over to state authorities. I would have thought that the FIRB should investigate and be interested in the quality of services, particularly in the health area, that are being provided to our community. I ask the minister whether any attention has been paid to the fact that this is a French company. Does the government have any thoughts about that?

—I thank Senator Spindler for his expression of view, but his expression of view is based on a misunderstanding. I never said that the Australian government pays no attention and passes it on to the state health authorities. What I said was that the Australian government has regard to the proper authorities and in this case they are the state health authorities. Their expertise in assessing whether a company is fit and proper is much more appropriate than the expertise that we might bring at federal level. That is not to say that we do not have regard to it. We do have regard to it, but we regard the abiding authority to be the appropriate state health authority.

PARA.TAB: The second part of the question asked whether I have any thoughts on the fact that it is a French company. I do not really have any thoughts on the fact that it is a French company except that if it was a French company associated with the French defence effort I would be opposing its investment in Australia because the Australian government, in its opposition to French nuclear testing, has taken certain steps with regard to the French defence effort or military involvement. This is not one of those occasions. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. Minister, I refer you to your remarks quoted in the Asian Defence Journal on 8 September this year where you stated that you were opposed to a UN rapid response force and that you opposed UN control of units of various countries for deployment purposes. Can you explain the contradictions between your position and that of your colleague Senator Evans who boldly declared his support for the creation of a rapid deployment force in the United Nations General Assembly earlier this month?

—Senator Evans, of course, did nothing of the kind. My attitude to these particular questions can only be based on the experience of the United Nations involving itself at a military level. Those experiences have been mixed so far. There have been both successes and failures. Where there have been failures or weaknesses, various defence ministers and foreign ministers around the globe have looked at how best to address those. In broad principle, of course, we have said that, in terms of our own involvement, one must be absolutely certain that the mission is properly defined. One must make sure, especially if it is peace enforcement or peacekeeping, that there is a political solution in prospect. Thirdly, there should be at least a finite period for which forces are committed.

PARA.TAB: Having made those views very clear, there have still been weaknesses exhibited in a variety of UN operations as to command and control and the way the UN can react with sufficient speed. The current difficulty is, if an emergency breaks out around the globe, a whole range of countries are approached to see whether they are able to respond. Not always can every country respond in the way the UN would like them to respond, Senator Newman. Therefore, some thought has been given to a consideration of whether the UN could possibly have its own forces; whether it could have designated forces available to them at their direction in a country; or whether there could be stand-by forces. If you like, they are the three broad alternatives.

The first alternative is a very difficult one, in my view. It is very difficult because the United Nations for a start does not have an intelligence organisation on which most military commitments would have to rely and judgments be made. On the second issue, I think there would be very few countries around the globe that would give up their sovereignty on issues that would have their own forces being able to be committed by an international body. So the area Senator Gareth Evans—and, to a lesser extent myself—and the Prime Minister have been working on is to give some support to the concept of stand-by forces where each country identifies what assets it thinks it can make available.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not a rapid response.

—No, it is not a rapid deployment force. This is also not an absolute commitment that they can be used in every operation. I have made it very clear that, as far as I am concerned, we will not commit to areas such as Bosnia, or Afghanistan or other areas where we cannot operate effectively because of the nature of our forces. So I have not been in favour of a rapid deployment force under the control of the UN, mainly because of the practical difficulties associated.

PARA.TAB: I think if you go back and read Senator Evans's view, you will see that he also did not endorse that. But what Senator Evans has especially been active on—and he can speak for himself, you can ask him a question—is trying to get the UN the necessary funds, the means to generate the funds, to have a proper involvement around the globe. So I do not think there is any dichotomy between Senator Evans's and my views on this. If there is, it is only at the edges, and that is what government is about—a conflict of ideas and views in which we eventually develop a government policy, and then all sides accept that as the final policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Defence, by way of a supplementary question, is it not true that your attitude really is the one that you have previously expressed about the UN's management of peacekeeping, namely, that the effort in Bosnia is—and I quote—`a half-arsed exercise', and isn't the conflict between you and the foreign minister really what you said earlier about foreign ministers being the ones who make these decisions and defence ministers being the ones who receive the body bags at home?

—I have not been backward when necessary in criticising the United Nations' military intervention where it has shown weakness. I also have not been backward in paying tribute to its activities in Namibia, in Cambodia and elsewhere where they have been successful. But I do not think much time should be spent on mere congratulations on success; it is where weaknesses emerge, and weaknesses have emerged in Bosnia, to an extent in Somalia and—to a lesser extent but still there—in Rwanda. Those particular questions must be addressed and rectified.

PARA.TAB: But I also say this: Senator Gareth Evans will find, when he visits the UN next week, that the amount of resources the UN is currently devoting to its military operations is insufficient to be successful. It is one of the reasons why Australia and some other forward-thinking countries have made competent officers available and seconded them to New York, to try to make up that deficit. But it still exists. There are four intelligence officers to cover the whole globe, and they are amateurs at that. They have to rely on other countries to provide intelligence, all of which is filtered and, currently, independently assessed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a brief personal explanation as I claim to have been misrepresented.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, in manifest ignorance of the nature of issues involved as well as the precise text of what I said in the United Nations, Senator Newman offered the nostrum that I was in support of a particular rapid deployment force concept in a way that put me in some conflict with Senator Ray. The truth of the matter is quite otherwise; I completely endorse what Senator Ray has said. What I said in the UN a few days ago was this:

SPEECH.PARA: Particular attention has been given recently to the question of improving the United Nation's rapid reaction capability, and I warmly commend the work that has been done to clarify our thinking on these issues by the Netherlands and Danish Governments, and particularly in the major Canadian report, Towards a Rapid Reaction Capability for the United Nations, just presented to the Assembly. The very useful emphasis of the Canadian study is on the idea of improving the UN system's capability at the centre first—particularly in the area of operational planning—and thereby encouraging greater willingness by troop contributors to give practical and more urgent effect to standby arrangements. No organisational arrangements will substitute for clear-eyed decision-making by the Security Council on the responses and mandates that are appropriate to particular situations, but the implementation of changes of this kind should make us much better equipped as an international community to deal in the future with situations like that in Rwanda, where last time our response was so tragically inadequate.

There are important issues of principle here; important issues of practice at work here. My mind has been trying to get around what the art of the possible might be for some time now, and I have expressed a number of views over the last couple of years on how we might best approach this issue.

PARA.TAB: I am now unequivocally of the view, after reading these reports and being involved in many discussions in many parts of the world, that the best way to proceed in the first instance is not by trying to create a separate force, either as a volunteer force or with a set of identified earmarking arrangements which would have people located in a particular place and available for this purpose. That might be a workable concept in the longer term, but right now the immediate need is to improve the UN's managerial capabilities, strategic and operational planning capability, logistics capability and all the rest of it at the centre in order to make possible more effective and rapid reaction in the future.

I do wish Senator Newman, rather than asking silly questions, would just make herself a little bit better informed in the future about the nature of these issues, because that would stop a lot of people being misled about the nature of the issues that are involved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook), to a question without notice asked by Senator Tambling this day, relating to housing affordability.

SPEECH.PARA: This is an important issue and, as I said at the time of the supplementary question, Senator Cook was obviously either avoiding the issue or not coming to grips with the reality of Labor's failing economic policies, particularly as they impact on young Australians seeking to secure—whether that is to buy or to rent—a home for the first time in Australia. Very obviously, the housing affordability indices of various bodies—whether it was the Real Estate Institute, which I cited, the Commonwealth Bank or the Housing Industry Association—all make it very clear that we do have a problem of major proportions for many and, in fact, just about all young people in Australia.

PARA.TAB: The fact that the Real Estate Institute index shows that housing affordability is now 36 per cent lower than in March 1983 really shows the Labor government's hand on this issue. I was appalled at the response by Senator Cook, who showed absolutely no sympathy for and no identification with young people in Australia. He waffled on about the increase in the size and standard of an average house today. He waffled on about increased areas of contribution. He talked about the costs and wages rising, but he did not put them in proportion to the cost of a house today compared with the increases in an average family's wage or salary or with the costs that they experience. It is that widening gap that is the major issue and threat.

As I said in the original question, this matter was raised by the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, on 5 October, when he said, `The housing affordability index is very good now.' That is a fine quote. It is an easy throwaway line on a radio station, but it really does have no connection whatsoever to the problems or to the identification. I hope people were listening at the time of that radio broadcast, which I think was in Melbourne with Peter Couchman.

Anyone seeking to purchase a house or rent a house would know that what the Prime Minister said on that occasion was nothing short of absolute hypocrisy. Here we have a Prime Minister who throws taxpayers' dollars around building carports at the Lodge that are more expensive than an average family home in Australia. We all know that Mr Keating has purchased a magnificent mansion for his own retirement in Woollahra at a cost of some $2 million. Senator Cook stands up and talks about the square metres of a house being increased marginally. There is no comparison with what Mr Keating is currently doing. If he is spending $2 million of his personal money—he has probably borrowed the whole lot of it under some fancy arrangement or deal—how does that compare to the position of a struggling family in the outer suburbs of Sydney or, in my case, in Darwin in the Northern Territory? How does the Prime Minister's reality compare? He says housing affordability is very good now. It is very good now for Mr Keating but it is not very good now for the average family seeking to secure a home, particularly those seeking to secure a home for the first time.

There are many other issues related to housing affordability. The housing industry is in crisis. We have certainly seen a slump, not only in confidence but also in the whole construction industry. That impacts back to every family in Australia. Anyone who knows a young person seeking to be employed as an apprentice or a tradesman knows that it is just so much harder now to get work in industry because it is just not there. The economy is failing.

So whilst my question today sought more information on housing affordability, what that question flushed out of Senator Cook was the fact that this government had no knowledge whatsoever of how it was impacting on average families and young people throughout Australia, on their jobs and on their homes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Howard won himself a nice cheap little headline a few days ago when he said in a speech that real average monthly mortgage repayments have risen from $674 in 1983 to $951 in 1995. That was reflected in the equally cheap shots advanced by Senator Tambling today. The truth is that the increase of around 50 per cent in real monthly mortgage repayments since 1983, as claimed by Mr Howard, is more than accounted for by an increase of over 60 per cent in the real average loan size. The reason the real average loan size has gone up to the extent that it has is overwhelmingly because people have been buying bigger and better houses. You can attack Senator Cook for talking about square metres and so on but that is the truth of the matter: the increase in real average loan size reflects in the first instance an increase in real average house prices of over 30 per cent since 1983 as a result of bigger and better houses, with the average size of a new house increasing from 167 square metres in 1983-84 to 198 square metres in 1994-95, which is an increase of 18.5 per cent.

PARA.TAB: The other reason for these figures showing up as they do is that there has been an increase in the loan to valuation ratio by about 20 per cent since the March quarter of 1983, which reflects the ability to obtain a greater proportion of the required finance from a low cost provider as compared—as Senator Cook again said in his answer—to the expensive cocktail financing that was the only way you could put these things together in the past. It also reflects the use of loans secured against housing to finance other expenditure, which has also become a much more common phenomenon in the community over the last 10 years. The truth of the matter—and it can never be gainsaid—is that mortgage interest rates, which are a major determinant of mortgage repayments obviously, have fallen sharply since 1983. Benchmark variable rates for major banks declined from 12 1/2 per cent in March 1983, and even higher at 13 1/2 per cent in December 1982, to 10 1/2 per cent in June 1995. There are plenty of finance providers, newer banks and mortgage brokers, as again Senator Cook said, who are prepared to substantially undercut these rates. That is the truth of the matter.

What is the position so far as overall housing affordability is concerned? The truth of the matter, when you cut out the political nonsense that Senator Tambling was going on with, is that housing affordability does remain at a high level, despite a fall which occurred last year, mainly reflecting increases at the time in mortgage interest rates.

The decline in affordability last year followed more than three years of rising affordability, to a record peak in late 1983. Again, in 1995, the affordability index has improved. The index published by the Commonwealth Bank of Australia and the Housing Industry Association rose by 2.3 per cent in the March quarter and fell back a little in June; but it does reflect stable interest rates and the continued increase in household incomes which have partly offset some increase in house prices. The basic point is and remains the fact that affordability is well above the levels of the late 1980s and is around 42 per cent above the trough in 1989. That is the situation, as the figures demonstrate and as is being experienced out there in the marketplace. Huffing and puffing by Senator Tambling or anyone else is not going to change that basic situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was intrigued to hear the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans) in his last few remarks say that the late 1980s was a standard for comparison. Let us remember who was in government in the late 1980s—it was Labor. Comparing a disaster under Labor with another disaster under Labor seems to me a curious way of trying to demonstrate that the Labor government has somehow achieved some great step forward. The fact is that, yes, more battlers in Australia are now finding it more and more difficult to pay off their houses. Certainly, for them—they are the people Labor has abandoned—housing affordability is now a disaster.
