PARA.TAB: We can see that very clearly from recent media exposure of the gap between what people are owing on their houses and the value of the houses—the negative equity that so many Australians now face. They have borrowed more on their houses than their houses are now worth. This is a disastrous situation that is a direct result of this government's policies. For example, the media has quite properly revealed the enormity of this problem in the marginal seats of Macarthur and Gilmore in New South Wales. Let us consider houses that cost around $120,000. I know members of the Labor Party would not understand a house costing $120,000 when the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) happily spends $250,000 on a carport at the Lodge—that is roughly two normal houses for the battlers of south-western Sydney. Naturally, those members do not understand the reality of the problem. This problem is a very serious one. Senator Evans can quote figures about the increase in the amounts of the loan; but that has brought about this sort of result. Yes, there are bigger loans on individual houses—

TALK.START.PARA: —Because there are bigger costs.

—As Senator Tambling has interjected, there are bigger costs. The fact is that having a bigger loan as a percentage of the value of the house involves increasing risk to those people—those battlers—who, having gone into a house with a very high gearing, find that a small reduction in the marketplace wipes out their equity in their home. It is not just one individual location in one section of Sydney; it is throughout Australia.

PARA.TAB: Channel 9 demonstrated that, in Melbourne, these people—low income earners who had suffered either retrenchment or some other financial difficulty—were finding that they could not sell their homes because they would get so much less than the homes were worth. I think in one instance there was something like a $9,000 loss facing these people—the people the Labor Party is supposed to represent—if they were forced to sell their house even after having paid interest for some two, three or four years on it.

This is a disaster for the battlers' end of the housing market, for the people who desperately want to have their own houses and get out of the rental system but who simply cannot afford to now if they are looking at housing affordability in general or if they have made that exciting move into their own homes. They now find that because of the high borrowing they have undertaken and the fall in the housing market as a result of this government's policies, they owe more than their houses are worth.

I expect that the Labor Party will eventually wake up to this. It happens to be in almost every one of the marginal seats they just hold on to around Australia. Firstly, it is politically stupid of them to ignore this large group of battlers. Secondly, it is grossly unfair that their policies should hit the battlers of Australia, who are struggling to buy their own homes. They are the very people about whom the Liberal Party is concerned. As we will demonstrate when our policies are revealed, they will be protected against the sort of actions that the Labor Party has deliberately chosen to impose on them. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the problems with housing that we have today is that people are playing politics in the housing industry and they do not appear to be telling the whole truth in relation to what is happening. It is quite obvious that larger houses are being built and that people are paying more for homes than before because of that increase in the size of homes. For instance, I know a couple of young battlers who started off by buying a house at $110,000 and who are now living in a house that is worth half a million dollars. The husband did very well in business and has paid for a house in that price vicinity.
—That will go over well with the battlers.

—They were battlers. Although Senator Herron does not believe it, there is an opportunity in this country for people to rise above where they are. This young lad did. He had a business, did very well at the business and moved himself into a $500,000 house. But that is not the point I am making. It is happening to a large number of people throughout the community. It is not just an isolated case.

PARA.TAB: Senator Baume said that battlers who encounter a problem when living in their home have to sell the house and that they cannot gain the valuation of the house or the amount of money that they borrowed against it. There has to be some responsibility in this in relation to the banks. Before you can get a loan, the first thing you have to do is go to the bank. The bank inspects the house and values it. It then decides whether it will lend you the money. You tell the bank that you have the deposit to meet the requirements, and you accept the loan that it offers you. Surely the banks have some responsibility if they are overvaluing the houses and people are taking larger loans than they should be. That is what is happening in lots of cases.

Today you can borrow money to buy a house on a 10 per cent deposit. A few years ago, you could not do this; the banks were not competing as hard with one another. You would need 25 to 35 per cent or in some cases even up to 50 per cent of the amount of money that you wanted to borrow. On 10 per cent, you are now borrowing the balance of the money against the house. The bank values it. Surely the bank is not stupid enough to overvalue the house. For example, it will not say that the house is valued at $200,000, give you a $180,000 loan and then find later, when it goes to sell it, that the house is only valued at $115,000.

There is some responsibility in the housing industry. There is a responsibility in the recent actions of the banks when lending money to the battler for a house. Another consideration that has to be taken into account is that the amount of deposit that is being paid by people purchasing a house is much less. They now need a much smaller deposit than they needed years ago. Therefore, if they run into some problems, there is a greater risk to the self. Of course, the amount of interest they pay in the first two or three years does not pay very much off the principal. I think everyone here understands that the interest paid in the first two or three years hardly pays anything off the principal. So it is very difficult to return the money borrowed.

The other thing that is happening, which I think everyone also knows but no-one has mentioned, is that the building industry is starting to level out. The cost of housing and the cost of land has levelled out. It has not moved to the extent it was moving. Now the government has inflation under control I do not believe that in the future costs to this industry will move to the extent that they moved over the last period of years.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with deep regret that I inform the Senate of the death on 10 October 1995 of former Senator Arnold Joseph Drury OAM, a senator for the state of South Australia from 1959 to 1975.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate expresses its deep regret at the death, on Tuesday, 10 October 1995, of former Senator Arnold Joseph Drury, OAM, a Senator for the State of South Australia from 1959 to 1975, places on record its appreciation of his long and meritorious public service, and tenders its profound sympathy to his family in their bereavement.

SPEECH.PARA: Arnold Drury was born in Adelaide on 23 July 1912. Prior to his election to the Senate, his working life was with the company Julius Cohn where he rose to the position of foreman overseeing the manufacture of food products. During World War II he enlisted in the Australian Military Force and later transferred to the 2nd Australian Imperial Force and served in the South West Pacific area. He was discharged in 1945.

PARA.TAB: Arnold Drury was first elected to the Senate in 1958 and took his seat in 1959. In his maiden speech, he showed a special concern for social justice and made reference to the importance of a just wage, family support and basic education. He made many contributions over his 16 years of parliamentary service. Of particular note was his work as chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence from 1973 to 1974, and as chairman of a subcommittee of the Joint Committee of Foreign Affairs on the South Pacific region from 1967 to 1972. He also served on the Senate committees on disputed returns and qualifications, publications, road safety, and metric system of weights and measures.

Arnold Drury retired from federal politics in 1975 but his contributions to the community never ceased. He was active in veterans' welfare, community hospital and charity work in his home state of South Australia. He was a valued member and office bearer of the Lockleys sub-branch of the RSL and the Knights of the Southern Cross. He was also deputy chairman of the RSL Hospital Visiting Committee, trustee of the Soldiers, Sailors and Airmen's Distress Fund and deputy chairman of the Thebarton Community Hospital Board.

He was awarded the Medal of the Order of Australia in the general division for service to the community in 1986. Arnold Drury will be fondly remembered and sadly missed by all those who knew him. On behalf of the government, I accordingly extend to his wife Mona, son Peter, daughter-in-law Kay, and grandchildren Mark, Karen, Helen and Craig our most sincere sympathy in their bereavement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on behalf of coalition senators to support this motion of condolence on the death of former Senator Arnold Joseph Drury. Former Senator Drury was born in Adelaide in 1912. I do not know a lot about his earlier life but I understand he worked as a manufacturing grocer and worked his way up through the ranks of the manufacturing grocers union and then the state ALP.

PARA.TAB: He did, as Senator Gareth Evans said, serve with the AIF during the Second World War in the South West Pacific area. Needless to say, he was one of a remarkable generation of Australian men and women whose efforts and sacrifices have been remembered this year in particular with the Australia Remembers celebrations and commemorations.

He was elected as a senator for South Australia in 1958, began his term in July the following year and served until November 1975. During that time he worked on several Senate committees including the disputed returns and qualifications committee and the foreign affairs and defence committee, which he also chaired. He also served on the joint committee of foreign affairs and defence, including its subcommittee on the South Pacific region, the area in which he had served during the war.

I want to make reference to one of his comments, which was in a 1973 report of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence, in relation to Japan. In noting that the relationship between Australia and Japan was based largely on trade, he stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee believes that trading alone does not provide an adequate foundation for long-term warm relations between the two countries. I believe that much effort must be devoted to the strengthening of personal relationships between the peoples of Australia and Japan.

As a former serviceman who fought in the Pacific against the Japanese, I think these words give us some insight into the character of the man. On behalf of coalition senators, I express our condolences to his wife and family.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to associate members of the National Party in the Senate with the condolence motion moved by the government for Arnold Drury, who passed away last week at the great age of 85. Arnold Drury was born in Adelaide in 1912 and was educated at the Dominican Convent in Adelaide. After leaving school he joined the grocery manufacturing sector where he worked for the next 30 years, interrupted only by his war service. He entered the Senate in 1958. He enlisted in the Australian Military Force in August 1942. After being transferred to the 2nd Australian Imperial Force he served in the South West Pacific.

PARA.TAB: In 1958, Arnold Drury was elected as a Labor Party senator for South Australia. He was elected for three terms, during which his interest in defence matters was reflected by his membership of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence. He was chairman of that committee from 1973 to 1974. He was a staunch advocate for the veterans of the Second World War and he reminded the Senate on key repatriation bills that the freedoms enjoyed by Australians were directly due to the efforts and the suffering of service men and women and that those disabled during their war service had a right to expect every measure of support possible from the government.

Arnold Drury also served on the Senate Select Committee on Road Safety and the Senate Select Committee on the Metric System of Weights and Measures. He attended parliamentary delegations to South East Asia in 1963 and the South Pacific Commission Conference in 1970 and was an observer at the 29th session of the General Assembly of the United Nations in 1974.

Arnold Drury had a long career in federal politics, most of which was spent in opposition. I imagine that it was very gratifying for him to finish his career in government. Arnold Drury made a significant contribution to Australian public life through his war service and tireless parliamentary work representing the people of South Australia for 16 years. I am sure all honourable senators will join with me in extending sympathy to Arnold Drury's family and friends.

TALK.START.PARA: —A great deal has been said already about former Senator Arnold Joseph Drury. The Democrats endorse those remarks. We would like to be associated with this condolence motion and also extend our sympathy to his family.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —As a senator for South Australia and as an Australian Labor Party official in South Australia in the 1970s, I wish to speak to the condolence motion for former Senator Drury. When I joined the party in 1965, as a very young person, Arnold Drury was already a senator for South Australia. I appreciated very much the kindness and support he extended to me, and many other people of my age, at that time on becoming active in the Labor Party. I know of no state or federal member of parliament who acted in a more gentlemanly manner in their conduct with both their colleagues and their opponents than Senator Drury. His particular interest in social welfare and repatriation matters is well known. As an adviser in the Whitlam government to the then Minister for Repatriation, Senator Bishop, I remember his very strong interest in these areas as well as his strong interest in the broader issues of foreign affairs and defence.

PARA.TAB: Former Senator Drury won the third position in the Senate for the Labor Party team in the 1958 general election and half Senate election. It was not expected that the Labor Party would win the third seat in that election because of the split that had then occurred in Labor Party, but it was Arnold Drury's selection, his campaigning and his support from a broad range of community groups in South Australia that enabled him to win the third position for the Labor Party and to go on over the subsequent 16 years to serve the Senate and, above all else, the people of South Australia with considerable distinction and dignity.

He retired at the 1975 election because of the age rule that the Labor Party then had. I think he felt a bit disappointed that, at the time of that election in the crisis circumstance of the 1975 double dissolution when the Whitlam government was sacked, he was standing down from the Senate. Though Arnold Drury was a great gentleman, his outrage at the events at that time was very strong indeed.

On behalf of the South Australian branch of the Labor Party and my fellow federal members in both the Senate and the House of Representatives, I place on record our recognition of his long contribution to the South Australian Labor Party and, in particular, to the South Australian community. We pass on our condolences to his wife and family.
Question resolved in the affirmative, honourable senators standing in their places.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with deep regret that I inform the Senate of the death on Sunday, 24 September 1995 of Leonard Keith Johnson, a member of the House of Representatives for the division of Burke from 1969 to 1980.
—It is with deep regret that I inform the Senate of the death on Monday, 9 October 1995 of Lord Home, British Prime Minister from 1963 to 1964.
—Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Freedom of Choice
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The humble Petition of the Citizens of Australia, respectfully showeth:
That we:
(1) Affirm the importance of quality education for all the children of this Commonwealth of Australia irrespective of their religion, nationality or sex;
(2) Support the rights of parents to have freedom of choice of the school for their child;
(3) Support the right of all non-government schools to maintain their distinctive moral values and foundational ethos;
(4) Support the freedom of choice in staffing of all Churches and religious organisations.
(5) Support freedom of religion and the right of all Churches and religious organisations to maintain their distinctive foundational ethos.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate oppose any attempts to introduce legislation that would jeopardise these freedoms and rights and which would force Schools, Churches and religious institutions to compromise their distinctive moral values and foundational ethos.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray:

PETITION.TITLE: Recycled Paper
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned strongly opposes attempts by the Government to reintroduce sales tax of 22% on the following recycled paper products from 1 November 1995 to include:

PARA.TAB: writing, drawing or printing paper (including pads of writing, drawing or printing paper), paper of a kind ordinarily used in accounting ledgers or accounting journals and envelopes.
Your Petitioners ask that the Senate take action to reject this proposed change.

PETITION.TITLE: Landmines
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The Petition of the undersigned shows that we citizens of Australia support a world-wide ban on the production, stockpiling and use of all forms of anti-personnel land mines.

Your Petitioners request that the Senate support our call for a world-wide ban on the production, stockpiling and use of all forms of anti-personnel land mines, give high priority to support for efforts to clear land mines in affected countries and use its influence to encourage other countries to financially support the clearance of land mines in poor countries.

PETITION.TITLE: French Nuclear Testing
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The Petition of the undersigned:
1. Condemns the President of France, Jacques Chirac, and the French Government for deciding to resume nuclear testing at Mururoa Atoll;
2. Joins in the world-wide anger over France's decision, which calls into question France's commitment to the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty;
3. Urges the Federal Government to urgently inform France in the strongest possible terms of the anger felt by the people of Australia at the decision;
4. Calls on the Federal Government to consider all available diplomatic; economic and cultural measures which may force the French Government to cancel nuclear testing.

PETITION.PARA: And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: French Nuclear Testing
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: We, the undersigned, wish to lodge our protest in the strongest possible terms against the resumption of Nuclear Testing. Therefore we request:
1. the immediate and permanent cessation of mining and the export of Uranium as a signal to all nations that we will not accept nuclear weapons in any form,
2. the use of all means possible to dissuade France and any other nation from Nuclear Weapons Testing,
3. that the Minister for Foreign Affairs make a submission arguing the illegality of Nuclear Weapons to the International Court of Justice.
To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:
The Petition of the undersigned urges the Government to press for a total ban internationally on the production, stockpiling, trade and use of anti-personnel devices;
Your Petitioners ask that the Senate urge the Government to provide financial aid for the de-mining of countries such as Cambodia.

PETITION.TITLE: Marks Royal Commission
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: The Petition of the undersigned expresses widespread community concern about the Federal Labor Government's decision to pay Dr Carmen Lawrence's legal expenses in her legal challenges to stop the Marks Royal Commission.
Your Petitioners ask that the Senate:
(a)note and endorse the concerns expressed in this petition; and
(b)call on the Government:

TAB.TAB: (i)to publish full details of the basis of the decision by Cabinet, including copies of official advice; and
(ii)to immediately reverse the decision and cease public funding of attempts to stop Commissioner Marks finding the truth about the Penny Easton petition.

PETITION.TITLE: Child Care
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Senators in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows: the unjust and inequitable nature of the Government's policy to restrict Childcare Assistance where a parent is outside the workforce to 12 hours per week. This policy will cause hardship to lower income families, to the children of those families, and child care workers. The Government should be condemned for breaking its promise to ensure access and affordability in child care.

Under the Government's policy parents will have to pay full cost fees after 12 hours of childcare per week if one parent is outside the workforce. This will widen the gap between rich and poor, and many child care workers may lose their jobs.
Your petitioners therefore ask that the Senate should oppose the passage of this Bill into law.

PETITION.TITLE: Child Care
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Senators in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: We, the undersigned, request that the Senate oppose the proposed legislation of restricting parents who are unemployed and receive child care assistance to a limit of 12 hours per week.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, I give notice that 15 sitting days after today I shall move that the following delegated legislation be disallowed:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Public Service Determination 1995/58, made under section 82D of the Public Service Act 1922
2.Determination of Technical Standard Notice TN5 of 1995, made under section 244 of the Telecommunications Act 1991
3.Remuneration Tribunal Determination No.12 of 1995, made under section 8 of the Remuneration Tribunal Act 1973
4.Employment Services (Participants) Determination No.2 of 1995, made under section 25 of the Employment Services Act 1994
5.Employment Services (Terminating Events) Determination No.2 of 1995, made under section 26 of the Employment Services Act 1994
6.Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1995 No.240, and made under the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act 1993

7.Prawn Export Promotion Levies and Charges Regulations, as contained in Statutory Rules 1995 No.245, and made under the Prawn Export Promotion Act 1995, the Prawn Export Charge Act 1995 and the Prawn Boat Levy Act 1995
I seek leave to make a short statement about the committee's concerns with this legislation.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The committee's concerns with these instruments include discretions which may not be subject to merits review, possible invalid incorporation, subdelegation of legislative power and failure to effect legislative intent. As usual, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a short summary of the matters raised by the committee.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The summary read as follows—

PARA.EMPHASIS: Public Service Determination 1995/58, made under section 82D of the Public Service Act 1922

SPEECH.PARA: This Determination provides for increases in the level of salaries for unattached Secretaries.
The Determination was made on 16 June 1995. Clause 4.1, which commenced retrospectively on 1 March 1995, provided for salary increases for named unattached secretaries of Departments.

Clause 4.2, for which no commencement date is specified, provides for the deletion of a specified name from the list of relevant secretaries. The Explanatory Memorandum advises that this person retired on 5 May 1995.

The Committee has written to the Minister seeking advice on when this officer ceased to be entitled to the salary provided for him by this Determination. Advice was also sought from the Minister on whether this cessation was effected by the present Determination, or whether there is another legislative provision under which the relevant provision of the present Determination was rendered nugatory on 5 May 1995 and clause 4.2 became legally superfluous from that date.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Determination of Technical Standard Notice TN5 of 1995, made under section 244 of the Telecommunications Act 1991

SPEECH.PARA: This instrument determines the Technical Standard "End-to-End Network Performance" No.TS27-1995.
Clause 5 of the Explanatory Statement advises that, "Carriers will be required to regularly report to AUSTEL to demonstrate compliance with the standard.".

The Committee has written to the Minister seeking advice on whether such mandatory reports are required by legislative authority or whether they will be obtained by administrative means. The Committee asked the Minister for detailed advice on possible review of any adverse decision about compliance.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Remuneration Tribunal Determination No.12 of 1995, made under section 8 of the Remuneration Tribunal Act 1973

SPEECH.PARA: This Determination fixes the salary and allowances of a named officer who is a Director of the Civil Aviation Safety Authority.

Clause 1(i) provides that a specified salary is to be reduced by the amount of any superannuation contributions payable by the Civil Aviation Safety Authority in accordance with arrangements approved by the Minister for Finance. Clause 2(i) provides that performance pay, subject to a ceiling, shall be assessed by the Board of the Civil Aviation Safety Authority in accordance with guidelines advised from time to time by the Tribunal.
The Committee has written to the Minister seeking advice on whether these subdelegations are valid.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Employment Services (Participants) Determination No.2 of 1995,made under section 25 of the Employment Services Act 1994 andEmployment Services (Terminating Events) Determination No.2 of 1995, made under section 26 of the Employment Services Act 1994

SPEECH.PARA: These Determinations specify classes of persons that may become participants in the case management system and specifies events or circumstances that will result in a participant exiting from the case management system.

Clause 4 of the Participants Determination refers to the Disability Reform Package Strategy and to other strategies, packages and initiatives. Clause 4 of the Terminating Events Determination also refers to the Disability Reform Package Strategy. The Committee has written to the Minister seeking advice on whether the Determinations refer to these strategies and other instruments as in force at the time the Determination came into effect, or whether there is legislative authority for them to be applied as in force from time to time.

Both Determinations provide for the exercise of discretions which may have serious adverse effects on individuals. There is no indication in the Explanatory Statement of review of the merits of adverse decisions. The Committee has asked the Minister for advice on review. provisions.

The Terminating Events Determination confers specific powers on the Employment Secretary. The Committee has asked the Minister whether there is legislative authority for these powers to be delegated and, if so, to whom.

The Regulations insert a Schedule into the principal Regulations listing those public sector superannuation schemes that are exempt from the Act and the Regulations in respect of their 1994-95 and 1995-96 years of income.

New r.1.04(4B) provides that, if a scheme listed in the Schedule is renamed, the reference to that scheme includes the scheme as so re-named. Some of the schemes are established under Commonwealth Acts, others under State or Territory Acts, others under trust deeds and others by other means.
The Committee has written to the Minister seeking advice on whether these automatic changes from time to time are valid under s.49A of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Prawn Export Promotion Levies and Charges Regulations Statutory Rules 1995 No.245

SPEECH.PARA: The Regulations set the level of levies and charges and provide a regime for their administration and collection.

Regulation 4 provides for the measurement of ships for the purposes of the prawn boat levy. Subregulation 4(2) provides that if the length of the ship is disputed, the length may be determined by a surveyor employed by the Australian Maritime Safety Authority with the costs being borne by the owner of the ship.

The Committee has written to the Minister seeking advice on the reasons why such reviews are to be conducted by a paid employee of a statutory authority and why the costs are to be met by the owners. In this context, section 8 of the Australian Maritime Safety Authority Act 1990 provides that the Minister may give written directions to AMSA, although these may only be of a general nature. The Committee suggests that the appearance of independence may be enhanced if the review, or an appeal from a review, could be undertaken by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

(a)notes:

TAB.TAB: (i)the arrogant disregard for the citizens of Australia by the Australian Labor Party (ALP), and in particular the members of staff of Labor Members of Parliament in refusing to carry out the duties for which they are employed and paid at taxpayers' expense, and
