DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Keating Government: Economic and Social Policies

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Childs)—The President has received a letter from Senator Hill proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

The disillusionment and disadvantage faced by mainstream Australian families because of Mr Keating's failed economic and social policies which have resulted in higher youth unemployment, declining housing affordability and the growing gap between the rich and poor.

PROCTEXT.PARA: I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

PARA.TAB: More than the number of senators required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand the Labor party's reticence about debating this issue but it is one of vital national importance. We are nearing the completion of almost 14 years of Labor government in this country and we have three areas that are causing particular concern to what we might refer to as mainstream Australia—which really incorporates most Australians.

PARA.TAB: The first of those issues is the fact that unemployment is again rising and youth unemployment remains at such appalling high levels. The second issue concerns the decline in housing affordability, and linked to that is the highly unusual situation for Australia where home owners and home buyers are finding that their equity in their homes is falling. In a number of instances the home owner's debt is greater than his equity. The third issue concerns an appalling legacy from a Labor government of a greater gap between rich and poor than existed when it came to office. Those are three areas of debate which are vitally important to all Australians and issues which should be discussed in the Senate today.

I start with the unemployment picture. This issue is obviously topical in view of the release of the unemployment statistics last week. Those figures showed that unemployment has risen slightly, but nevertheless has risen to 8.55 per cent. Over 760,000 Australians are now unemployed. It is particularly worrying because under this Labor government's policies during the recession, unemployment rose to a record high level since the war. As the Senate will recall, we reached over one million unemployed. During the recovery from the recession the figure of unemployed has very slowly reduced but now, some years on, we find that the trend has started to move up again.

There is probably no statistic that could be a greater indictment and a greater worry to most Australians than that of 760,000 Australians out of work. For the young Australians who want work, but who are unable to get it, we have a national figure of some 27 per cent. This is the situation in a country that is so potentially rich. It is an appalling record for any administration.

What is happening should be obvious even to this Labor government. The government made it plain that to continue to reduce unemployment we needed economic growth in this country of 4.5 per cent or higher. Now, of course, that economic growth has slipped away, even in the government's own estimates, to between three and four per cent and trending down. The Minister for Industry, Science and Technology, Senator Cook, did not seem to be able to understand it at question time today, but on those figures it becomes impossible to further eat into this mass unemployment which will be the legacy of the Keating Labor government.

The economic growth that is now taking place under this government's economic foundation is simply insufficient to further reduce that level of mass unemployment. Mr Keating himself recognised it when he accepted that 4.5 per cent was a necessary minimum. As you will recall, Mr Acting Deputy President, Mr Keating said, `If you can't achieve growth of four per cent then you ought to give the game away.' It was prophetic because economic growth has now slipped under that level and is projected to go even lower. There can be no other logical consequence than that the government will cease to eat into this mass unemployment.

Many other statistics are available that reinforce our concerns. If we look at the figures for overtime we find that they reached a peak of 18 per cent in December last year and declined to 16 per cent in September 1995 and are still falling. If the government looks to its own indications, such as the trend as demonstrated in its DEET figures, it will find that it has clearly stabilised and is now starting to slowly reduce. The tragedy of unemployment still shows an average of 27.8 per cent. During question time today Senator Cook tried to talk his way through that subject. For young people who are seeking work the figure is 27.8 per cent—25.2 per cent for males and 32 per cent for females. There is no way that Senator Cook can avoid that.

If we look at the graphs of history we find that six years ago the comparable figure was 15 per cent. It is now 27 per cent. Senator Ian Macdonald is particularly concerned about regional areas where the situation is worse. The Labor government has failed to address this issue. Areas in the cities are still in tragic circumstances. In Victoria, the Liberal government has been trying to rebuild the state economy after the disaster of Labor governments. Some areas still have over 50 per cent youth unemployment. The same situation applies in western New South Wales. In my state of South Australia much the same picture exists. The disastrous Bannon government practically bankrupted the state. As a result, in the northern suburbs of Adelaide we have 34 per cent youth unemployment, 30 per cent in the western suburbs, 43 per cent in the eastern suburbs, and in the southern suburbs—in such seats as Kingston, the seat of the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs (Mr Bilney)—youth unemployment is at 45 per cent. Thus the picture continues.

Unfortunately, these Liberal governments have had to pick up the legacy of failed Labor inheritance. The same situation exists nationally. Despite the improving economic circumstances overall, the task of eating into those shameful unemployment figures for youth remains very difficult. That is the picture on unemployment. Not only is it tragic, but it is now on the rise again and there is no greater or more dramatic reason why this government should stand condemned. It does not deserve to be re-elected.

The second issue I mentioned was this very worrying one of housing affordability. We raise this matter today following the release of the Real Estate Institute of Australia figures. This body does not have any vested interest in talking down the affordability of housing. In its publication the institute keeps saying that it hopes the trend will discontinue. The trend for housing affordability under this government has been a deteriorating trend. The latest figures indicate that loan affordability has declined for the sixth consecutive quarter. Affordability is at its lowest level since 1992. This occurs at a time when the great Australian dream is still so important to most Australians. The fact that people's capacity to afford to buy a home is declining is of great concern to them. It is not surprising that Australians are upset with this government.

The minister likes to make comparisons. If we compare the situation in the 1980s with that of the early 1990s we find that housing affordability now stands at 33 index points whereas at the beginning of the 1980s it stood at 57 index points. Housing affordability has steadily declined under this government to the extent that it is half of what it was. The decline from 57 index points to 33 index points is a decline in affordability over the last 15 years of 43.3 per cent. What causes that? Regrettably, it is high and rising interest rates—a legacy of this government. Real interest rates are still around the highest in the western world.

Inflation is rising again. We have the same consequences. The government no longer seems to be able to control underlying inflation. Why? Because of wage pressures. That is not surprising because the government's Accord has artificially suppressed wages in this country and average weekly wages have fallen. It is not surprising that housing affordability has suffered as a result. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a matter of public importance, raised by the opposition, about the economy, and one can say that we welcome the debate. It is raised by the opposition really out of fear for their own position—fear that, despite their attempt to label themselves as the battlers' party, the public of Australia still see them as a party for privilege, a party for special interests and, most importantly, a party without any policies and only platitudes to fill the gap.

PARA.TAB: One of the reasons the opposition has raised this matter of public importance out of fear is that, in today's news services, on the wires, there is a report on what the consumers of Australia think about the future of the Australian economy. What the ordinary people of Australia believe to be their future is an important consideration. This matter of public importance tries to produce a picture of gloom and doom. The figures for October, from the Roy Morgan Research Centre polling on consumer confidence, are reported as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: Consumer confidence in October rose to its highest point for 1995 with a significant boost in expectations of future economic conditions, the Roy Morgan Research Centre said today.
It goes on:
The Morgan Consumer Confidence Rating, to be published in the Bulletin this week, rose 4.5 points in October to 116.2.
That is not an indication that the public of Australia believe the opposition.

PARA.TAB: But, Mr Acting Deputy President, the fiction of this MPI is the big lie tactic that the opposition is deploying. Their big lie tactic is to paint gloom and doom in the expectation that they can mould perceptions within Australia. But, no matter how hard they attempt to mould perceptions about a failing economy, they will not be able to change the facts in any way.

This MPI, which talks of failed economic and social justice policies, defies the facts. The facts do not present that sort of picture and, no matter how hard Senator Hill tries to contort the statistics, he will not be able to avoid what stands before the eyes of the public as plain as a pikestaff—the record of economic achievement of this government.

In fact, one is encouraged to ask the question: against what social policy base does the opposition operate, and against what social principles of compassion and concern for those Australians in less fortunate positions than those in employment does the opposition act? On the weekend, at the ACOSS meeting, we heard from John Howard a list of things the opposition will not do. We never heard anything from him about what the opposition will do. There is a major question mark hanging over what they will not do—a question mark which says, `How can you afford to reconcile what you say you will do in terms of outlays and promises that you have made to other interest groups and balance a budget, as you promise you will do, and afford the welfare costs that there are in Australia because of your concern for the underprivileged and for those less fortunate and less able to defend themselves'?

Let me just work through a couple of the statistics, and let the statistics speak for themselves. On youth unemployment, the number of teenagers looking for full-time work is at its lowest level since April 1990. In September, it fell by 2,900 to 88,500. In March 1983, when Labor came to power, there were more than 158,000 young people looking for full-time work—nearly 80 per cent more than there are today. That hardly speaks to the point of this MPI about youth unemployment, or concern for unemployment. The record of the opposition in government is one of massive unemployment, double digit unemployment, and our record in government is one of bringing unemployment down from those peaks.

Indeed, with respect to youth unemployment, the figures need to be thought about and considered quite properly in detail before anyone jumps to conclusions, because the figure most commentators have been using is 27 per cent. In fact, the official unemployment rate for 15- to 19-year-olds, as measured by the ABS, is 20.7 per cent, which is the original data. But even this, in many respects, is misleading for this group, as has been recognised by a number of pundits, including the Melbourne Age newspaper on 13 October this year.

As an ABS study found, most of the teenagers counted as unemployed are, in fact, students looking for part-time work. While there were 88,500, 15- to 19-year-olds looking for full-time work—and these figures are seasonally adjusted—this is only around seven per cent of the total population aged 15 to 19. So when we have these figures bandied about, as Senator Hill did, of 27 per cent, they should be seen against that fact: that the ABS, in fact, is counting many students who are looking for part-time work in that figure. The real figure is around only seven per cent of the total population aged between 15 and 19. I think that exposes one of the big lies that the opposition is trying to foster in this campaign.

The other key factor is: which party—us or the opposition—is best suited to manage the economy? When John Howard was the Treasurer in Australia, the average rate of real economic growth was 2.6 per cent. Under Labor, for the nearly 13 years of our government, it has averaged for all of that time 3.5 per cent. If employment is the test, then let us look at the average number of jobs created per year. Under John Howard, when he was Treasurer, 51,300 for the whole of the Fraser period was the average number of jobs created; whereas under us, the average number of jobs created each year is 163,600. Compare those figures again: 51,300 or 163,600. That is the difference between these two parties.

If you look at the annual average growth in employment, when John Howard was Treasurer of the Commonwealth of Australia, employment on average grew annually at 0.8 per cent. It has been growing at 2.3 per cent under us. If you look at the unemployment rate when John Howard left office, it was at 10 per cent. It is 8.5 per cent now. The number of extra jobs created over the last 12 months in Australia is 333,200, and that is a considerable change on anything that the opposition has been able to produce.

I think that the biggest part of this big lie, however, is when the opposition talks about social security and social security pensions. As if this party has any justification for holding its head up in public on social security! It ought to be ashamed of itself; it ought to be disgusted with itself. Australians see through it, since it has fought Medicare all the way along the line and opposed its very existence. It has fought changes in pension rates in Australia all along the line.

Let me just give you a few examples here, in percentage terms, of real change. Under the coalition government—and this is the period December 1975 to March 1983; the period of the Fraser government when Mr Howard was Treasurer—the value of the pension for a single age pensioner not renting went down by 2.3 per cent. If they were renting privately, it went down by 2.2 per cent. Under us, `not renting' went up by 11.9 per cent, and `renting privately' went up by 20.4 per cent. For a pensioner couple, they went down 2.1 per cent in both categories under the coalition. They went up 12 per cent and 16.5 per cent under us.

Let us not have any of this cant about welfare, because the social welfare changes are quite dramatic. The real value of the Commonwealth social wage per person under John Howard in the period 1977-78 to 1982-83 declined by 17.5 per cent. The total value of the services delivered to the underprivileged in this country and to wage and salary earners reliant on a high standard of health care, a high standard of education and a high standard of other service delivery actually declined during the Fraser years, when John Howard was Treasurer, by 17.5 per cent. During our period of office, 1982-83 to 1995-96, it has gone up by 73.1 per cent. That should be sufficient to put an end to the issue of the underprivileged.

Let us turn to the subject of real wages, because again today Senator Hill misled the Senate when he insisted that real wages under a Labor government have fallen. That is just not true. I know the coalition wants to trot out that belief, but it is just not true.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. Pursuant to standing orders, it is unparliamentary to allege that an honourable senator has deliberately misled the Senate.
—I didn't allege deliberately.

—You said that Senator Hill misled the Senate. It is inappropriate for Senator Cook to make that allegation, except on a motion in respect of the statement. Senator Cook knows that, and I would just suggest to you that he withdraw the comment.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Childs)—I do not uphold the point of order, because I think Senator Cook is attempting to point out why he disagrees with the figures. He said `misled', and now he proceeds to make his case.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a clear fact that what Senator Hill said was not true. He said that real wages had fallen under Labor. The truth is that during the period of our stewardship of this country real wages, full-time adult average weekly earnings, have increased by 7.2 per cent. While those opposite continue to run around saying they have fallen, they are propounding a fiction in the public, which goes to this big lie scare mentality of undermining the success of the Australian economy that we have come to know from the opposition.

PARA.TAB: Let me go to another statistic about real household disposable income, because wages are one measure of how well people are doing. The level of tax they pay, what they take out of those wages, is another. The provision of a social wage, the provision of services delivered by a government to ordinary citizens, also goes to what their real quality of life and real standard of living are.

Household disposable income is a measure which shows at a household level how much people have in their pockets after they have met their tax bill. Real household disposable income under this government has increased by 41.8 per cent, and real household disposable income divided by per person in the household has gone up by 20.9 per cent. The approximate increase in real annual household disposable income per capita from June 1983 to June 1995, expressed in the current June 1995 dollars, is $3,500.

I go on to one other statistic, which is interest rates. The opposition, which has come in here and accused the government of having high interest rates, ought to look at its own record. Interest rates in Australia reflect what the expectations will be of inflation. The level of inflation in this country has come down dramatically. The inflation stick has been broken by us; therefore, interest rates have fallen under us.

Remember this: when John Howard was the Treasurer of this country, we were in recession, and in recession you expect interest rates to fall. Interest rates in the recession under John Howard were higher. Housing loans were at 12.5 per cent; building society rates, when Howard left office, were at 13.9 per cent. That is their record on interest rates. At the present time interest rates are at 10.5 per cent for the categories of home loans, and now you can shop around in a much freed-up market and get better deals than that. So let us not have this cant that interest rates are high. By the standards of the coalition, interest rates in this country are much lower, and people do respect that.

Can I just conclude by talking for a few minutes about industrial relations, because there is very little we know about the opposition's economic policies. Under their headland speeches, all they said was that they would create a productivity commission—made up of the Bureau of Industry Economics, EPAC and the Industry Commission—and that that productivity commission would recommend economic policy. All we know is that they are going to shift the deckchairs around, create a new body and rely on the public servants that inhabit that new body to tell the country what their economic policies should be. Is this responsible government? Hardly.

Under that headland speech as well, we do know something. The thing that we know is that Mr Howard is determined to press ahead with his industrial relations changes—his industrial relations changes that were rejected overwhelmingly in the last election. But they are foxing clever this time. They know that the battlers—the blue-collar vote that they so carefully try to cultivate—reject absolutely and fundamentally the industrial relations changes put forward by the coalition last time. So what have they done? They have changed the words. The first thing that they have done is said that Labor will run a scare campaign on this. We have no intention of running a scare campaign; we are going to run a truth campaign and expose the vacuous nature of your changes.

Compare this. In 1981, when the coalition was in government, the average number of working days lost per 1,000 employees because of your industrial relations policies was 797. In 1994 the figure was 76 working days lost per 1,000 employees. Which government is capable of inducing industrial harmony? It is us, not you lot. The only thing that is fracturing that record is the behaviour of state Liberal governments. Take the example of Western Australia. Tomorrow there will be a state strike in Western Australia directly in protest about the industrial relations so-called reforms that are being enacted in that state. There is one thing that people in the workplace want to hear about this opposition, and that is why they want to pick out the no-disadvantage test in industrial relations law. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Hill's motion today highlights three areas of significant failure in the government's economic and social policies. So far we have had the usual `our record is better' or `worse than yours' debate, as seen in here regularly. In terms of the motion on youth unemployment, while the absolute rate is falling it is not falling as quickly as adult unemployment. Young Australians are now 3 1/2 times more likely to be unemployed than adult Australians. Yet two years ago they were `only' 2.9 times as likely to be unemployed.

PARA.TAB: The government's key employment programs, including a jobs compact between the unemployed, government and business, have largely failed to meet their targets. Jobstart, for example, a subsidy program, has not been taken up by business. In the first year of its operation it has failed to reach its target by 40 per cent. That is 92,000 places. I would say in making that criticism, though, that businesses like Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation so far have shown very little interest in availing themselves of these opportunities.

The response from government has been to trundle more and more of the unemployed into short-term, mostly unaccredited training schemes. We are close to having the best trained dole queue in the world. Too few of the training opportunities are going to go anywhere. For example, accredited training places per youth are 60 per cent behind target. Places in the Australian traineeship system are also 20 per cent behind target.

The second issue Senator Hill's motion deals with is housing affordability. Again, that is the function of three key things: interest rates, house prices and the ability to save. I have said many times here that our interest rates are amongst the highest in the world. They are kept high, in our view, because of two key policy failures of government—firstly, our excessively high current account spurred on by a debt-ridden public sector and a trade and industry policy which keeps exporting Australian jobs overseas and, secondly, our uncompetitive banking sector, which the government allows to charge margins on bank loans, particularly to housing and small business customers, margins on average twice as large as banks in other industrialised countries. Yet despite warnings from the Reserve Bank last year that margins on bank loans were too high, nothing has been done.

On the third matter of the motion, the gap between the rich and the poor, every study on income distribution shows that the gap between rich and poor in this country has widened between 1980 and 1995. The OECD now says we have the third worst income distribution of any member country. At the heart of this are the combined policies of the government and the opposition over the last decade, pushing each other to lower government taxes on high income earners to provide tax breaks and government subsidies and support to entrepreneurs while at the same time increasing user-pays charges and decreasing services and support to low and middle income earners. Labor can at least point to a reasonably good record of a well targeted safety net, of social security payment increases, of Medicare and of—rapidly diminishing—free education.

Prior to the dumping of Fightback, the coalition spent much of the last decade trying to water these things down. Similarly, Labor has spent much of the last three years also chipping away at things like free education and at the rules on targeting. It was interesting to see Mr Howard give commitments to ACOSS last week that the opposition will not wind back the safety net. That is a welcome commitment.

But if we really want to talk about the disadvantage faced by mainstream Australian families because of economic and social policy failure, we should all cast our minds a few months back to the Competition Reform Policy Bill, passed in here on the combined vote of the government and opposition. This bill converts public services in the public interest into economic goods to be contracted out, to be sold, to be bartered, whatever. Competition might very well be a good thing when you are selling apples and oranges but it is not necessarily a good thing when it comes to delivering health services or aged care services or providing decent housing for low income families.

The fact is that in some of these areas we still accept a social responsibility to educate or clothe or house people. That social responsibility overrides the dictates of the market, which has been the feature of the government's and opposition's economic and social policy of the last decade. What you end up with often is access to services limited to the well-off or the very poor. The group which misses out are working families—precisely these battlers whom everyone is professing to be so concerned about. In ten years get ready to point the finger back to what we did in here a few months ago, to another economic and social policy failure which will disadvantage mainstream Australian families. How do we know this? Because it has happened already in Great Britain in terms of higher prices for basic services, et cetera.

Let us get away from, `your record is worse than ours.' The federal government does stand condemned for some of its performance on youth unemployment. Most Australians, like myself, are waiting for the opposition's answer to these problems. But what we need to do is not have more of the same but rethink the last decade of economic and social policy failure in this country. They have been totally market based and that has been an inadequate solution. So I hope that I am wrong in saying in 10 years' time people will point back to the last few months and look to where mainstream Australian families have been again disadvantaged. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I take up the point that Senator Kernot has made. I refer her back to eight short years ago when then Prime Minister Hawke coined that now infamous quote, some say epitaph: `By 1990 no Australian child will live in poverty.' Eight short years after that ill-fated quote and some 13 years under the Labor government it seems that Australia is no closer to solving the problem of inequality and poverty. In fact, some studies show that during the past decade poverty and inequality have risen dramatically. Poverty, Adam Smith wrote, is `not having enough to live without shame in your own community.' In communities around this country it seems that more and more Australians are forced to live in shame.

PARA.TAB: Within the course of 30 years Australia has gone from being the most egalitarian nation in the world to one of the most unequal. According to one recent world competitiveness report, out of 18 similar industrialised nations, Australia ranked as the least equitable nation as far as wealth distribution was concerned. Senator Kernot referred to a report where in the OECD nations we are the third worst in the world. You cannot ignore those facts.

In addition, Australia has the dubious honour of having one of the highest levels of affluence coupled with one of the highest levels of poverty in the industrialised world. Ironically, Australians have always considered themselves an egalitarian society, a homogeneous middle class society, free from the vast disparities of wealth evident in other nations. Yet this perception of middle class society is now nothing more than a myth, a vestige of the 1950s and 1960s ethos when the middle class was a growing sector in our society. In the 1990s we are a much more polarised society. Australia's middle class is shrinking, while both ends of the economic spectrum are growing. In Australia today the wealthiest one per cent control around 25 per cent of the nation's wealth while the top 10 per cent control about 60 per cent. This contrasts dramatically with the poorest 40 per cent in this country—

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. I draw your attention to a standing order that urges senators not to read their speeches. I particularly do it in this case because while I know they are copious notes, Senator Herron, you are always very good when you do not refer to notes. So I urge you to give us the benefit of your best thoughts on this matter.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Childs)—I do believe that Senator Herron is speaking from copious notes. Senator Herron, continue.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to give accurate statistics. In referring to the statistics I will give my usual free-fall speech at the appropriate moment. I am sure that Senator Crowley would like accurate statistics, and that is what I am referring to. I was making the point that this contrasts dramatically with the poorest 40 per cent of this country, who only a decade ago controlled 22 per cent of the nation's wealth, whereas today they control little more than nine per cent.

PARA.TAB: We have a society where the poor are getting poorer and the rich are getting richer. That is a fact. In contrast with these growing sectors in society, Australia's middle class is now an endangered species. While the problems of the long-term unemployed and the elderly constantly surround us, attention must now be directed at a new class of Australians, a class equally powerless, and some say even more disenfranchised from the power base than the two I have just mentioned. We are now witnessing the emergence of the working poor.

The greatest cause of poverty in Australia today is unemployment. Unemployment, with its economic and social costs, has a dramatic effect on the rising gap between rich and poor. Reducing unemployment is the first step in reducing poverty and the disparities of wealth, but under the Keating government we have seen unemployment stuck over eight per cent; and the forecast is that it will rise in the new year. What a legacy to have! Some two million Australians are either unemployed or want more paid work.

Senator Cook disparaged my leader's statements. But only the other day we heard Rupert Murdoch saying that the economy is a disgrace and that an even greater disgrace was youth unemployment. That cannot be denied, either. When measuring the rise in poverty levels in Australia, our ageing society cannot be ignored. With the number of retired people growing by over 10 per cent each year, the level of income inequality in Australia is directly linked to the growing number of pensioners, with more and more people leaving the work force and retiring on the old age pension. The effects of this on the social welfare system and the work force are evident.

It is ironic that we have today in parliament a group meeting which represents the most rapidly growing segment in our society. I refer to the National Seniors—and I congratulate them on their success. I should declare an interest as I am a member of the National Seniors; and proudly so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very good.

—You have to be over 50, Senator West, and I would not be so ungallant as to suggest you might fit that category. But I refer you to that group as a great one to join. In the 13 years of Labor rule, the real losers in the area of wealth distribution are the so-called true believers. These are the young Australians in full-time, low-skilled jobs; taking home low-paying wages, with some wages just above the poverty line. These are the people who are trying to build a home, raise a family and keep some hope—but this hope is fading fast. I defy senators to show me a couple on a single income who can afford to buy a house. It is fatuous to suggest they can.

PARA.TAB: These hard-working young Australians now constitute almost 10 per cent of the bottom income earners in this country. These are the forgotten poor, the working poor, the single-income families who are battling to stay off the social security system and to maintain the self-esteem that having a job provides. Just because they have a job does not restrict them from being in the poverty trap. For the low wage earner, the benefits provided by the state for the elderly and the unemployed are scarce. Studies show that the working poor are the most affected by the inequalities in wealth distribution.

If we are effectively to reduce poverty in this country we must not limit ourselves to those without work. Our efforts must include bolstering the vulnerable at the lower end of the income scale. There are 8,520,284 citizens receiving benefits from government—that is, from taxpayers—in this country. It seems ironic that at a time when we are striving for greater autonomy and independence as a nation, we are quickly chaining ourselves to foreign lenders, as their servants.

The constant rhetoric about the rise in GDP gives little comfort to the ailing in our society. By allowing funds for the poor, preventative health plans have the greatest chance of raising the aggregate level of health in Australia. Inequity, as we have seen, is not just about income and money; it is about dignity and security. The historical paradox is that change will come about only by the election of a Howard coalition government, a government which has a fundamental belief in a just and equitable society.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was very interested in the comments made by Senator Herron. I would have been even more interested if they had contained the policies that are going to be pursued by the coalition if they ever get into government. It is really quite curious that this MPI criticises the family policies of this government and of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). This government is more committed to the needs of families than probably any other government in Australia's history. The government and I believe that the family is an integral part of society and that families, particularly those nurturing children, deserve support.

PARA.TAB: This year the government spent $12 billion on assistance to families. If that is not commitment I would really like to know what is and what the commitment is of those opposite in terms of expenditure on families. This is a real commitment to families. Under this Labor government, 80 per cent of families in Australia—there are about four million families in Australia—receive some assistance from the government. I would like to briefly outline the initiatives of this government.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is an indictment—

—Would you withdraw that assistance? I would like to briefly outline the initiatives this government has taken to enhance the position of families and to further contrast the position of families prior to the election of this Labor government in 1983. The truth is that the opposition, when last in government, had an opportunity to do something for families in Australia—but chose not to. If they are in government, again they will choose to do nothing for families.

PARA.TAB: The major achievement of this government in terms of families is Medicare, a universal health cover that ensures that each family has their health needs met in times of crisis and when they are ill. This is where the security of families starts. This government has concentrated on the preservation of health and the prevention of disease by increasing expenditure on immunisation, breast cancer detection and cervical cancer detection.

In the area of family income support, the additional family payment has been added to what was known as child endowment. That had dwindled away to virtually nothing before this government was in office. The payment was increased and paid directly to the carers in families, usually women, to assist in the care of their children. It is aimed at the less well off in our community who may not otherwise be able to properly provide for their children.

From 1983 to 1995 family assistance has increased in real terms by 149 per cent, a real achievement for families. In terms of the home child-care allowance, this was a payment introduced by this government. It was a direct payment to carers at home, again usually mothers, to allow them to properly care for their children. That initiative had not been considered previously. Just this year the maternity allowance came in, a payment of six weeks maternity allowance on a means tested basis for those who earn under $61,000. It is a payment of $816 at the most difficult time for many families, a time when families are under stress, emotionally and financially. The government saw fit to take the initiative of providing those families with that additional assistance.

Also, the government has assisted working families in the area of child care. This government has the objective of achieving 300,000 places by 1996-97. To date, over 240,000 have been created. This is a real commitment to families. We have also made child care affordable by the subsidy provided by the child-care allowance and by the direct child-care rebate.

The National Centre for Social and Economic Growth found that these payments boosted the take home pay of mothers at work by up to 60 per cent, certainly something that is going to help families. Altogether, these payments made by the Commonwealth together with the housing and education programs put forward by this government amount to $1,670 of social wage per person. In fact, over the period of this government—from 1983 to 1995—as Senator Cook said, the social wage has increased by a staggering 73.1 per cent. The fact is that real average household income over the period has increased by 20 per cent. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —The motion before the Senate this evening really encapsulates what is good government and all that is under the jurisdiction of governments to administer in our society, including youth unemployment, unemployment generally, housing affordability and the gap between the rich and the poor. So it is a worthy motion to discuss today. The Minister for Industry, Science and Technology, (Senator Cook), the leader of the government speakers this afternoon, trotted out his usual `them and us' speech. He twisted and turned all the figures into favourable comparisons of his government with the Fraser government 13 years ago.

PARA.TAB: While I do not accept those figures, Senator Cook should realise that that has really now become very hollow rhetoric. Australians have stopped listening. No matter how Senator Cook invites us to look at it, the matter is far simpler than the figures trotted out by him. It could not have been put better than by international media baron Rupert Murdoch last week, when he expressed the very feelings that mainstream Australians have. They are not very complicated; they are really quite simple. Rupert Murdoch referred to this country's youth unemployment as disgraceful. That is the feeling in society, and the Morgan Gallup poll and all trending polls reflect it. It is a very simple feeling.

Both sides can spend hours in this chamber rattling out figures for averages, absolutes, reals and nominals, but out in mainstream Australia, as this motion highlights, the feeling is that economic circumstances have not improved and that the economy is a disgrace, as expressed by Rupert Murdoch. You only have to look at the editorials, articles and letters to the editor that followed Rupert Murdoch's comments to see how much people agree with them.

It is disgraceful that this country has 27 per cent youth unemployment, particularly when only two weeks ago this nation was crowned the richest nation in the world by the OECD. It is true; we are the richest nation in the world. We have vast mineral resources, expansive agricultural lands, a very moderate climate to do our work in and a very stable political system compared with other nations. Given that backdrop, it is even more disgraceful when you consider that, when all those natural talents are put together, we have great social uncertainty and anxiety in the community after 13 years of this government. We have a growing gap between the rich and the poor.

Australians have always prided themselves on never having had the extremes between poverty and wealth that are so prevalent in America or the Asian nations. While we do not yet have extremes like those in America and Asia, we are certainly dangerously propelling ourselves in that direction. For the first time, we are actually talking about an underclass in this country and a widening gap between the rich and the poor.

We have now reached a stage where we have a second generation of unemployed persons. There are families where the parents and children are without jobs. A recent Australian Bureau of Statistics report has found that more than 700,000 children under the age of 15 are in families where no-one has a job. Naturally, they are caught in the poverty trap. Demand on charity food banks increased last Christmas—1994; we are approaching the 1995 Christmas—to historical levels. Saint Vincent de Paul declared that, in its 140 year history, it had never had such a demand upon its services.

As a measure of that growing trend, in 1991, the Smith Family provided aid for 25,000 Victorians. In 1992, it increased to 42,000. In 1993, it jumped to 79,000. In 1994, it jumped to 110,000. This Christmas, it is expected to jump again. Why should it not, because that is the trend. All those charities are now at near breaking point.

Given the very stacked nature of our Reserve Bank, it takes a lot for a Reserve Bank governor or board member to start talking about urban ghettos. You would be surprised if you were told that a Reserve Bank board member started talking about the growing gap between the rich and the poor in this country and the possibility of urban ghettos in Australia. That is exactly what has happened.

The prominent and distinguished professor, Bob Gregory, a member of the Reserve Bank board but also a distinguished labour market economist, released some alarming research in around April on the growing gap between the rich and the poor. That study found that, in 1976, the average income of people in the bottom five per cent of neighbourhoods was 60 per cent of that of the top five per cent of neighbourhoods. More than 15 years later, those at the bottom earn less than 40 per cent of those on the top income. It has dropped 20 per cent. That is a backward motion.

The single most important cause for this developing economic and social phenomenon is sustained high unemployment, as my colleagues have pointed out, particularly for youth. In the past decade, we have seen unemployment levels range between 700,000, which is unacceptable, to a record one million. Senator Cook failed to mention that figure in the numerous statistics that he belted out. We had a record one million unemployed individuals some years ago.

TALK.START.PARA: —There have been very interesting dissertations from Senator McGauran, Senator Herron and the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, Senator Hill. The Leader of the Australian Democrats, Senator Kernot, in her contribution, alleged that we should not sit here and each say that our policy is better than the policy of others and get into arguments.

PARA.TAB: I have made a score card while this debate has been on. Whilst we on the government side have been talking about what our policies have been able to deliver, the opposition has talked about zero policies, or how it would do things better. We do not like high unemployment. We have a number of programs in place to address it. We have done a lot to address high inflation and high interest rates. When we came into power in 1983, we had the triple whammy of double digit inflation, double digit unemployment and double digit interest rates. Those opposite forget about that. We worked to bring these three things down to a much more acceptable level. We are still working on it.

The matter of public importance talks about the alleged growing gap between the rich and the poor. It fails to recognise that the lowest income groups in Australia have gained very substantially in recent years. Real average household incomes have increased by 20 per cent since 1983. That is not ignoring the growing gap. As an aside, we also noted with interest that when the Leader of the Opposition moved the motion he was a bit slow in getting some of his people behind him to support him. But that is their problem, not mine.

We were invited by Senator Hill to look at Victoria. I thought that was a good idea. There is a Liberal government there. He mentioned health. I heard a report the other day of a mother whose child is in hospital having chemotherapy. The mother is given prescriptions by a public hospital in Victoria and has to go to an outside chemist and buy the prescriptions for the child's chemotherapy. That is the Victorian health system.

We have had people in this debate talking about children's services. It is a very valuable and important issue. I again make the point that I keep making whenever people want to talk about families in Victoria: they have restricted the number of visits families with young babies and children can make to the early childhood centres to 10. That is totally insufficient.

We see also the opposition at the federal level running around and talking about foreign debt, overlooking the fact that only four per cent of foreign debt is owed by the federal government. Most of it is private.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who pays the interest on it?

—Therefore, the private sector pays the interest on their own borrowings, and these are the people who are actually upgrading and spending money to have industry in this country. From the way the opposition is talking, you would think that industry was bad for this country.

PARA.TAB: We had the spectacle last week of the New South Wales government bringing down its budget. We had the New South Wales shadow Treasurer on the 7.30 Report being critical of the New South Wales government. He was saying that the New South Wales government was reducing that state's debt too quickly.

Just where do they stand? They do not know. They have come in here and all they have said is a lot of hot air. They have failed to look at the real facts. They have failed to look at the fact that economic growth prior to 1983 was 2.6 per cent. Under us, it has been 3.7 per cent. They have failed to look at the fact that under Mr Howard as Treasurer the average inflation rate was 9.8 per cent. Under us, the average is 5.3 per cent and since June 1991 it has been 2.3 per cent. They have failed to look at the number of jobs created per year. Under Mr Howard it was 51,300; under Labor it has been 163,600 per year.

These are the sorts of comparisons that it is very important for people to be aware of; these are the sorts of comparisons that indicate that this is a government that does care about people and families and is prepared to do something to assist them. The average annual growth in employment under Mr Howard was 0.8 per cent; under Labor, it is 2.3 per cent. Obviously, we have here a government that does care about families and about people. Unlike the opposition, we have policies. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —The disillusion and disadvantage faced by mainstream Australians is a result of failed economic and social policies. I hope that no-one is under the illusion that the coalition policies are an improvement. It has been axiomatic that there is really very little difference between ALP new right policies and coalition new right policies.

PARA.TAB: Where there is a difference, for example on the subject of labour market reforms, it seems that the coalition policies would probably make things worse for mainstream Australians who provide the labour you want to make cheaper. The coalition cannot make things very much more worse; it just makes them more obvious.

The basic ideology of both major parties is that taxes should be low. Both parties believe the crucial economic factor is to assure and maintain high profitability for big companies. As a social agenda, this is outrageous. Increasing the amount of profit that goes to the rich cannot remedy any problem mentioned in this matter of public importance. It would be one thing if profit was based on technical efficiency, but it is not. The focus is on capital efficiency.

As a consequence, the push has been to greater labour productivity. This generally means that the mainstream Australian is asked to do more work for less money. It may mean that they are expected to do unpaid overtime or to work harder. It may mean that companies sack workers, leaving those remaining to do more while leaving some things, generally customer service, poorly done. It is often trying to break down extra payment for unsociable hours, which means more people will be working such hours. It means an end to any sense of job security.

In the days when the ALP presented a real alternative to the coalition, the issue of distribution of profits was central. The principle is that major industry is a social activity, and the profits should be distributed equitably. Failure to do this, allowing for the economic and social power of capital to direct the profits its way, accruing to the rich, is unjust and ultimately counterproductive.

It is time to reassert that principle, and if we are concerned with distribution of profit, if we are concerned with unemployment and underemployment, and if we are concerned about distributing the benefits of technical advance, we must give mainstream Australians a greater share of the profits their efforts generate. This means higher wages for ordinary people and less exorbitant salaries for executives. Part of this effort at equity should be a decrease in hours in the standard working week.

Another side of the agenda has been the erosion of the quality and number of public services. The big push to privatisation seems like it will give little benefit to mainstream Australians, will probably mean that some people will pay more and will probably mean it will be harder to get a decent level of service. The main virtue of privatisation seems to be that a lot of people can be sacked, and companies no longer need to be socially responsible in a number of directions. Water authorities will not need to consider conservation. Other areas, such as the privatisation of libraries, will probably mean that services become either more expensive or less available. We have already seen that in the health system. Yes, the disillusionment and disadvantage are issues. Unfortunately, the coalition presents no better alternative.

SPEECH.PARA: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT (FBT COST OF COMPLIANCE) BILL 1995

The Taxation Laws Amendment (FBT Cost of Compliance) Bill 1995 will amend the fringe benefits tax and income tax laws to give effect to the Government's fringe benefits tax cost of compliance statement of 24 February 1995. It will also make changes to the fringe benefits tax substantiation rules which were announced on 29 March 1995.

In line with this Government's desire to minimise taxpayers' costs in complying with the tax laws, the amendments in this bill will substantially reduce compliance costs for employers liable to fringe benefits tax. In addition, a number of benefits provided by employers will no longer be subject to fringe benefits tax.

Most of the measures in this bill will apply from 1 April 1995, the start of the current fringe benefits tax year. However, measures dealing with living away from home allowances will take effect from 1 July 1995.

The bill will exempt from fringe benefits tax a range of benefits that are primarily used for business purposes. These benefits include employment related protective clothing, briefcases, calculators and electronic diaries, tools of trade, employment related software and portable computers.
Mobile and car phones will also be exempt where their use is primarily for employment purposes.

In recognition of the safety and health issues involved, taxis provided by employers to employees for travel to and from home between the hours of 8pm and 6am will be exempt, as will taxi travel for sick employees to home or to another place of care.
The exemption of taxi travel is estimated to cost $45 million in 1995-96 and $30 million in each later year. The other exemptions have a small but unquantifiable cost to the revenue.

The bill will also reduce the number of declarations required by the fringe benefits tax law. Where a series of identical benefits is provided, an employee declaration is generally required each time a benefit is provided so that the private portion of the benefit can be determined. This requirement for multiple declarations will be replaced by a single employee declaration which can be used for up to five years.
Further, a single employer declaration will also be available in certain situations. This declaration can also be used for up to five years.
The bill will reduce the compliance costs associated with the calculation of FBT on meal entertainment by providing two further options for determining the value of a benefit.

The simplest of these methods is to accept that 50 per cent of expenditure on meal entertainment in a year is subject to fringe benefits tax, with the balance being non-deductible to the employer. This method will also be available for use with the lease or hire costs of corporate boxes and other entertainment facilities.

The other method requires the employee to keep a twelve week register. This register is then applied over the whole year to determine the amount of meal entertainment which is subject to fringe benefits tax and the amount which is deductible for income tax purposes. The register will remain effective for up to five years.
Amendments in the bill will also reduce the compliance costs associated with the taxation of car parking benefits.

First, fringe benefits tax will no longer apply to car parking on employers' premises unless there is a commercial car parking station within a one kilometre radius that charges more than $5 a day at the beginning of the fringe benefits tax year. This will ensure that fringe benefits tax will only apply to car parking in areas where such benefits have significant values, such as in CBD areas.

Secondly, employers will be able to adopt a simplified method of valuing car parking benefits. This new method will enable an employer to determine the value of a benefit by reference to the average of the lowest commercial car park fees at the start and end of the FBT year.

Also, a further two optional methods for calculating the total taxable value of car parking fringe benefits will be available. One of these methods uses a statutory formula and the other allows an employer to keep a twelve week record of car park usage.
Comparable changes will be made to the income tax law relating to the deductibility of car parking expenditure incurred by self-employed taxpayers.
These amendments are estimated to cost $76 million in 1995-96 and $62 million in each later year.

The Government will also take the opportunity in this bill to make a technical correction to ensure that, as originally intended, car parking benefits provided by Commonwealth, State or Territory government educational institutions will be exempt from fringe benefits tax. This amendment, which will have no effect on revenue, will be retrospective to 1 April 1993.

The bill will also modify the fringe benefits tax treatment of living-away-from-home allowance benefits and other food and accommodation benefits provided to employees who are required to live away from their usual place of residence. These modifications will provide a greater degree of certainty in determining whether the benefits will be subject to concessional treatment.

These benefits will be subject to concessional treatment for up to four years for benefits provided to expatriates working in Australia or for benefits provided to Australian residents working overseas, for up to two years for employees working in remote areas (unlimited time for employees working on a `fly-in fly-out' basis) and for up to one year for benefits provided for all other employees.
The date of effect of these measures has been moved to 1 July 1995.

The bill will also amend the fringe benefits tax substantiation provisions to make them generally consistent with the revised income tax substantiation rules, including reducing the period for which records are required to be retained from seven to five years.

In order to maintain the revenue neutrality of this package of compliance cost reduction measures, the bill will increase the statutory fractions used in the statutory formula for car benefits by approximately 10 per cent. Even with these increases in the statutory fractions, the statutory formula will remain significantly concessional under a wide range of circumstances.
This amendment is estimated to raise $121 million in 1995-96 and $91 million in each later year.

The bill will also extend the rebate of fringe benefits tax presently allowed to certain non-profit, non-government bodies to certain medical research bodies which, while established under a Commonwealth, State or Territory law, are not conducted by or on behalf of a government.
The amendment will be effective from 1 April 1994.
Full details of the amendments in the bill are contained in the explanatory memorandum circulated to honourable senators.

I also foreshadow that the Government will be moving some minor amendments to the bill in the Senate. Copies of those amendments and a Supplementary explanatory memorandum will be circulated to senators.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
PUBLIC SERVICE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1995

This bill proposes a number of amendments to the Merit Protection (Australian Government Employees) Act 1984 and the Public Service Act 1922 to implement the decision announced in the 1995-96 Budget to amalgamate the Public Service Commission and the Merit Protection and Review Agency. Details of the amendments are set out in the explanatory memorandum which accompanies the bill.

While the integration of the MPRA and the Public Service Commission will generate only modest savings of approximately $200,000 in 1996-97 and subsequent years, the Government considers that significant benefits will result from the arrangements proposed in this bill. By drawing on the collective experience of both organisations and rationalising their corporate resources, the amalgamated body, which will be known as the Public Service and Merit Protection Commission, will be better placed to develop innovative personnel management and service delivery arrangements.

The integration of the MPRA and the Public Service Commission will provide the Public Service, and the people of Australia generally, with tangible benefits. The Public Service and Merit Protection Commission will bring together two vital streams of people management in the public sector and create an environment in which systemic issues which are brought to light in the grievance and appeals handling process can more effectively inform and improve the policy perspectives of the Public Service Commissioner. Similarly, integration with the Public Service Commissioner will provide staff of the Agency with a better appreciation of the policy issues relevant to their casework activities. By drawing together the Public Service Commission's work on best practice and the MPRA's experience in merit protection and grievance resolution, the new Commission's ability to contribute to the delivery of quality service to the Australian public will be greater than the sum of its individual parts.

Mr President, the Government remains committed to the principles on which the MPRA was established and which are articulated in its legislation—fairness, equity, sound personnel management practices, efficiency and good staff relations. The MPRA has an important role in preserving key values in Australian Government employment and, in particular, in preserving the merit system. In its first eleven years, the MPRA has developed an enviable reputation for probity and independence.

In developing this legislation, the Government has been careful to ensure that the Public Service Commissioner and the Director of the MPRA, who will in future be known as the Merit Protection Commissioner, will continue to exercise their statutory powers independently of each other. The powers of the MPRA in relation to the investigation of grievances and the resolution of disputes will be unaffected by these amendments, and it will be just as vigorous in protecting public servants' rights as it has always been. The Government's intention is that the two Commissioners should have a close and cooperative relationship, but that neither will be able to interfere in the other's statutory role.

One necessary consequence of the amalgamation of the staff of the Public Service Commission and the MPRA, however, is that the Merit Protection Commissioner will no longer have the powers of a Secretary in relation to the staff of the MPRA. These powers will rest with the Public Service Commissioner, but the Government expects the Public Service Commissioner to delegate his personnel management powers in relation to the staff of the Commission who are required for the purposes of the Merit Protection Act to the Merit Protection Commissioner. This will guarantee the continued independence of the MPRA from the Public Service Commission, and ensure that there will be no diminution in the rights of public servants to independent appeal and grievance mechanisms as a result of this bill.

Finally, Mr President, the bill makes a number of other minor changes to the act. Members of the Merit Protection Agency will continue to be appointed by the Governor-General in Council on Ministerial advice. However, the bill will require wider consultation on these appointments than is currently the case. In addition, the bill provides that only the Merit Protection Commissioner will be able to be appointed on a full time basis. This, in fact, has been the situation since the MPRA was established in 1984, and the amendment does no more than reflect the reality of the current practice.
I commend this bill to the Senate.
