SPEECH.PARA: SYDNEY AIRPORT CURFEW BILL 1995
The purpose of the bill is to strengthen the curfew at Sydney Airport.
Honourable senators will recognise the importance of balancing the interests of noise affected communities against the operational requirements of the airport.

The night hours are the most noise sensitive period. Communities affected by aircraft noise during the day deserve to be free of this disturbance during the night. The government is therefore committed to minimising, to the greatest extent possible, the activities at the airport during the night-time curfew period.
The government has already made significant improvements to the curfew regime over the past year.

Last December, the government introduced a monetary penalty of up to $25,000 for curfew breaches. This replaced the previous arrangements where curfew breaches were dealt with administratively rather than by the courts and without provision for monetary penalties.

Last April the government introduced stricter limitations on movements by larger freight jets. Approvals for the operation of Boeing 737 and Airbus A300 freight aircraft have either lapsed or been withdrawn. Moreover, operations by McDonnell Douglas DC9 aircraft are being phased out and must be eliminated by May 1996. Permitted jet movements will then be restricted to the quieter British Aerospace BAe146 aircraft.

A strict approach has also been adopted in considering requests for dispensations from the curfew at Sydney Airport. In the first six months of 1995, an average of 3 dispensations a month have been granted, compared with an average of approximately 25 curfew dispensations per month during 1994.

Regulations have been made to ensure that all night-time jet freight operations into Sydney Airport are banned after the opening of Sydney West Airport. The people of Western Sydney can be reassured that the government's comprehensive updating of the Environmental Impact Statement for the new airport will have as its central objective the prevention of noise nuisance arising from night-time operations. It is fundamentally important that we learn the lessons of Sydney Airport and ensure that future generations of Western suburbs residents are not exposed to excessive noise.

The private members' bill introduced by the Leader of the Opposition into the other House in the last sittings, by proposing only to replicate the current curfew regulations in an act, did nothing to ease the burden of the airport's operations at night on the residents of Sydney. After so strongly supporting the parallel runway development at Sydney Airport, the Opposition now seek to deceive voters into thinking they will do something about the curfew. In reality they would do nothing.

At the request of the Member for Lowe, the Howard private member's bill was referred to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure with a view to strengthening the current curfew arrangements. Residents affected by aircraft noise in Sydney are fortunate to have an elected representative such as Mary Easson who recognised the need to strengthen the curfew and at whose instigation the Committee was tasked to look at this issue. The measures in this bill are the direct result of her efforts on behalf of residents living around Sydney Airport

The government is grateful to Peter Morris and his committee for carrying out this Inquiry and reporting in such a tight time-frame. The proposals put forward by the committee comprise a significant package and have been of considerable assistance in the preparation of the bill now before the Senate.

This bill, in building on the current stricter curfew arrangements, goes much further to provide a range of new initiatives to strengthen and enhance the current controls. For this reason the government has decided to draft a new bill, rather than propose numerous amendments to the Opposition bill. The government's bill is aimed at minimising curfew aircraft operations at Sydney Airport.
On behalf of the government, I would now like to respond to the committee's proposals.

In their first two proposals the committee suggested steps to reduce the number of international passenger aircraft movements during the first and last hours of the curfew. The government accepts the absolute desirability of reducing the number of these movements.

Consistent with the committee's recommendations, the international entitlements in the bill reflect current usage patterns. This means an immediate reduction in the current international passenger jet entitlements between the hours of 5am and 6am from 42 movements per week, with no more than 8 on any day, to a maximum of 35 movements per week, with no more than 7 on any day. The bill also enables regulations to prescribe lower levels of entitlements. In line with the committee's proposal for a progressive phase-out, the Minister for Transport envisages reducing entitlements whenever practicable.
Additionally, the bill introduces a regime requiring each individual international passenger movement during the curfew shoulder periods to be fully justified.

International passenger movements during the shoulder periods will not be permitted once Sydney West Airport is capable of handling those movements. In the interim, international passenger movements will only be approved if they can be justified by reason of curfew constraints at overseas airports or lack of available capacity at Sydney Airport outside the curfew.

The bill establishes a process where operators of international passenger aircraft may apply to the Secretary of the Department of Transport for approval for specific flights. This will require the Department and the industry, for the first time, to assess carefully the feasibility of rescheduling these shoulder hour flights into non-curfew times.
This process is consistent with the committee's proposals.

Members of the public have complained about aircraft departing to the north of the Airport just on 11pm and therefore not clearing the suburbs until some time after the start of the curfew. In order to address this issue the bill contains a provision which requires all aircraft to depart over the Bay after 10.45pm. If wind conditions preclude these take-offs the aircraft will not be permitted to depart.

The current arrangements allow an aircraft that has received a clearance to push back from a gate before 11pm to depart during the curfew provided it takes-off over Botany Bay. Certain operators have taken advantage of this provision and have been seeking, and receiving, push back clearances well before they are actually ready to depart. This has allowed some aircraft to depart from the Airport well after 11pm without breaching the Regulations. In line with the committee's proposal this push back provision has been abolished. The bill before the Senate contains a provision based on taxi clearance, which means that aircraft will have to be actually available for take-off before 11pm .

As I stated earlier curfew movements by the larger jet freight aircraft have been, or are being, phased out. In order to ensure that the gains from this initiative are not circumvented by the use of larger and relatively noisy propeller-driven aircraft, the bill contains a provision which prohibits the use of propeller-driven aircraft which have a maximum take-off weight greater than 34,000kg. This seeks to address the concerns expressed by the committee.
There has been considerable public disquiet about the issuing of curfew dispensations and the committee made a number of proposals in this area.

In future, guidelines will be used in assessing applications for curfew dispensations. The preparation of these guidelines will be subject to a public consultation process. It is envisaged that, subject to this process, the guidelines will restrict any such operations to fly only over Botany Bay. However, there will be provision for dispensations to be granted for operations on other runways in the event of a force majeure situation arising, for example, civil emergencies.
When a dispensation is granted, the bill requires the minister to table a statement outlining the reasons for the dispensation in each House of the Parliament within 5 sitting days.

The Morris committee suggested that the minister be given authority to increase the number of flights during the curfew for one-off events such as the 2000 Olympics. The government intends to ensure that Sydney Airport and Sydney West Airport, which will then be open, are capable of handling the level of air traffic during the Olympic period without the need to relax the curfew at Sydney Airport. This proposal is therefore not accepted by the government.

Under the present curfew regulations the maximum fine for a breach of the curfew was $25,000 for a corporation. This is consistent with the Commonwealth criminal law policy that penalties in regulations are intended for minor offences only. By placing the curfew controls in this act, the penalties can be increased to be consistent with those imposed for similar offences under other legislation. The government therefore supports the committee's proposal that the bill provide for penalties of up to $20,000 for individuals and $100,000 for corporations.

The government is committed to improving the processes for community consultation on curfew issues. This is already demonstrated through the establishment of the Sydney Airport Community Consultative committee chaired by the Hon Joe Riordan.

The Morris committee has proposed that this be further pursued through a general purpose standing committee of the House of Representatives. The bill incorporates the consultation procedures currently before the Parliament in the Legislative Instruments bill. They will allow public scrutiny of any proposals to amend this bill once enacted. They will also apply to development of instruments under this legislation. Adoption of these consultation procedures will not of course preclude any curfew issues being dealt with by a Parliamentary committee when considered necessary.

The issue of residents being woken up early on weekend mornings by a succession of landings from the north starting at 6am has been a particular problem. The committee proposed that the feasibility of restricting operations over Botany Bay between the hours of 10pm and 11pm and 6am and 7am at weekends be examined. The bill adopts this proposal to give much needed relief in this area, whenever safe operations can be conducted over Botany Bay.

On certain occasions aircraft approach the Airport from the south at night, but `miss the approach' and have to abort their landings. Although this is an internationally accepted procedure and is essential to safe flying, it results in the aircraft flying over the suburbs to the north and creating significant noise disturbance. In order to explain to the community the reason for these events the committee proposed that operators place an explanatory advertisement in local newspapers within 7 days of such an event.

This proposal has not been taken up in full due to advice of the Civil Aviation Safety Authority which considers that a statutory requirement for airlines themselves to give a public account for carrying out a missed approach may have an adverse effect on flight safety.

However, consistent with the longstanding requirement for the reporting of the use of reverse thrust, the bill contains a requirement for an explanatory report to be provided to the Secretary of the Department when a missed approach occurs. This information will be made public through the Sydney Airport Community Consultative committee.

The committee noted that noise disturbance at night is not restricted to aircraft operating out of Sydney Airport and that a study should be undertaken of the impacts of propeller-driven aircraft carrying out night-time operations around Sydney. The government accepts this. The proposed study will be carried out immediately.

As a first step to offset the noise impacts of propeller-driven aircraft operating into and out of Sydney Airport at night, the Minister for Transport proposes to amend the Air Navigation (Aerodrome Flight Corridors) Regulations so that propeller-driven aircraft will be required to adhere to flight corridors over the Kurnell sandhills when landing or taking off during the curfew.
One final matter raised by the committee was that the noise complaint handling procedures at Sydney Airport be reviewed. The Minister for Transport is now taking steps to ensure that this is done.
With their ineffectual private member's bill having been gazumped by our curfew bill, the Opposition has pulled a new stunt in the form of an amendment to "re-open" the east-west runway.

Leaving aside the outrageous cynicism and cowardly deception displayed by the Opposition in attempting to back away from their strident advocacy for the third runway, nothing could be more detrimental to the interests of those in the flight paths.

All our technical advice has been in favour of parallel runway operations, just as it would be if the Opposition were in office. If they ignored such advice from all the relevant agencies and outside experts, they would be directly and singularly responsible for running the airport in a manner that was less safe and a long way below capacity.

In reality this notion of re-opening the east-west runway is the airlines proposal to use the eastern end of the runway for stub operations by propellers. Sure this would overcome some of the safety and capacity problems, but it would also free up the north-south axis for more jet operations. Indeed the movement rate to the north could be up to 80-85 jet aircraft per hour. An increase of at least 10 jets per hour to the north.

The airlines would be delighted because they could go on deferring any need to use Badgerys Creek and therefore to duplicate facilities. But the already suffering residents on the north-south flight path would face a huge increase in their noise burden, all thanks to the Opposition.

Perhaps this is the reason they supported the third runway in 1989. Back then they were absolutely derisory about the issue of aircraft noise. Just as they try to deceive people into believing they now care about the low paid, they now say they care about noise affected residents. Well the government won't let them get away with it. At every turn we will remind the electorate of everything the Opposition has previously said. At the same time we will continue our own drive to provide genuine protection for noise affected residents under the Sydney Airport flight paths.

The government considers that the new measures introduced by the bill will significantly enhance the current curfew arrangements and will therefore bring much needed relief to residents living around Sydney Airport.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
GOVERNOR-GENERAL AMENDMENT BILL 1995

The enactment of this bill would set the salary of the next Governor-General after he is sworn in on 16 February 1996. Because Section 3 of the Constitution fixes the salary of the Governor-General for the term of office, the salary fixed at the commencement of the Governor-General's appointment must be set at a level that will still be appropriate at the end of the term. The Income Tax Assessment Act provides that the official salary of the Governor-General shall be exempt from income tax.

The Governor-General Act 1974 provided for a salary of $30,000. It was amended in 1977 to increase the salary to $37,000, in 1982 to increase the salary to $70,000 and in 1988 to increase the salary to $95,000. It is now proposed that the Governor-General's salary be $58,000. The salary will remain unchanged through the period of the next Governor-General's appointment.

In proposing this salary for the next Governor-General, I would like Honourable Members to note that Sir William Deane has requested that the salary be set to take account of the non-contributory pension which he will receive under the Judges' Pension Act after retiring from the High Court. Payment of this pension will continue during his term of office as Governor-General. At the commencement of the term of office, the sum of Sir William's net pension and the proposed salary would be in the order of $130,000.

The principle that has governed the calculation of this amount is that used to determine the salaries of Governors-General in the past; that is, to keep the average salary over the notional period of the appointment somewhat ahead of the estimated average annual income, after tax, of the Chief Justice of Australia.

The proposed salary, combined with Sir William's pension as a retired Justice of the High Court, is commensurate with the office, it is economically responsible, and maintains the traditional relativity between the Chief Justice and the Governor-General.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
ANL SALE BILL 1995

The ANL Sale Bill makes the necessary legislative provision to facilitate the sale of the Commonwealth's shares in ANL Limited although agreement has been reached under which the finalisation of the sale to P&O Australia has been deferred until 31 October 1995. Finalisation of sale arrangements is subject to the satisfactory conclusion of negotiations on ANL's future industrial arrangements and the retention by the Commonwealth of a special share.
ANL is a shipping company wholly owned by the Commonwealth. It formerly operated as the Australian National Line and was converted to a public company, with effect from 1 July 1989.

The Government first announced its intention to sell a substantial part of ANL in the context of the 1991/92 Budget. A scoping study was undertaken which concluded, in 1992, that given its then trading circumstances, a sale of less than 100 per cent of the company was unlikely to be commercially feasible.

During 1994 a further consultancy was undertaken as the first stage of a due diligence process into ANL. The due diligence process is a thorough examination of the company which, among other things, is designed to give a firm understanding of its assets and liabilities. That report was completed in August 1994 and its recommendation was that due to ANL's poor financial position and bleak outlook a sale was unlikely to be possible at that time and that the Government's best option was likely to be a managed trade down of the company. This would have meant an effective liquidation of the company.

Rather than pursue this option, the Government decided to appoint a new Board, headed by Mr Neville Wran, to undertake further analysis, restructure the company and examine future options. The Government also announced its intention to provide guarantees in respect of ANL's debt and any future drawdowns under its Promissory Note facility so as to enable the restructuring to be carried out in a stable commercial environment.

The ANL Board carried out some considerable restructuring of the Line, including the sale of ANL's interest in Australian Stevedores, the winding up of joint ventures with Howard Smith in bulk shipping and with Union Shipping in the trans-Tasman trade, the pay out of a bank debt facility and the lease on the ship River Torrens and some rationalisation of overseas and corporate staff.

Having received and pursued a number of inquiries, the Board reported, earlier this year, that there was interest from a number of companies in the purchase of some or all of ANL, including proposals from two companies which may have involved the purchase of all of the Commonwealth's shares in ANL. In May 1995, the Government agreed to the Board progressing with potential bidders, expressions of interest in the purchase of the Commonwealth's shares in the Company. In the event one bid was received, being from P&O Australia, and this was not for the purchase of ANL with all of its existing liabilities.
Based on that bid, the Board and Commonwealth officials have been able to negotiate an agreement under which P&O would purchase the Commonwealth's shares in ANL, subject to a number of conditions.

The Government has had discussions with ANL unions, with the ACTU and with P&O on the sale option. Deferral of a decision to finalise the sale to P&O until 31 October 1995 will allow P&O and the unions, under the leadership of the Secretary of the ACTU, to conduct negotiations on ANL's future industrial arrangements. Subject to the satisfactory completion of those negotiations, the sale to P&O will be finalised. If the unions and P&O cannot reach a resolution acceptable to them and to the Government then the option of restructuring ANL to increase the potential for it to return to viability will be pursued.

In order for the option of a sale to P&O to be quickly carried out at the completion of the negotiations between unions and P&O, it will be necessary for the ANL Sale Bill to be passed by both Houses of Parliament by the end of October. P&O is keen to be in a position to take action to turn ANL's results around. Any further delay creates uncertainty, with the risk of consequent damage to ANL's market share in its various businesses.

The substantive provisions of the bill do not come into operation until the draft sale contract is signed. Should the contract not be signed by the end of 1995 the legislation provides for its automatic repeal on 1 January 1996.

The bill makes transitional and savings provisions in relation to ANL employee long service leave, maternity leave, compensation and rehabilitation and certain retirement benefits that have become standard in legislation providing for the disposal of major Commonwealth assets, as for example in the sales of Qantas, ASTA and CSL Limited.

There are three major features of this bill which have arisen out of the negotiation of the draft sale contract and the recent discussions between the Government, unions and P&O in relation to the sale.

The first feature relates to the provisions which flow from the fact that P&O is not willing to purchase all of ANL's businesses nor take on all of ANL's liabilities. The second feature is the provision of an appropriation to meet any contributions required by the Commonwealth under the draft sale contract. The third feature is the need to provide for the protection of the future industrial arrangements that are being negotiated with P&O.

To move the required businesses and liabilities out of ANL and convert ANL into a company with reduced liabilities, the bill provides for the transfer of certain of ANL's assets, rights, liabilities and obligations to a nominated company (or a subsidiary of that company) or to the Commonwealth direct. The nominated company, which is called "RetainCo" in the bill, must be wholly owned by the Commonwealth.
ANL, under P&O Australia's ownership, will continue to hold around $140 million of debt, in the form of ship and container leases and drawdowns under ANL's Promissory Note facility.

The assets, liabilities, rights and obligations to be transferred out of ANL will primarily be long term ship leases and associated transaction documents, as well as several dormant ANL subsidiary companies. If a sale of ANL's shares in the Coastal ExpressLine business on satisfactory terms is not concluded prior to a sale to P&O, a holding company structure will be utilised to protect the Commonwealth's interests in this business.

After the sale the Commonwealth will continue to hold liabilities in the form of obligations under the long term ship leases transferred from ANL to RetainCo. RetainCo's obligations under the ship leases are, however, to be substantially matched by reciprocal income streams under long term sub-leases of the ships to major companies (including ANL after the sale). These long term sub-leases are either in place or the subject of negotiations in train.

The liabilities of RetainCo, in total around $183 million, will progressively diminish over time as the leases are paid out and it is expected that RetainCo will be at least cash neutral to the Commonwealth over the long term; that is, there should be no net call on Commonwealth funds to meet RetainCo's obligations over its life.

The bill provides for a Commonwealth guarantee to be granted in respect of the obligations transferred to RetainCo. As the company will not be a commercially operating company in the ordinary sense, a guarantee will be required to give comfort to financiers that it will be able to meet its obligations.

There is the possibility that RetainCo or an ANL company transferred to the Commonwealth may require operating funds in its initial year and the bill appropriates any funds necessary to provide working capital for 1995/96 for RetainCo or for the holding company.

The bill also appropriates up to $15 million to meet any Commonwealth contribution required under the draft sale contract. There are three elements to this contribution. The first element is to cover the contingency that relevant financiers may exercise change of ownership rights which would impose additional costs on the Commonwealth. Those financiers have, however, already provided in principle consent to the change of ownership. Other elements of the $15 million include any expenses, such as legal costs, related to the transfer of businesses out of ANL to RetainCo or the Commonwealth direct, and a contingency to provide for the possibility that ANL's operating results up to the date of sale are significantly worse than forecast. Current expectations are that only a small percentage of the $15 million will be required.

In respect of the industrial arrangements to be negotiated in respect of ANL, the bill provides for the articles of association of ANL to contain special articles which will enshrine the outcome of those negotiations.

The special articles will not be able to be altered or removed without the consent of the Minister, and the Ministerial consent is to be an instrument required to be laid before Parliament and subject to disallowance. The consent will not be effective until the disallowance period has expired.
The bill provides for the Minister to have the power to seek injunctions in the Federal Court to enforce the observance of the special articles and to prevent their removal or alteration.

The bill also provides for alterations to ANL's tax position as a consequence of the sale. ANL's accounting period is to be aligned with P&O's and the holding of the special share by the Commonwealth is to be deemed not to prevent ANL being treated as a wholly owned subsidiary of P&O for tax purposes. ANL's accumulated tax losses, of about $70 million, for the period before the sale will be extinguished and will, therefore, not be available to P&O to offset against profits post-sale.

The Government believes that a sale is the preferred option and the bill will facilitate the realisation of a long term future for ANL. ANL is currently losing around $2 million per month in its operations. ANL has some cash reserves, which were obtained from the sale of some of its assets, but once these have been exhausted—a matter of months not years—it would require cash support from the taxpayer to continue to trade. This is not a sensible long term approach.

The alternative to a sale is, therefore, a further major restructuring aimed at eliminating the likely need for taxpayer funding, which would see ANL withdraw from a number of trades and reduce in size. There is a risk that the resulting small organisation will lack sufficient resources to withstand any future poor trading periods. As is currently the case, ANL would not be able to influence in any significant way the freight rates paid by Australian importers and exporters.

If the sale is completed, ANL will continue to carry Australia's container imports and exports as a separate entity within the P&O group. P&O has indicated its intention to maintain ships under the Australian flag, crewed by Australian crews under Australian award conditions. Commonwealth ownership is not essential for there to be a continued Australian flag presence in international trades. In order to enhance the prospects of ANL's longer term commercial viability, and in the best interests of Australian taxpayers and the public at large, a sale to P&O Australia is the Government's preferred course of action, subject to a satisfactory outcome to the current industrial negotiations. Passage of this legislation is required urgently to enable the sale to be completed as soon as this negotiation process has concluded.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
HUMAN SERVICES AND HEALTH LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1995

Mr President, this bill is part of a package of two bills which will replace the Human Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1). That original bill was passed by the House of Representatives on 31 May, but divided by the Senate into two bills on 9 June. A message was sent from the Senate seeking the House's concurrence in its action.

Since the original legislation was introduced a number of minor amendments have become necessary. Rather than pressing on with the original legislation the Government has decided to introduce these new bills to better integrate some related measures and incorporate other minor amendments to the portfolio's legislation. I shall mention these new matters as I outline for Senators' benefit the key provisions of the bills.

The bill makes amendments to the Child care Rebate Act 1993, the Health Insurance Act 1973, the Health Insurance Commission Act 1973, the National Health Act 1953, and the National Health and Medical Research Council Act 1992. The bill repeals the Handicapped Persons Assistance Act 1974 which has become redundant due to a sunset provision which prevented further payments being made after 30 June 1992.
The bill also makes minor technical amendments to a number of acts as set out in Schedule 2 of the bill.
The amendments to the Childcare Rebate Act 1993 will strengthen the original intention of the act and clarify and facilitate certain procedural aspects of the Childcare Cash Rebate scheme.
The first group of amendments provide hardship provisions to assist certain groups of persons who are currently precluded from receiving the rebate but who should be entitled to the rebate.
These groups are:
children over the age of thirteen years who have a disability or other specified special need which requires ongoing child care;
parents who should be considered to have work-related commitments, such as those who are eligible for, but not in receipt of, a Carer Pension; and
families in which one parent has a work-related commitment but the other parent is unable to work or look after their children due to extenuating circumstances such as a medical condition.
An amendment is sought to allow carers under the age of eighteen years who have specified formal child care qualifications to register under the scheme.

Further amendments are proposed to confirm in legislation that family registration is able to be backdated to the date at which the family was first eligible to register, and that the rebate can be paid when a child is absent from child care for specified reasons.

There are also some administrative amendments proposed to rectify a number of drafting anomalies which have arisen. These amendments also make consequential amendments to the act to bring it in line with changes to other Commonwealth legislation.
Other administrative amendments are proposed to:
allow the Health Insurance Commission to backdate carer registrations to the date at which they were first eligible to register;
cancel family or carer registrations and recover payments when an administrative error has been made;
suspend family or carer registrations if cancellation of the registration is being considered;
ensure that the rebate is not paid for child care expenses which have been made or will be reimbursed by another agent such as an employer;
clarify the eligibility or persons who are not Australian citizens by correcting the description of visa categories to bring the act into line with changes in the Migration Act;
broaden the nature of courses which overseas students can be undertaking in order to be eligible for the rebate;
allow the Managing Director of the Health Insurance Commission to delegate powers;
allow the Minister to have some discretion over receipting requirements; and
to remove technical defects in the original act.
The bill has been changed to include two new minor technical amendments to allow the Health Insurance Commission to:
vary a family's registration if it believes a member of the family who is not included in the registration, should be included; and
cancel a family's registration where incorrect information is provided in connection with an application to vary the registration.

The amendments proposed to the Health Insurance Act 1973 are designed to correct a number of minor drafting errors in the Health Legislation (Professional Services Review) Amendment Act 1994 which established the Professional Services Review Scheme. In addition, the amendments will allow the appointment, as a President of a Professional Services Review Tribunal, of a person who holds or has held judicial office in a State or Territory jurisdiction. One of the new measures in this bill is to the Health Insurance Commission Act 1973. The proposed amendment would expressly give the Health Insurance Commission the function of providing information technology services to the Commonwealth and to other bodies established by laws of the Commonwealth.

This means that the expertise which the Health Insurance Commission has now or will acquire in the future can be made available to perform services for Commonwealth Departments or other bodies established by this Parliament.

The possibility of utilising the Commission's spare capacity and expertise is consistent with the recommended approach of the Commonwealth and Commonwealth agencies rationalising their existing information technology functions. This was foreshadowed in"Clients First", the Report of the Minister for Finance's Information Technology Review Group which was published in March this year.
Other proposed amendments to the Health Insurance Commission Act 1973 are designed to correct a deficiency in the Health Legislation (Powers of Investigation) Amendment Act 1994.

That act, which gave the Health Insurance Commission the power to investigate fraud under Medicare and to deal directly with the Director of Public Prosecutions, does not allow the Health Insurance Commission to retain evidential material seized under the authority of a search warrant for more than 60 days unless proceedings for an offence to which that material may afford evidence is instituted within that period. This deficiency will be corrected on the basis of advice from the Director of Public Prosecutions that without the amendment the Commission's search warrant powers are ineffectual.

The bill also empowers the Health Insurance Commission to engage in hedging of investment transactions, provide consulting, management and related services and exercise its powers and perform its functions overseas.

The Commission has undertaken a number of consultancies primarily, but not exclusively,under the auspices of the World Bank. As these activities are expanding, and moving beyond the use of spare capacity in the Commission's operations, it is desirable to make explicit provision to cover this activity.

So far as the proposed hedging power is concerned, this is consistent with other Commonwealth legislation and has been addressed, on the advice of the Attorney-General's Department, to resolve any doubt about the Commission's ability to enter into hedging transactions.

Hedging is, of course, one of the tools necessary in a prudent and balanced investment program which includes some overseas investments. The Commission operates Medibank Private in competition with other private insurers and must have available to it the same opportunities to manage the funds vested in it by its members.

This bill also contains amendments to parts of the National Health Act 1953 which regulate the administration of nursing homes. The Government has decided that these amendments should not await the introduction of the new Aged Care Act. The amendments to the current legislation are essential to address two immediate issues that have been identified.

Firstly there are a number of technical amendments to the National Health Act 1953 (the Principal Act) consequential upon amendments to the Principal Act introduced by the National Health Amendment Act 1992 which resulted in the entitlement to General Care benefit being calculated by reference to the "notional scale of fees" determined retrospectively under the Principal Act in place of the scale of fees determined prospectively under section 40AA.

For example, the Principal Act requires amendment to ensure that nursing home proprietors have a right of review of authorisations of payments of advance of benefit prior to the determination of the notional scale of fees within three years of the relevant accounting period.

Secondly, there are a number of amendments that relate to nursing homes which have been granted "exempt bed status". The amendments contained in the bill will address public concern about exempt nursing homes which fail to meet required standards of care.

The granting of "exempt bed status" under section 39AB of the act enables a proprietor to charge additional fees to nursing home patients. One of the criteria for granting "exempt bed status" is that the nursing home provides a higher level of accommodation and services than are normally available. However, the current provisions of the act do not enable the revocation or suspension of "exempt bed status" for those nursing homes which have failed to satisfy the standards for nursing and personal care.

It is clearly incongruous to continue to allow a nursing home to charge additional amounts for a supposed increased level of accommodation and services, when the level of nursing and personal care fails to meet the basic standards.
The decision to suspend or revoke "exempt bed status" is to be subject to internal review,as well as review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

The proposed amendment to the National Health and Medical Research Council Act 1992 is to specify directly the Health Ministers to be consulted by the Minister before appointing the Chairperson of the Council, the Chairperson of the Australian Health Ethics Committee, a Principal Committee of the Council, and the member of the Australian Health Ethics Committee classified as a person with knowledge of the ethics of medical research. Currently the act provides that the Minister is to consult in relation to these appointments with the other members of the Australian Health Ministers Conference.

The composition of that membership can of course vary from time to time and currently includes the New Zealand Minister for Health. The proposed amendment would specify that it is the Health Minister of each State and Territory who is to be consulted in relation to the appointments.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
THERAPEUTIC GOODS AMENDMENT BILL 1995

This bill incorporates and reintroduces all the provisions of the Human Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1995 in regard to the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989, as considered by both Houses of Parliament last session, and differs from that bill in the addition of one further minor amendment to correct an unintended consequence of a clause in the original legislation.

As outlined in my second reading speech for the Human Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No.1) 1995, the amendments included in this bill will establish a new accelerated process for placing listable drugs supplied in Australia on the Australian Register of Therapeutic Goods (ARTG) to cut product approval time to a matter of weeks, without in any way affecting the quality, or safety of the medicinal products. The bill provides a much better definition of some poorly understood aspects of the National Regulatory Scheme for Therapeutic Goods, which have been identified in its first 4 years of operation.

A mechanism to address shortages, or lack of essential drugs required by the public in emergency situations has been included, along with amendments that update and consolidate in a new part of the act, the entry, search and warrant powers to enforce the legislation. Also included in the bill are changes to align the monetary penalties in the current legislation with the "penalty units" classification used in other Commonwealth regulatory legislation, as well as closing a gap in the current scheme, in regard to the removal of illegal therapeutic goods of unknown quality safety and efficacy from the market.

A definition for "food" has been inserted to clarify the interface between food and drugs. Problems have arisen from the present definition of "therapeutic goods" which excludes "food" but fails to define the term. What constitutes "food" in the bill will be linked to the presentation and promotion of a product in the market. The words "prescribed dose" and "frequency of administration" included in the definition are to be read in a pharmaceutical sense, and are not intended to encompass serving suggestions applied to or normally associated with food and beverages.

Other amendments in the bill include a provision to replace the Therapeutic Goods Administration Trust Account with the Therapeutic Goods Administration Reserve, consistent with changes to be made by the proposed Financial Management Accountability Bill 1995 and related bills that will replace the Audit Act 1901.

The appeal provisions in the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989 relating to the review of decisions to register therapeutic goods have also been tightened. This will ensure that technical and scientific data that should be lodged in connection with a general marketing application, will be evaluated before a review on merits is undertaken by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

Turning to the new provision in the bill, the legislation currently provides that where therapeutic goods are refused marketing approval within Australia they may still be included in the ARTG as listed goods for export only. The secretary is empowered to require confirmation that the relevant authority of the country to which the goods are to be exported is willing to accept the goods. The secretary's power is currently confined to goods that have been manufactured in Australia for export only, and does not extend to products imported into Australia solely for re export.

The bill proposes that this provision be amended to ensure that the secretary's ability to require confirmation from Australia's trading partners of their willingness to accept goods refused marketing approval in Australia, extends to all products, irrespective of whether they have been manufactured in Australia or elsewhere.
I commend the bill to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —On balance, the coalition does not oppose the principle of the negotiated bulk payments of quantum of double dipped benefits according to a formula agreed between government and compensation payers. It is important that there is no administration tax relating to these arrangements. We accept the government's contention that insurers and other compensation payers were prepared to wear this type of arrangement in return for the waiver of fees, charges and given notification arrangements. We can see the benefits of these arrangements for small amounts of Medicare or nursing home benefits in respect of a given claim, but we do not accept that this is the best option or that compensation payers accepted it with anything but the greatest reluctance. It is a complex structure and will be costly for the compensation payers to service.

PARA.TAB: The implication is that insurers and Workcover authorities will have to gear up to adjust to the data and administrative demands of the Health Insurance Commission, rather than the other way round. Indeed, this seems to be the way of this government. Rather than using that well-worn line, `I'm from the government, we're here to help you,' it is a case of this government telling compensation payers, `Complain as much as you like, but we are here to help you.'

I also place on record the coalition's general view that, if these arrangements do work and absorb most of the insurance related claims, as the government argues, the revenue that would have been generated from this so-called administrative fee would have dropped to almost nothing. This simply reinforces the absurdity of the administration charge proposals. We note the undertaking of the government to review these arrangements after a period of time. I can assure the Senate that the coalition, in the likely event of being in government after the next election, will be reviewing these arrangements after 12 months of operation. We reserve our right to amend these and other arrangements in this bill if they prove inefficient, unfair or overly expensive.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Greens (WA) are in no doubt as to the necessity for this legislation, particularly in so far as it has addressed the problem of double-dipping in health and community services programs by those who are eligible for payments of compensation under the abovementioned schemes. However, we are more concerned that the federal government has to date shown little interest in addressing the many problems which exist in the area of occupational health and safety and particularly those which affect working women.

PARA.TAB: Almost without exception, these important issues have been neglected by successive governments in Australia. I am seeking to present some of my comments in relation to this at the third reading stage because, unfortunately, I was not able to raise these matters during the second reading debate. However, I acknowledge that the Greens have been pleased to support the changes that have been passed in the committee stage and would just like to put on the public record some of these concerns which relate to cost shifting in workers compensation.

There are nine major workers compensation schemes in operation in Australia, one for workers in each state and territory and one specifically for federal government employees. Moreover, under the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988—formerly known as the CERC Act 1988, as amended—licences have been granted to two federal government corporations, Australia Post and Telecom, empowering them to manage their own compensation claims and to administer rehabilitation programs for their injured employees.

The recently released report of the federal government's Industry Commission on workers compensation suggests that there is invidious competition between these various schemes, which was based partly on who could shift the most workers compensation costs onto individuals or onto the taxpayer funded health or social security systems. This report makes nonsense of the claims by insurers and compensation payers that they do not cost shift to the Commonwealth and that they fully meet their obligations to fund the treatment of those with compensable injuries. By their very nature, compensation insurers are driven by the profit motive. It is unrealistic to expect them to always act in the best interests of injured workers.

It does not seem to matter whether the compensation insurer is a private commercial enterprise or a federal government agency or corporation, cost shifting is rampant. In Western Australia, an organisation known as the Injured Persons Action and Support Association, or IPASA, owes its very existence to the injustices suffered by many injured persons as a result of exercises in cost shifting perpetrated by compensation insurers.

IPASA has repeatedly drawn attention to Telecom's campaign of harassment and victimisation of those of its employees who developed RSI in the early to mid-1980s. Telecom, well known for its insensitivity in these matters, continues this cynical exercise in cost shifting to the community, as evidenced by its insistence that many of those women be regularly examined by a doctor flown in from Adelaide. In fact, that doctor was the very doctor who coined the term `kangaroo paw'. Telecom prospers mightily in the 1990s, but it does so over the bodies of many of its female workers who were injured in the 1980s.

IPASA also exposed the nefarious exploits of certain of Australia Post's compensation delegates in WA. These revelations resulted in the then state manager apologising in person to one of his employees who, as a result of the continued harassment directed against him and his psychiatrist by the compensation section, had been driven to the point of contemplating suicide. According to IPASA, there have been many other injured persons employed by Australia Post who have been unfairly deprived of their compensation entitlements and forced onto social security benefits by these zealous delegates.

In 1992 Comcare laid down fairly stringent claims management standards for licensees under the act. However, its own claims management practices have attracted criticism. Areas of complaint outlined in the IPASA newsletter of November-December 1994 included: the fairness and rationality of decision making on some claims, both new and long-established ones; continuation of the practice of doctor shopping; incorrect interpretation of medical reports; removal of rights to compensation and rehabilitation without adequate reason; and interference in the medical referral process. Clearly, if Comcare cannot get its own house in order, it is hardly in the best position to ensure maintenance of claims management standards by those to whom it has granted licences under the Commonwealth Employment (Miscellaneous Amendments) Act 1992.

The state compensation system in WA has recently been extensively overhauled by the Court government. The major changes to legislation were specifically designed to remove lawyers from the system and to thus curtail cost. A conciliation and review directorate was established to speedily resolve disputes between employers and injured workers. Although it had to cope with a huge backlog of cases left over from the previous system, the government claims that the directorate has been an outstanding success.

However, an upper house committee of review has recommended that major significant changes be made to the system of dispute resolution. This criticism is not unexpected when one realises that the directorate commenced its operations with `conciliators' who were untrained in conciliation, with review officers devoid of legal training and with ad hoc medical panels selected from a list of those doctors volunteering to serve on them—for a fee of $400 per hour.

Considering that disputes can be, and often are, created at the whim of the insurer, injured workers often find that the conciliation process is a complete waste of their time. In addition, when they do have to attend conciliation and review hearings without legal representation, injured workers find themselves opposed by experienced insurance personnel representing their employer. This is obviously a most inequitable situation. As the promised speedy resolution of compensation disputes has not eventuated in WA, there has probably been no alteration in the extent of cost shifting to the Commonwealth practised by compensation insurers.

In an article published last year in the Medical Journal of Australia, Emeritus Professor David Ferguson reviewed the past 80 years of occupational medicine in Australia. His conclusion is relevant to this debate:

SPEECH.PARA: Australia has always been backward in providing safe conditions for workers. Occupational physicians have had to battle indifference, if not active opposition . . . Unsafe conditions are still accepted when the means of their prevention have been known since the beginning of the century. Political expedience, not science, has determined outcomes . . . The great majority of workers are not covered by specialist work [health] advice. Disparate State policies, programs, priorities, standards and laws lead to unequal worker protection and double standards apply. A poor quality of working life often still exists.
That is from `Eighty years of occupational medicine in Australia' by D. A. Ferguson, Medical Journal of Australia 1994:161:40.

PARA.TAB: In Australia women who are injured at work fare less well than work injured men. This conclusion was reached by Worksafe Australia in its report of October 1994 entitled Occupational health and safety: the experience of women workers, Australia, 1991-92. In response to this report, the Assistant Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Gary Johns, said, `The findings suggest that a special focus on women's workplace safety is needed if their problems are to be addressed.'

When his government's record on this matter is scrutinised, the assistant minister's remarks would hardly inspire much confidence amongst the working women of Australia. When RSI became so prevalent over 10 years ago, the health and safety of women in the workplace was prominently placed on the political agenda. However, it was quietly taken off the agenda by this federal government when economic expediency became the order of the day.

In 1986 Worksafe Australia's working party on repetition strain injury expressed concern both at the high degree of emotional and anecdotal debate on RSI and at the attitudinal barriers of racial origin and gender which could prevent sufferers from receiving appropriate and early attention. The report was severely criticised on the grounds that it failed to properly address these issues and that its authors appeared oblivious to the medico-legal conflicts which were proving so distressing to RSI sufferers. Such conflicts often resulted in great economic hardship for sufferers as well as interruption or curtailment of their working careers.

For many with RSI the not infrequent consequences of having this diagnosis applied to them were harassment and victimisation, family relationship problems, social isolation, loss of their former self-image and depressive illness. Other complaints by women with RSI included denial of access to correct medical management, to rehabilitation and to psychological support. The federal government and Worksafe Australia prefer to downplay and then to ignore these major problems affecting working women, perhaps hoping that they will just go away. Now, like the proverbial scapegoat, they have returned.

In his foreword to the 1994 report, the Chief Executive of Worksafe Australia, Dr Edward Emmett, admitted, `The causes and solutions for many occupational health and safety problems women experience have not received as much research or attention as those commonly found in many male dominated occupations.' The Greens (WA) see this admission as being one of guilt as well as a national disgrace. We look to the federal government for a positive commitment to rectify this matter. Buck-passing or, as it is known, cost shifting is only a symptom of a more widespread illness which exists within our society.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1995. This is an omnibus tax bill which contains 17 different measures. The bill is not opposed by the opposition; indeed, the coalition is strongly supportive of many of the changes contained in the legislation.

PARA.TAB: A popular cliche claims that all good things come to those who wait. In this instance we have had to wait a long, long time, so in this case there must be a whole lot of good in this bill. So long have we waited that this bill has had to change its name to get debated in this chamber. I must inform you that the bill was once known as the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1994—a change of name, but still another tax bill.

As I have noted already, the bill contains no less than 17 different measures. Those measures could be separated into three categories: business taxation, personal taxation and tax administration. The most significant changes are in the area of business taxation and administration.

At an administrative level, this bill contains a significant advance in the presentation of taxation legislation that should in future prove a valuable tool for the parliament. I refer to the inclusion of compliance cost impact statements. These statements were recommended by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts following its inquiry into the Australian Taxation Office in 1993.

The initiative is important for two reasons. It will provide an indication to taxpayers of the estimated cost of complying with particular changes in the tax laws. More importantly though, these statements will necessitate government actually considering the cost they impose on our economy—that is, on the people of Australia—of administering the government's taxation policy.

It is always easy for governments, particularly those that have been in power for 12 years, like this government, to believe that every tax change they introduce can be implemented without cost. It is easy to believe that governments should be required to only consider making good laws and that it is for the citizens to obey those laws regardless of the administrative costs of doing so. Such a view of the world is highly dangerous as it suggests that we are in this place to impose laws on the citizens of Australia rather than to make laws on behalf of those citizens. It is important to remember this distinction, especially with tax legislation.

I say quite plainly that I welcome the development of these impact statements. I do wonder, however, how serious the Labor government is about this reform. How serious is the government about informing Australians how much taxation changes will cost them? When I look at these statements, I have to ask how much effort is being devoted to estimating the cost of compliance. Could it be that the government cannot make these calculations? Maybe they can; maybe they cannot. If they can, then I believe the general statements which are contained in this bill are insufficient. It is important that people be able to appreciate the cost of our taxation system; that is, the cost of compliance. Perhaps the tax office has found it just too hard to comply with this requirement.

If the government cannot make these calculations, what does it say about our tax laws? If they are too complicated and their impact is too uncertain, then how does the government expect taxpayers to apply the law in the first place? It is a simple principle which I will state again: if a law is so complicated that the costs of complying with the law cannot be measured, then, in my opinion, that law is a bad law. I can only say in summary on this opening point that the coalition supports the further development of tax impact statements for the benefit of all Australians.

This bill makes amendments to four acts: the Income Tax Assessment Act, the Taxation Administration Act, the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Act and the Ombudsman Act. I had considered outlining all the relevant provisions of this bill and their impact on the various parties who will be affected. Senators may be reassured that I have chosen against this course. Indeed, having read through the explanatory memorandum of the bill, I have decided I should acknowledge the value of brevity and refer all interested persons to the detailed and elucidating speech of the member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) in the House of Representatives. His speech, which so eloquently outlined the prime features of this bill, can be found in the Weekly Hansard of 7 February of this year.

For my part, I am content to justify my aversion to a detailed exposition of the bill by citing just one passage of the proposed legislation. This particular passage is taken from that part of the bill which deals with an amendment to the Income Tax Assessment Act. The particular amendment changes the law so that payments of disability wage supplement, or DWS as it is called, are given similar treatment to that for other comparable social security payments. Proposed subsection 24ABD(5) reads thus:

SPEECH.PARA: If:
(a) a taxpayer's partner died; and
(b) the taxpayer is not under pension age; and

(c) the taxpayer would have been qualified for payments under a bereavement Subdivision but for an exclusion provision (taxpayer's pension or allowance increased on partner's death to such an extent that no bereavement payments); and
(d) the taxpayer derives payments of disability support pension under Part 2.3 of the Social Security Act 1991 on one or more of the 7 pension paydays after the death;
then those payments on that payday or each of those paydays are not treated under subsection (1) but are treated as follows:
(e) the supplementary amounts are exempt;
(f) so much of the balance as exceeds what would have been the balance (payments less supplementary amounts) if the partner had not died is exempt;
(g) the rest of the balance is not exempt.
There is one full stop in 131 words. I merely use this provision as an example of what our legislation has become: lengthy, convoluted and, I think, very user unfriendly.

PARA.TAB: Former Second Taxation Commissioner Brian Nolan, who is currently leading a team in the pursuit of simpler taxation laws, once described our tax laws in terms of a huge boiling cauldron of spaghetti: no-one can tell where it starts or where it ends. Each year we just add another layer of complexity upon complexity.

I prefer to think of our tax laws in terms of wandering through a maze in a thick fog. You know where you start, you know that getting to the end is important, you know there are many possible paths, you know that if you take a wrong turn you will get into trouble and yet the maze goes on and the fog gets thicker. Escaping from the maze is never easy!

At some point we are going to have to stop and ask: is this really the best way to run an economic and social system? Is it right that fewer and fewer citizens are able to read and understand our laws? It would seem that even a former taxation commissioner is now asking this most basic of questions.

There must surely be common political ground on which we can all stand and say enough is enough. It is time to give the law back to the people. It is time we found a better way to raise revenue for government. Sadly, I can only conclude that as so much of our law today is aimed squarely at raising revenue, our chance of finding any common ground is remote.

It has been a long time since equity or economic efficiency was at the heart of tax reform in this nation. It is depressing to think that the very worst of our black letter tax laws have been written during the term of a so-called people's party like the Australian Labor Party.

I can't believe that there would be one senator opposite who could claim to understand our tax laws in total. If there is, I challenge them to explain the provisions of the capital gains tax to me and the Australian people. I challenge them to explain the taxation treatment of superannuation and the substantiation provisions.

The minister here today no doubt has with him advisers from the Australian Taxation Office who will willingly take on board any questions that senators may wish to raise. I have no complaints with the professionalism of these officers. I admire their dedication, innovation and persistence.

It is a good and welcome thing that they are here today. Good and welcome, that is, for the minister. But where are those staff of advisers when an Australian taxpayer sits down to organise his or her affairs within our tax laws? Sadly, they are not to be seen.
Revenue for government—that is the bottom line of our tax laws today. If it makes the government revenue, it must be a good law. And if it doesn't, why bother with it?

I would ask those listening to this debate today to ask themselves the simple question: could I arrange my own affairs for tax without legal or accounting advice? I would think that most people, if not everyone, would have to concede that they are unable to answer my question in the affirmative.

Even those with the most basic of arrangements must now confront the reality of our complex tax laws. It is a sad reflection on our taxation system that this must be the case. It has, in my opinion, been the government's preoccupation with the raising of revenue that has created this regrettable situation.

While on the subject of revenue, I note that the measures in this bill will have some impact on the total revenue collected by the government, though not very much. Given that the government anticipates raising in excess of $119 billion in tax revenue this financial year—I say it again: $119 billion—I can understand how blase the government may well be with mere millions.

Australians are used to being taxed by this government. In the 1980s it was constantly altering the law to raise more tax revenue. Senators will remember how the fringe benefits tax and capital gains tax measures were supposedly for equity purposes. Today the FBT alone raises in excess of $2.3 billion or 0.6 per cent of our GDP.

In Mr Paul Keating's seven years as Treasurer of our country he increased the annual taxation take from just over $44 billion to an astounding $93 billion. Since becoming Prime Minister, he has increased the Commonwealth's tax revenue grab from $89 billion just three years ago to a forecast $119 billion this year. And, of course, worse than that, since he has been Prime Minister borrowings have gone from $30 billion and are expected to be $100 billion at the end of this year. So an additional $70 billion is being borrowed and that has been spent also—not to mention the outlays from selling off privatised firms, as well as the rundown in infrastructure investment by the Commonwealth.

I say `grab' advisedly, as this money comes from the pockets of all Australians, whether directly or indirectly. Can such a tax haul be justified? Of course it can if you are a Labor member of parliament. Of course, all you have to do is to point to the benefits that Australians have derived from paying all this additional tax.

I would like to ask all Australians to think about this for just one moment. Think about how good your services were back in 1993. Now ask yourself whether you are 30 per cent better off today than you were then. Is life 30 per cent more rewarding, 30 per cent more satisfying, or 30 per cent more comfortable? Or over the past three years, would you have preferred to have had that 30 per cent increase in government revenue in your pocket?

Perhaps Australians know who is 30 per cent better off now than in 1993. Perhaps they can see who has advanced by 30 per cent while Prime Minister Keating has been in office. Perhaps they are happy to know that their hard-earned money has been spent advancing the welfare of some of the richest and the noisiest, the loudest and the greediest—advancing those with the least merit but the most muscle.

All Australians can understand that with this Keating government they will be paying more and more tax in the years to come and they will be seeing less and less benefit for their taxes. So contemptuous of the people is this government that it doesn't even pretend any more.

The government's own budget papers indicate that over the next three years taxation revenue will increase by no less than 23 per cent—an extra $26 billion. That's the Labor way. That's Mr Keating's way.

Finally, I would like to briefly highlight two changes contained in the legislation which are definitely in favour of the Australian taxpayer and are welcomed by the coalition without condition. The proposed changes to the civil penalties and taxation offences contained in part 1 of schedule 2 of the bill derive from recommendations of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. The amendments are designed to ensure that taxpayers are not subject to an administrative penalty under taxation laws for an act or omission which gives rise to prosecution of the taxpayer under those laws.

These changes ensure that the Taxation Office must choose one path and one path only for seeking redress against a taxpayer. They will ensure, among other things, that the Taxation Office does not have the power to impose an administrative penalty against a taxpayer where a prosecution of the taxpayer is commenced and then withdrawn by the Taxation Office. This change is most welcome as an indication of the Taxation Office's complementary relationship to the tax paying citizens of Australia. It is a change that is owed to the Australian public.

The coalition also welcomes the government's moves to create the Taxation Ombudsman in the office of the Commonwealth Ombudsman. Once again, this was a recommendation of the Public Accounts Committee. The coalition continues to believe that this should be a statutory office position. The coalition finds it curious that there should be a statutory office position for all our human rights scrutinisers but not one for the protection and betterment of ordinary taxpayers. Strange logic—curious priorities.

In conclusion, while I welcome this bill on behalf of the coalition, I must once more voice the anger of those ordinary Australians who have long suffered through the high tax and spend policies of this government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1995. This bill has been around for a long time. In fact, last year it was called Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1994. It has had a long gestation period. The thrust of the legislation, as my colleague Senator Gibson said, has the approval of the opposition. However, in matters of detail we would have preferred certain alternative routes. Perhaps four or five years ago my attention was drawn to a series of situations whereby taxpayers, having been caught with an administrative penalty, also found themselves before the courts. They were in a double jeopardy position.

PARA.TAB: This matter was subsequently taken up with the Public Accounts Committee which brought forward a recommendation. That recommendation has now seen its way into law in that the measure will remove the power of the commissioner to impose or reimpose an administrative penalty where there has been a prosecution for the same offence or omission.

This is an omnibus bill that we are looking at today and the Taxation Office ombudsman will be established within the office of the Commonwealth ombudsman. It effectively means that when the ombudsman or ombudswoman is dealing with taxation matters he or she will be called the taxation ombudsman or ombudswoman. I am pleased to see that there is an allocation of additional resources for the review of ATO action and that will improve the equity of the taxation system.

We are yet to see the taxpayers' charter. I hope that this will be more than an administrative document or aide-memoire to taxation auditors and is actually enshrined within the legislation. The small claims tribunal is yet to be established. I have been invited to participate in a workshop on Monday to look into the mechanics of setting up such a small claims tribunal, and I welcome that because there is a problem about the cost of tax justice. All too often we have seen where, if there is a dispute between the taxpayer and the taxation auditors, the taxpayer can take it on appeal if he is dissatisfied. Quite often the amounts involved do not warrant the costs and the hassles accompanying such an appeal. Reasonable amounts of money for small businesses or taxpayers can be involved. I believe that the alternative of a small claims tribunal is the appropriate way to go in providing an independent adjudication of such issues.

Another amendment to which I wish to refer concerns the payment of instalments by companies. When the government reduced the income tax company rate from 39 per cent to 33 per cent, as part of the trade-off it decided to bring forward the time schedule within which payments had to be made. Initially, in the euphoria of a significant reduction in the corporate tax rate, a lot of people accepted the concept of perhaps having to pay their tax somewhat earlier. But the proposal was more draconian than people had envisaged. The tax rate has now moved up from 33 per cent to 36 per cent and people are caught with these very tight schedules for meeting company tax.

An instalment taxpayer is liable to pay tax instalments under the new company tax instalment regime in accordance with a table contained in section 221AZK(2). Under the table, the timing of the amounts of the payments differ depending upon whether the instalment taxpayer is classified as small, medium or large. Under subsection (3) of that section of the act the taxpayer's likely tax for the current year is calculated in the first day of month nine. It is possible for a taxpayer to have more than one amount of likely tax on the first day of month nine. This may happen where an estimate is lodged during that day. Accordingly, section 221AZK(3) has been amended to make it clear that an instalment taxpayer will only be classified as at the end of the first day of month nine.

It is unfortunate that, as part of a deal of reducing tax, the government brought the tax instalments forward. But there is no leniency because the tax rates have gone up and the instalment rates will not be brought back. As a result, there is going to be quite an added cash flow put onto taxpayers.

In the legislation there are provisions in relation to the valuation of livestock involving the cost price of natural increase of livestock. We have amendments to the law which will ensure that the natural increase of livestock, for which no minimum value is prescribed, is valued at its actual cost. Taxpayers can elect to value stock at its actual cost. I acknowedge that the effect of the amendment is to eliminate an inappropriate deferral of tax but, with some new primary production type varieties, if the absorption cost method is used you can have an exceedingly high value placed on your natural increase vis-a-vis other items of traditional livestock for which there are prescribed minimum values such as sheep, horses, goats, and pigs.

I have had some discussions with officers of the Taxation Office and they assure me that efforts are being made to contact primary producers and their associations at state and national level to try to accommodate such new varieties to expedite the setting of minimum prescribed values. I seek assurances from the minister that arrangements have been made today in terms of meeting the undertaking that the Taxation Office will use its best endeavours to get minimum values applied as expeditiously as possible. This would certainly apply to new varieties such as alpaca and emu. Without that assurance, in the initial years there will be a higher tax payable even though there may be limited sales due to the application of the increases in natural livestock items. We will have the high cost associated with the application of the absorption cost placed on closing stock values and this will enhance the closing stock amount.

There is an interesting feature in the superannuation guarantee, and this is an area in which I have some interest. The bill extends the present annual superannuation guarantee contribution requirements under the superannuation regime to 1994-95 and later years until the regime is more established. This is somewhat curious because, obviously, where an employer receives an employee contribution it must be remitted within a month. But the employer's responsibilities and obligations can be met only by a once a year payment. I would have thought that perhaps the gestation period would have been well and truly satisfied. From the way that the explanatory memorandum is worded, it appears that it can go for quite a few years yet.

It is said that there is no cost to revenue, but I notice in other areas where the collection period is being brought forward there is a gain to revenue as a result of the earlier collection of money. In a sense I suppose that is correct because if it has never been collected in advance in the past a decision not to change the method will not result in any change to revenue. With the development of superannuation and its basic acceptance, I think perhaps quarterly instalments would be somewhat more appropriate.

The next item concerns the capital gains tax. It ensures that there will be a liability for capital gains when an asset is created and held by its creator as the trustee of a discretionary trust. That will apply in circumstances where there is a future interest, say, in a professional partnership. It is an anti-avoidance measure.

The eligible investment income of registered organisations includes, in the assessable income of friendly societies and certain other registered organisations, income derived from certain assets within the organisation. I would like to take this opportunity to express my concern about the increased tax impositions placed by this government on friendly societies. Friendly societies were established to help the less well off in the community but, as a result of changes in the tax legislation, those societies are being forced to move towards clients which they have not traditionally done a lot of business with in the past.

With the use of the tax file number, perhaps, I think they could well be developing products to assist those less well off in the community, provided that the societies themselves with particular investment incomes had a lower friendly society rate. I know that this government is very keen on having level playing fields, but I think it is somewhat unfortunate that, as a result of tax changes, you are deliberately forcing certain types of institutions either out of business or to deal with other than what has been their traditional client base.

I ask the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook), representing the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear), to look again at the taxation of friendly societies. Perhaps nowadays, with the sophistication of the tax file number system, you might be able to develop a range of tax rates to suit the particular income levels of those members of the community who are not, say, in the top quartile. I am referring here to those members that friendly societies traditionally dealt with, the less well off—those people who sought to form an association to improve their lot in life and to provide for their security. I use this opportunity to flag that issue.
This bill also includes changes to life assurance companies in regard to dividends payable to life assurance companies which are satisfied through the issue of bonus shares and so on.

The other issue of interest is the notice of ruling. The bill before the parliament will make changes whereby, when a ruling is made by the Commissioner of Taxation, a notice of the taxation ruling will be published in the Commonwealth Gazette. This measure removes any uncertainty about when a public ruling is made. I notice there is also a table for the information. I think that is a good move.
