One thing that worries me in relation to rulings is that I am not sure that there is the appropriate oversight of all rulings, with the result that there is still a lot of shopping around going on amongst the various tax offices to get the best ruling under the circumstances. You can go around to a particular branch of the tax office and apply that ruling which suits you best. In other words, there is not enough liaison within the Taxation Office itself. There does not seem to be an officer who is actually in overall control of these rulings. I think the shopping around for rulings is an unfortunate practice that is developing, and certainly it is one I would like to see stopped as soon as possible.

Apart from that, there are some minor amounts, such as the rounding down of tax liabilities to the nearest 5c. There are some good measures in relation to panel vans and utility trucks. One-tonners or more are treated in the same manner throughout the taxation law, irrespective of whether they are derived from passenger motor vehicles. This has been an impediment in the past. Some time ago I brought in a private member's bill drawing attention to the problems associated with that, and the unfair advantage that, say, imported vehicles had at the time over local vehicles. Of course, my private member's bill did not cover the same matters as this legislation but it dealt with the same sorts of issues, including derivatives of passenger vehicles.

So that measure is welcomed, as indeed are the measures relating to social security changes. I think they will be welcomed by those people in receipt of disability support pensions. I therefore support the thrust of the measures proposed, but not perhaps the manner in which some of those have been achieved.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is gripped in a frenzy of enthusiasm as it debates the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1995. When Senator Watson commenced his speech, he referred to the fact that at one time this had been Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5). I can verify that. Indeed, on my briefing paper the `5' has been crossed out and `1' has been inserted, and the `1994' has been crossed out and `1995' has been inserted, giving eloquent testimony to the fact, if you like, that this has been around for a long time and was expected to come on a lot earlier but, for one reason or another, it has come on now.

PARA.TAB: We have had two speakers from the coalition in this debate, Senator Watson and Senator Gibson, both of whom have indicated support for the legislation. Senator Watson in his closing address indicated that perhaps he would have approached it from a different point of view, but nonetheless he finds that the outcome expressed here is something that he can support.

I have not heard from the minor parties or from the Independent, but this is an omnibus bill cleaning up a lot of not minor but important and detailed applications of the taxation act, so it is not surprising that they would not come here to simply voice their approval. They would certainly have come here had there been disagreement, but it is not likely they would come to express their agreement. So I take it, therefore, there is strong support for these measures in the chamber, and that they will pass.

Let me therefore turn to some of the questions raised in the debate because I think some comment is necessary. Indeed, Senator Watson explicitly asked me to comment on the provision in this bill concerning the cost price of natural increase of livestock. Since he explicitly directed that question to me, out of respect for him and for this chamber, I think I should reply to his particular request.

Before I do so, though, might I say that I have noted the broad remarks of Senator Watson and Senator Gibson and, in Senator Watson's case, particularly his observations about the superannuation guarantee and about the capital gains tax provisions; the entreaty he made on the taxation of friendly societies—that is, that the societies were for the less well off—when he referred to the reasons for the formation of those societies and how the tax laws apply; and his comments on shopping around for rulings and, in Senator Watson's view, the need for a proper, more centralised oversight of that to prevent such shopping around. I mention these things now so that they will appear in Hansard as being acknowledged as points by the government, and so that the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear), whom I represent in this debate, can have them explicitly drawn to his attention. I hope, as well, to do that myself.

Returning to the cost price of natural increase of livestock, can I say that a number of groups which represent breeders of exotic birds and animals have expressed concern about the proposed new basis for valuing natural increases, and that is because there have been no prescribed minimum values for these exotic species. They include things like emus, ostriches, crocodiles and alpacas—I think Senator Watson referred to emus and alpacas—but obviously the list could be longer. At present, the income tax regulations only prescribe minimum values for sheep, cattle, horses and pigs.

I can advise the Senate that the Australian Taxation Office is undertaking a project to develop minimum values for the natural increase of several exotic species, together with a value for their breeding stock. The Taxation Office is consulting with the various bodies representing breeders of these species who are providing information on these values. The national body representing emu breeders, for example, has worked closely with the ATO in developing a minimum value for emu chicks. I am advised that the ATO and the breeders are happy with this value. The ATO hopes that regulations prescribing these minimum values will be in place early in 1996.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it possible for you to tell us what prescribed minimum value for emu chicks has been agreed between the government and the industry?

—I understand that Senator Watson has asked me across the floor through you, Mr Acting Deputy President, what the agreed value is between the government and the emu breeders for emu chicks. Just taking the advice I have received, there is an agreement as to the minimum value. That agreement has to be reduced to a regulation.

PARA.TAB: There is some consideration as to whether there is a protocol or proper procedure here about releasing a figure before it is reduced to a regulation. We will check that and, if there is none, I will make that information available to you, Senator Watson. The only reason why I am cautious is that all of us at this end of the chamber are a bit unsure as to whether there is some sort of proprietary element here about releasing such a figure.

However, your question, Senator Watson, was: is the tax office going to be talking to these people and coming to a reasonable conclusion about what the value would be? My advice is yes, they are; they are determined to do that. That will come up in regulations prescribing those values early in 1996. In view of those remarks, I thank all of the contributors to this debate and the Senate, and I commend the bill.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.
Debate resumed from 7 December 1994, on motion by Senator Faulkner:
That this bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I ask the minister at the table, the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook), a question in relation to the handling of the rest of business today. I understand that at the conclusion of the debate on the Broadcasting Services Amendment Bill 1994 [1995]—if that is achieved by 7.20 p.m., and I am not sure it will be achieved by 7.20 p.m.—it is the government's intention to move on to government business order of the day No. 8, which is the Aboriginal Education (Supplementary Assistance) Amendment Bill 1995. Can I just confirm with the minister that that is, in fact, the case, rather than going on to item No. 4? Can I also confirm with the minister that, if that is the case, he will be moving a motion accordingly to give effect to that agreement?

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Childs)—I do not know whether the minister has any information, but I am informed that it is still under discussion. We are not going any further than the second reading of the Broadcasting Services Amendment Bill 1994 [1995]. (Quorum formed)

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Prior to the quorum call Senator O'Chee, with leave of the chamber, put a question to me through you, Mr Acting Deputy President, on the order of business and what the government's intentions were. The government's intentions, can I say through you to Senator O'Chee and the rest of the chamber, are to proceed with order of the day No. 3, the Broadcasting Services Amendment Bill, to the end of the second reading stage. At that time the government will propose that the next order of business be No. 5, Standing Committee on Procedure, consideration of first report of 1995. Order of the day No. 4, the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill, resumption of the second reading debate, would not be proceeded with as it appears on the Notice Paper and order of the day No. 8, the Aboriginal Education (Supplementary Assistance) Amendment Bill, would not be promoted out of order.

—The Broadcasting Services Amendment Bill is a timely attempt to make the anti-syphoning laws in the Broadcasting Services Act more workable. As we know, the anti-syphoning laws were designed to protect free-to-air broadcasts of events which are deemed to have national or cultural significance. The Democrats are strong supporters of the objectives of that legislation. Viewers should not be forced to pay to see major events that they normally see free of charge. Economists would, of course, argue that people do pay for so-called free-to-air broadcasts: our taxes pay for the national broadcasters and our consumer spending funds the advertising revenue which keeps the commercial networks going. But a pay TV subscription comes on top of those existing imposts. It is an additional cost which many Australians either cannot afford or do not want. Because of technical limitations, many Australians cannot receive pay TV broadcasts even if they want to. Free-to-air coverage is far more comprehensive.

PARA.TAB: Having said that, the Democrats also believe that the present system is flawed and needs to be improved. In trying to describe what is wrong with the present system, it is hard to know where to start. The first problem is that this list is too long. It contains events which are not normally screened in Australia. It is hard to see how an event which has never been screened here can be classified as highly significant to the Australian public. It is particularly hard to understand how Australians can be used to seeing an event free of charge when it has not been shown on our free-to-air networks at all. The fact that some events of this kind are on the list shows how much the government has departed from the original concept. I am not a conspiracy theorist but I can understand why it has been rumoured that this list was basically drawn up by the networks. For example, free-to-air viewers have never seen a test or a one-day cricket series played in India, Pakistan or Sri Lanka, yet they are all on the list. The tour of Pakistan was by all accounts very exciting but was not screened here. Nor was the 1994 Australia-New Zealand Davis Cup match, even though that too was on the list.

This chamber did have the option of trying to make the list more balanced by using our disallowance power. The Democrats considered taking that step at the time. We decided not to proceed because disallowance would have been too blunt an instrument. The list was drafted in such a way that we would have had to strike off many events which actually should be on it. This would have created a vacuum while a new list was drafted and gazetted. The result could have been chaotic and counter-productive, so we dropped that idea at the time. But the fact remains that the list is too generous, and that is one cause of the problems which we are now experiencing.

The second problem is that the delisting procedure is too restrictive. It is wide open to legal challenge by a very litigious industry. It does not allow delisting where a commercial network hoards rights by buying them but not showing the events solely to prevent them from being screened on pay TV. In the Democrats' view this bill will help to solve that problem. It provides the minister with a more useable mechanism to amend the list. It proposes a completely discretionary power to add or to delete items from the list, subject to the approval of both houses of parliament. It blocks off the avenues for legal challenge which would otherwise constrain the exercise of that power. Ordinarily, such a wide discretion might be seen as unfair and even dangerous. However, this is a special case. The anti-syphoning provisions give the free-to-air broadcasters special privileges and these should not extend to an open invitation to take the minister to court.

Having said that, it is essential that guidelines be developed to help the minister exercise those powers consistently and transparently. The note in the amending bill gives some guidance on when the minister might exercise power to delist an event. The note does not, however, give any guidance on when events might be added to the list. Guidelines for the minister's listing and delisting an event should be developed as a matter of urgency so that the industry can better understand how the minister will use his powers under the act. For example, I am mystified that the Australia-Pakistan one-day series held in October last year is still on that list, even though it was not bought by any free-to-air broadcaster and the minister has been asked by Australis to delist it. Pay TV subscribers deserve better than to wait 11 months to see an event which the free-to-air networks have shown no interest in whatsoever.

Channel Nine publicly stated that it was happy to have the 1994 series delisted but not any future series, just in case it decides that it wants to screen them in the future. In other words, Channel Nine sees the list as reserving to it a range of choices which it might take up or, then again, it might not. It hardly needs to be said that this is not what the list is for. The list is not an exclusive smorgasbord for the optional consumption of the free-to-air networks. If the networks are not deadly serious about screening an event then it should not be on that list.

The third problem is that the act prevents pay TV licensees from acquiring rights to listed events unless free-to-air networks have bought them first. This puts the networks in a strong position to veto a pay TV broadcast or to extract cheap rights from pay licensees instead of paying full price for them in the first place. This is not just a theoretical concern, as Nine has demonstrated in the West Indies case. The only recourse available to pay licensees is to request that the minister delist the event. But the wheels grind very slowly—far too slowly for that to be any kind of realistic solution.

What this means overall is that if the free-to-air networks do not buy rights to a listed event before it starts, it cannot be shown on pay TV, even if the networks themselves have been unreasonable about it. It does not matter if they were not serious about buying or imposed outrageous conditions; it still cannot be shown by the pay operators. That gives the networks too much leverage. The networks should not have a power of veto over pay broadcasts. If anyone should have that privilege it should be the minister. Given that this bill solves only one of the three problems with the list, I have had an amendment to the anti-syphoning provisions drawn up to make the system operate in a more balanced fashion. The Democrats' amendment would automatically delist an event once it is ended.

Automatic delisting will not diminish the public's ability to see most major events live on free-to-air television. As the Australian Broadcasting Authority's recent report on the operation of the list shows, most events on the list are already shown on free-to-air services live. While the ABA's broadcast figures are only for Sydney, and only for six months, they show that over three-quarters of the broadcast hours of list events were broadcast live on free-to-air channels. All of the finals of sporting events were shown live and the majority of delayed broadcasts, comprising only about 14 per cent of the broadcast hours of list events, were delayed broadcasts of international events. Therefore, automatic delisting of the event after it is over would not cut into those live broadcasts.

What automatic delisting will do is allow pay operators to purchase rights to broadcast an event immediately after it is ended, whether or not free-to-air broadcasters have acquired the rights to that event. It will ensure that pay television operators will be able to broadcast events which the free-to-air broadcasters do not want to broadcast or do not want to broadcast in full. Arguments have been made that automatic delisting would reduce the value of free-to-air broadcasters' rights to list events. That argument ignores the fact that the government's stated policy reason for introducing the list was to ensure that the public did not have to pay to see major events that they could see on free-to-air channels. It is not to preserve or to add to the commercial value of free-to-air rights.

The Democrats are also concerned that the act does not provide an easy and a quick way for pay television operators to find out whether events have been acquired by free-to-air broadcasters and whether the acquisition of highlights of an event amounts to acquisition for the purposes of the list. Acquiring rights to programs can be anything from a handshake over dinner to the signing of complex legal documents, yet the outcome in both cases will determine whether pay operators can or cannot bid for the right to the event. There are also events where free-to-air broadcasters do not want to buy rights to more than program highlights, which may or may not amount to acquiring rights to the event. In both cases pay operators need advice on whether or not rights to the event have been acquired for the purposes of the list.

The minister's office has advised us that the ABA now has sufficient powers to provide such advice to pay operators. Indeed, the ABA's own draft guide to the pay TV anti-syphoning provisions suggests that pay operators can now apply either to the minister or through the ABA to have an event delisted. However, the extent of the ABA's role in advising on acquisitions of rights under the list is not spelled out in the legislation and we would urge the ABA to clarify its powers to advise pay operators as part of its guide.

The ABA is also required, by ministerial direction, to report every six months on the operation of the anti-siphoning provisions. We urge the minister to direct the ABA to include in its six monthly report any advice it has given to operators on when rights have been acquired, and when highlights have amounted to the acquisition of rights to the event. The first ABA report on anti-siphoning has finally been made public. We strongly urge the minister to ensure that all future ABA reports on anti-siphoning are also publicly available. The recent spectacle of Messrs Packer and Murdoch combining to form a news channel emphasises the need for our second amendment to this bill.

The ABC's pay television licensee AIM has the highest Australian content provisions of any pay operator. AIM's Australian content requirements for general programming go from 25 per cent to 35 per cent during the day and peak viewing hours. The news channel's Australian program content went from 40 to 50 per cent. In contrast, the Murdoch/Packer news channel, according to news reports, will be little more than reruns of free to air news bulletins, with Murdoch's BSkyB providing more foreign input. There will be no additional journalists hired in Australia, and there is little promise that the channel will offer anything new in the way of either Australian or overseas news and information. This sorry state of Australian content of news on pay television is possible because the only Australian content requirement put on all pay TV licensees—other than AIM—relates only to Australian drama.

Back in 1993, when Australian content on pay TV was debated, I moved an amendment that the required review of broadcasting go beyond pay TV's compliance with drama requirements to at least look at Australian content on news and sport. I am moving the amendment again, but this time to require that any review of pay TV content look at all Australian content provided by the industry. This does not amount to imposing a content requirement, but it does amount to putting the pay TV industry on notice that their provision of new Australian content will be reviewed and, if found wanting, may be subject to further content requirements.

This amendment gives the pay TV industry an opportunity over the next year or so to behave responsibly in providing Australian content and it provides the minister and this parliament with an opportunity to review the industry's performance on overall Australian content and to better understand what requirements, if any, may be needed in the future. The Democrats are very concerned at the increasing concentration of ownership and control exercised by a very few media players across the media industry.

Back in 1993, the Democrats argued for stronger cross media regulation, which included the satellite pay TV operators as well as the press and commercial broadcasters. Once again, this chamber rejected Democrat proposals to strengthen those cross media rules. Unhappily, the two intervening years have, as a result, seen not the diversity of new players promised by the government, but the same old players acquiring more of our media. We are all familiar with Mr Murdoch's domination of the press. We can add to that his interests in free to air broadcasting, pay television, program production and, indeed, ownership of a studio that produces the product. We are also becoming aware of the linkages between Mr Packer's magazine holdings, his interests in Fairfax press, his control over a free to air commercial network and his involvement in pay television. Last Friday, we were treated to the spectacle of those two media barons combining to create a news channel which, perhaps coincidentally, severely threatened the ABC's pay TV news channel. We have seen since then that it has gone down.

In the Democrats' view, enough is enough. That is it; that is where we should stop. The act now requires the ABA, in consultation with the Trade Practices Commission, to monitor cross media ownership of pay television licensees and, if concerned, report to the minister. We now call on the minister, as a matter of urgency, to ask the ABA to report within six months on all cross media linkages between pay TV licensees, people in control of the press, and people in control of commercial radio and television licences. At least then, parliament can be informed of who owns what interest and, perhaps belatedly and perhaps too late, make more sensible cross media rules which promote real competition and diversity in the pay TV industry—not the developing cosy duopoly which is now emerging.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on behalf of the coalition to support the Broadcasting Services Amendment Bill. There were some fears that, under the Broadcasting Services Act 1992, pay TV operators would be able to buy up exclusive rights to major sporting channels and cultural events; and this would force viewers to go without or to pay for events that were always free.

PARA.TAB: Since the matter came before the parliament in 1992 we have been concerned about the way in which pay television has developed. Given the government's response to many of the developments in pay TV and in telecommunications generally, we do not have a lot of confidence that the government got this matter right initially. Certainly we do not have a lot of confidence that this bill is the complete answer. One of the things I want to do today is go through some of the ways in which the original legislation was flawed and go through some of the problems that are still presented by the amendments before us today.

Telecommunications and broadcasting are areas where we need the government to be completely on the ball, because of the very dynamic and rapidly changing nature of this whole area. We have splendid opportunities for Australia, if the government gets telecommunications right. With the whole pay TV area we have the opportunity to create an enormous new area for Australia, for the development of our industry and, most importantly given the current debate, for employment in this country.

It is a great pity that when matters come before the parliament, when we have legislation before parliament to set the guidelines as to how an industry is to develop—and we set the regulations for an industry—that these matters are not considered fully and the wisest possible decision is not made. A lot of the reason for this goes back to the way the minister operates in this field. Minister Lee has a history of reacting to problems and not having the foresight or developing the planning strategies to head them off in the first place.

This whole area of pay TV, specifically the free list problem, demonstrates that lack of planning to start with. We have seen it in other areas of the communication network—and in the development of broadband services generally. We have seen it specifically in pay TV from the time of the Senate pay TV inquiry. We saw how inept this government was in handling this matter. I was deputy chair of the pay TV inquiry that first looked at developments in this field.

It was about 18 months ago that we had that inquiry. What has absolutely amazed me is how rapidly this field has developed and how the landscape in pay television now looks so totally different from how it looked at the time of the pay TV inquiry. That is why a wise government would have set out at that point a regulatory framework that was comprehensive enough and had sufficient foresight to foresee some of the problems that were going to develop.

Minister Collins had a very poor start in that whole area. I remind the Senate of the basic nature of that start. When the minister was setting up the first licences in pay television, he had a determination before him which he signed without reading. It was for an auctioning system for the pay television channels on satellite. That auctioning system did not require any sort of deposit. This led to a number of collapsing bids, meaning that one series of companies could put in a number of bids.

TALK.START.PARA: —They had 30 or something bids, didn't they?

—They put in bids at certain prices. When the first bid failed, it then collapsed to the next one. Guess what? It was the same company. If it dropped to the next one, it was the same company, and so it went on. This lack of foresight by the government delayed this whole process for many months. That is just inexcusable for a government. How many public servants do we employ in these departments to watch over these matters, yet the whole thing ended up a total debacle.

PARA.TAB: We have now seen that series of events played to its final conclusion. Australis was one of the companies that was successful in buying it. There are now suggestions that it will merge with Foxtel. In the days when we had that inquiry—I remind the Senate that it was only 18 months ago—Foxtel did not exist. With the involvement of News Ltd and Telstra, it was not even on the horizon. Yet we now have that company emerging as a media mega-monster. Optus Vision, the Optus group and a number of television stations are emerging as the second huge player. The smaller players, unfortunately, are being squeezed out.

I have given that preamble to all this to indicate the great necessity for government to have some foresight in the problems that they are dealing with, to plan well in advance and to hire the best possible experts to help them map the way through, which this government should follow to come out with the best possible outcomes in an area which will be a booming part of our economy. If this government gets it wrong—in many instances so far, it does not give us a great deal of confidence that it has the right direction on this—industries that could develop will not develop, and that is a great tragedy.

TALK.START.PARA: —And regional viewers could miss out, too.
—As my colleague says, regional viewers can particularly miss out. That is a point to which I want to return in more detail later.

PARA.TAB: What we are considering here today is tied basically into the matters of the anti-siphoning list for pay TV. One would have thought that it is basically a fairly simple and straightforward matter. You do have a list. On the basis of that list, you can tell what events should be on pay TV and what events should be left free to air. Indeed, the minister came out very boldly early in this process and seemed to be saying that he would set up this list and that all these events were going to be available to people who did not want to purchase pay TV rights. We were happy with that initially. But when it hit its very first test, which was the Windies test last year, they ran into trouble. Viewers had to go without or pay for events that they had always viewed for free. Such events included the football code grand final, the Melbourne cup, cricket tests and one-day cricket matches.

The government's response was to list events under the Broadcasting Services Act which should be, in the opinion of the minister, available free to the public. The object of the anti-siphoning list was that viewers would continue to see major sports events for free. But, as I have foreshadowed, the government's legislation on this occasion was hopelessly inadequate.

The government made a promise that audiences listening to their normal station would be able to watch their cricket, rugby league or whatever. Minister Lee made a mess of that promise. The principal act did not ensure that they had these rights. The legislation simply said that a commercial channel had to be given the right to show the sporting events. This explains the key purpose of this bill.

The minister's intention is to amend the Broadcasting Services Act to ensure that free to air broadcasters cannot hoard rights they obtain through the operation of the anti-siphoning list. The bill seeks to clarify the discretion of the Minister for Communications and the Arts to vary the free list of sporting events. The minister recognises that the principal act is flawed. Minister Lee now sees the need to vary the free list to sporting events which may not be acquired by pay TV operators until acquired by free to air TV operators. This legislation was originally referred to the Senate Environment, Recreation, Communications and the Arts Legislation Committee. This committee took evidence from the major free to air and pay TV stakeholders in February this year.

Strident criticisms of this Labor government's conduct on this matter were well canvassed during this inquiry. The government made a phoney promise which it did not keep. Its incompetent legislation meant that it could not keep its solemn promise about the major sport and free to air availability. The ALP legislation was clearly inadequate. They have made a mess of it again, and the West Indies series cricket fiasco highlighted this.

The ABA report into the acquisition of the broadcasting rights for the 1995 Australian cricket tour of the West Indies is now publicly available. The report is dated 7 March 1995. Minister Lee consistently said that the ABA preliminary report advised that the series was on the anti-siphoning list. All the parties—Nine and Australis—conducted their negotiations on this basis. The ABA report—I have a copy of it from the minster's office—advises that the West Indies series was not covered by the list. This minister had grossly misled parliament, the networks and the public on this issue. He has sat on the contents of this advice from the ABA. I repeat that these matches were not subject to the anti-siphoning rules, and the minister knew this. He has proven his deceit in this matter relating to the ABA report.

The amendments in the Broadcasting Services Bill 1994 seek to clarify the discretion of the Minister for Communications and the Arts to vary the free list of sporting events, the anti-siphoning list. The sporting and cultural events on this list may not be acquired by pay TV until acquired by the free to air operators.

The bill has two principal effects. It removes the reference to live televising. This clarifies the intent of the act but removes the only reference to the quality of the broadcast to be provided by free to air operators. The other effect is to give the Minister for Communications and the Arts complete discretion to vary the anti-siphoning list. This is freedom to list or de-list sport and cultural events at ministerial whim. This could be against the interests of regional Australia particularly, as was mentioned earlier by my colleague, which has little access to pay TV services. So, if it ends up on pay TV, it is bad luck if you are in the country. You will not be able to access it anyway.

The Keating government has created, with its legislative approach, an anti-siphoning maze. A regulatory regime to allow Australians to continue to see sport on TV that they now see free of charge simply does not work. The principal acts and these amendments are riddled with flaws that will cause problems for the televising of sport and cultural events in Australia. I will show that this Labor government's rules have the potential to cause many problems for free to air TV viewers. The potential for massive problems and doubts has already been realised through what happened with the West Indies test.

Mr Lee's unworkable anti-siphoning rules came up against their first major test over the Australia versus West Indies series. The rules are in tatters. The unseemly brawl over the coverage of this series saw Mr Lee cash in his independence to side firstly with the Nine Network. He then sided with the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), not surprisingly, who forced his hand. Minister Lee had to take his riding instructions from Mr Keating, do a breathtaking backflip and then support the Galaxy pay TV operator. This Windies TV coverage fiasco has exposed Labor, and especially Minister Lee, as incompetent.

This Labor government's legislation simply does not achieve what it has promised the Australian people. Labor promised faithfully to all the low income earners who rely on free to air telecasts that they would not be forced to pay for the events that they now see for free. Such events include the AFL, the rugby league, the Olympics and Commonwealth Games, the rugby and international cricket. These low income earners were feeling very cheated by Labor over Windies cricket until Network 10 threw the minister the lifeline that he so desperately needed. The coalition was relieved, on behalf of Australian sports lovers, that commercial reality overcame the minister's unworkable rules.

Network 10 had rescued the minister. It is a vote for the free list concept. The minister is not off the hook as he has admitted that similar battles on coming sports events are still likely to occur. Only good fortune and Network 10 sorted out the Windies fiasco and can guarantee that this ALP government's unworkable rules will be put to the test again shortly.

We on this side of the House do not oppose the bill. We support the principle of the free list of major sporting events and cultural events. The coalition is committed to maximising free to air coverage and to making it work, but this bill does fall short of fixing the TV anti-siphoning rules that we all know do not work. There are currently a large number of problems with the operation of the current act, and this bill does nothing to address those.

Let me raise some of the specific questions that the industry—that is, pay and free to air operators—and the public still want answered: free to air operators blocking pay TV access to listed events by dragging out negotiations and then not acquiring the rights until the last minute and free to air broadcasters refusing to acquire rights to a listed event thereby denying pay TV operators the opportunity to get the pay TV rights.

An example of this situation was the Australia versus Pakistan cricket test and the one day series last October. Free to air networks could buy both free to air and pay TV rights and then hoard the pay TV rights to stymie the other pay TV operators. The New South Wales Rugby League is an example of this with Channel 9 holding the free to air and pay TV rights. Here, uncovered or partially covered matches would be unavailable to pay TV operators and their viewers. The definition of an event is confusing as the free to air operators may televise highlights only and pay TV operators may be prevented from carrying the event at all.

We should also ask: when does the haggling over price, conditions, et cetera, become hoarding by the networks? The minister is not required to exercise the power under this legislation to list or delist an event if national or commercial free to air stations have not acquired the rights within a reasonable time.

Another weakness of the current provisions is that there is no objective criteria for the inclusion of an event. Also, there is no objective process for removing an event. Section 115 of the Broadcasting Services Act 1992 also promised that free to air audiences listening to normal commercial ABC-SBS stations would see the cricket, or whatever, free as always. The legislation still does not ensure this. It simply says that a commercial or national channel has the first right to show it. So one small regional TV station with pay TV connections could buy the free to air rights and show the event to a small free to air audience and then in the major cities and regional towns the events would only be available by pay TV.

So Minister Lee and this Labor government are facing their worst fears because of the inadequate legislation they have created: the prospect of presiding over a media environment where a paying elite will have privileged access to major Australian sporting and cultural events. On the other hand, the TV anti-siphoning law seems to treat in some circumstances pay TV operators very unfairly. Minister Lee must ensure that this legislative mess is fixed otherwise it will be treated to a similar unedifying spectacle every time subscriptions and free to air networks are both attracted to major sporting events. This legislation fixes some of the problems but it does not fix all the problems. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I follow my colleague Senator Tierney in this debate on the Broadcasting Services Amendment Bill, and he has properly outlined the importance of the forthcoming revolution in pay TV and the government's handling of it.
—Stumbling and lurching.

—The government has been stumbling and lurching on the verge of the pay TV revolution to get this bill to the stage it is at today. There is absolutely no doubt that all Australians will be affected by the pay TV revolution. We have already seen the preliminaries in this matter with the Super League wars between the Murdoch forces and the existing conservative forces. I think the Australian public has been surprised by the depth of those wars, and no doubt surprised by the possible money involved.

PARA.TAB: Without all forms of sport crossing over to pay TV, you really have to wonder how pay TV can pay for itself. It is little wonder that we are all witnessing the depth and strength of the wars, as highlighted by the Super League and the rugby league wars that are going on at the moment. That is the essence and the profit making area of pay TV.

It is incumbent upon this parliament to be prepared for the onslaught of pay TV, the hundreds of channels that Australian households will have access to. We need to be prepared in two specific areas. The first is the fact of competition. It is important that we maintain the strength of competition in the pay TV and free to air industry.

The Trade Practices Commission or the soon to be formed Australian Competition Commission will play a leading role in that area. We have read in the papers of late about the merger of Galaxy pay TV and Murdoch Foxtel. The Trade Practices Commission is inquiring into that merger and rightly because without competition in this area the Australian public, the consumers, will be the losers. It is incumbent upon the parliament that the existing powers and culture of the Trade Practices Commission be transferred to the Australian Competition Commission and that we closely guard and check the adequacy of competition particularly in the area of media.

There is an area that is incumbent upon the Australian Broadcasting Authority to oversee in the forthcoming revolution in pay TV. There is no doubt that this is a revolution because we have seen in the United States that households have access to literally hundreds of different channels with different programs. The Australian Broadcasting Commission needs stronger powers in this regard than it has at the moment.

The free to air television code of conduct is, at the moment, voluntary. Senator Tierney would well know, from his work on the Senate community standards committee, that the Australian Broadcasting Authority, as it stands today, does not have strong enough powers and a strong will in this area. It needs to be restructured so that it is at arms length from the industry and has powers to act upon any breach of the code of conduct or breach of the censorship laws.

Censorship is a very grey and debatable area. I do not think there are many in this country who believe that there should be no censorship laws at all. Heaven forbid if it were the majority view in this government that there should be no censorship laws on pay TV. I know that the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, does not think that. In fact, he has very strong views about establishing a specific channel just for families.

That being the case, we have to arm the Australian Broadcasting Authority with powers that are similar to those of the Trade Practices Commission. Of late I have been most critical of the lack of governing by the Australian Broadcasting Authority in terms of free to air television. It should worry this parliament how they are going to cope with the array of channels and shows that will be upon us with pay TV. If they cannot cope with the existing four channels, how are they going to cope with the multiple channels under the pay TV system?

There was evidence of this last year when Channel 9 aired a show called Death on request which dealt with the very sensitive subject of euthanasia. Channel 9 was not in error to put that Dutch program on free to air television, but, I believe, it was in error in terms of the time slot and the rating it gave that program dealing with that sensitive subject. The program had very graphic pictures.

It actually showed for the first time—and this was admitted by Channel 9 executives—the point of death. On the 6 o'clock news we see a lot of footage of wars and seizes, but they never show the point of death. They always clip it because that is the code for 6 o'clock to 6.30 viewing. Death on request had a lowly M rating and was shown at 8.30 p.m. even though it showed for the first time an actual death scene. I had many calls regarding the screening of this program but I did not need to be told because it offended me as well. I complained to the television station, but of course I did not get anywhere.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Teague)—Order! It being 7.20 p.m. I propose the question:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak about a matter that is affecting and disadvantaging a large group of pensioners—a group of pensioners who were the victims of the 1990 Estate Mortgage collapse and who lost money, for many of them their life savings, and who are losing out again. Just as their share values start to rise, the Labor government is cutting back their pensions. Lately the Meridian Trust units have been steadily increasing in paper value, and so the paper value of the shares is on the rise. Many of these shareholders are pensioners.

PARA.TAB: In the 1992 budget, this Labor government put legislation through this House which established that unrealised capital gains on shares would be treated as income for the purposes of assessing the pension. We said that we would review that when in government because it was not to come into effect until 1993. Unfortunately, we were not in government to do that. However, we did the best thing we could in opposition; we moved a number of amendments to try to address the issue. A private members bill went through the Senate which tried to repeal the legislation but still the government would not listen.

The government did not do anything about this issue until it was forced to conduct a review when we indicated that we would have a Senate inquiry if it did not have one itself. We set a date by which that inquiry would be held if it did not have its own. The government had Ageing Agendas undertake a review. It was indicated that there were really very severe and serious problems associated with this matter.

Pensioners who retained their units are now just recovering some of the losses on the Estate Mortgage Trust. They were hopeful that, in the long term, they would recover the majority, if not all, of the losses they sustained. I will give an example of one of those pensioners. In a letter, one pensioner wrote:

Prior to 5th. Nov. 1993 my wife and I jointly held 30,000 units in Estate Mortgage Deposit Trust No. 4 which cost us $30,000. Owing to the collapse of the Estate Mortgage Trust these units were swapped for 10,772 A units in the newly-formed Meridian Investment Trust with a net asset value of $1.00 per unit and a market valve of 50c per unit. Thus our $30,000.00 originally invested in the Estate Mortgage Trust was reduced to a paper amount of $5,386.00—

SPEECH.PARA: so they went from $30,000 to $5,386—
and we sustained a loss of $24,614.00.
They have steadily been increasing in value. They now have a paper value of $10,449. The letter goes on to state:
. . . we have retained the units happy in the belief that at least portion of our losses on the Estate Mortgage Trust will be recovered in the longer term.

What happened? They are now told by the Department of Veterans' Affairs that that increase is being assessed as income for the purposes of the pension and that their income per fortnight has gone down. There is case after case like this. In the Herald-Sun today you can read about a 75-year-old man in Kilsyth who said last night that he was speechless when told his pension would be cut because of investment units that had never earned him a cent.

PARA.TAB: The situation is the same for the person who wrote this letter. The units have never earned them a cent. The units were worth $30,000 and went down to $5,386 but the paper value is now $10,449. None of these units has paid a cent in income and yet the paper increases have been treated as income for the purpose of assessing the pension. Who stands to benefit? In the paper today we read:
The Department of Social Security—

SPEECH.PARA: It is not the Department of Social Security; it is the Labor government—
has become an unwitting aide to corporate fishers . . . which see big pickings in the former Estate Mortgage trusts, now listed as the Meridian Investment Trust.

Do you know what is happening? Those pensioners are having to sell those shares at a devalued price, because they probably will not achieve the price they paid for those shares. Meridian is being disadvantaged because they have actually increased the value of those shares; they have brought the business back to a reasonable level. They are disadvantaged because people are selling the shares, and who is gaining from these pensioners? It is the people who can skim around and pick up these cheaper shares.

PARA.TAB: I suppose I could say, `I told you so,' because we told the government this when we had this debate in 1992, in 1993, in 1994, in 1995, and I suppose we will still be telling the government in 1996. The changes do not come into effect until July 1996, so there are going to be more pensioners who are caught up in this. This is the work of a government that does not think about the implications and the unintended consequences of its legislation.

Eight thousand pensioners are the victims of the Estate Mortgage collapse. Think of them. They are in their 60s, their 70s, their 80s, and I presume in their 90s. I have had some of the most pathetic—and I use that word pathetic in its real sense, full of pathos—letters from people in their 80s and 90s writing to me listing details of their investments over the years. They have been frugal with their very limited resources. Some of them have $20,000 or $25,000 as their only asset other than their home and they find they are being caught up in this.

There is not really much choice for these pensioners. Both options—keeping their shares or selling them—make them worse off. The choice of pension reduction can mean the difference between, on the one hand, being able to pay the bills and buy necessities and, on the other hand, having to go without. The other choice is to sell the shares after holding on to them for so long and avoid a pension reduction. These people cannot gain anything from their investment. They cannot even get back to where they were before. As I said, the government is giving these pensioners a rough deal. It is giving a great deal to the people who are buying these units. These people who are going around and skimming off these shares are benefiting at the expense of the pensioners who are losing out twice over.

These issues, these sorts of examples, were pointed out to the government over and over again. We asked the government to repeal that legislation. We asked the government to do something about it and nothing is going to be done until July 1996. As far as I am aware, the best that the department can do for these people is to say that the matter is under review. The office of the Minister for Social Security is also hiding behind this statement. Meanwhile, these pensioners are losing out and will have to suffer pension reductions.

When he spoke to ACOSS last week the Minister for Social Security (Mr Baldwin) issued a press release entitled `A Government committed to Social Justice'. Where is the social justice in this piece of legislation? Where is the social justice for pensioners, 8,000 of them, who have made not one single cent on their investment losing significant amounts of pension? Where is the social justice? That is the question I ask you, Minister McMullan, sitting there, reading away. I hope you can go out and face those 8,000 people and say, `This is what we did. We have taken so long to fix it up. We had to be forced into a review.'

They will remember, those pensioners. They will remember that they were told they were going to be taken out of the tax system by 1995. They will remember, some of them who are part-pensioners, that they were told they would be taken out of the tax system. They will remember when the next election comes. This is just another example of the appalling attitude that Labor has towards older Australians and pensioners in particular. How long will you continue to ignore them?

Over and over again I receive calls and see cases of Labor discriminating against them and affecting older Australians. Over and over again I stand up and point out that these policies and actions are hurting the aged, and over and over again the government turns a blind eye, ignores these problems and fails to take adequate action.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr President, and welcome back. Several weeks ago I travelled with a number of parliamentarians from both this parliament and a number of other parliaments to Tahiti, where we objected to the French nuclear testing in Mururoa and Fangataufa. A week or so after that I was invited by the people of East Turkistan in Adelaide to address a rally in Adelaide, because those people were also very concerned about the testing by the Chinese of nuclear weapons on their land. It was interesting in speaking with both the Polynesians and the people from East Turkistan who are in Australia that precisely the same processes of occupation of land, the dilution of the local population by an influx of migrants and the use of that land for purposes which would be intolerable on the home territory were being carried out.

PARA.TAB: The French are behaving quite atrociously in French Polynesia, with the dilution of the Polynesian population by French people when it comes to voting in local elections, and with large numbers of French soldiers and police being given the vote—much as they were in Noumea. The same thing is happening in East Turkistan. The people of East Turkistan gave me an open letter to Senator Gareth Evans regarding nuclear testing on their original home territory. When I spoke with them I undertook to read that letter into the record for the wider dissemination of its information. The letter reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Sir

PARA.TAB: Australia played a leading role in the world's condemnation of France's testing of a nuclear bomb in its Pacific colony of Mururoa Atoll. This condemnation and protest rocked the Chirac government in Paris. Meanwhile on the 17th of August 1995 China, in the search for world domination and nuclear superiority, conducted its 43rd atomic test in Lop Nor, East Turkistan . . . with the world and Australia adopting an utterly different attitude to the same issue.

The Australian government politically condemned the nuclear testing in Mururoa Atoll by the French and used economic pressure to impress its views on France. But when it came to China's nuclear test, Australia seemed to tread softly softly.
We, the East Turkistani community in Australia, were very disappointed by your comments which stated:

"China is not in quite the same position as France, it didn't ever sign on to a moratorium moreover it's conducting the test on its own soil, and it's conducting them in a geographically more stable area than an atoll out to sea."

We strongly protest against your statement which we believe is an act of injustice to the oppressed people of East Turkistan. We also challenge the validity of your statement as they disrespect historical facts.

France colonised Mururoa Atoll in the middle of the 19th century. While on the other hand East Turkistan, as had been reported in the Australian Human Rights Commission report of 1992, "has been the home of Turkic nationalities for more than two millennia" and was an independent republic until 1949 when it was finally occupied by China's People's Liberation Army.

While Mururoa Atoll is located in the middle of the ocean, Lop Nor is only 600 km from Eastern Turkistan's capital city, Urumchi. While Mururoa Atoll is sparsely populated, the Lop Nor region in East Turkistan has a population of millions.

In 1955 China built its first atomic base in Lop Nor and in 1964 they exploded their first atomic device. This led to a dramatic change in the ecology and environment of Eastern Turkistan. All water resources, soil, air, flora and fauna were contaminated and polluted with radioactivity. More than 250,000 East Turkistanis have died from radiation related illnesses, such as liver cancer and skin cancer. Today we can say that there is not a single East Turkistani who has not been affected by radiation. We have witnessed the affect of this radiation in East Turkistan's famous pear and rock melon exports which are now rejected on the world market and are returned to East Turkistan and sold in local markets by the Chinese. After all this devastation, how can one say that Lop Nor is a more stable area than Mururoa Atoll?

Your comments give the impression that China is justified in its actions because it has not signed the nuclear test moratorium. But regardless of this, China's atomic bomb and its ability to mass destruct is no different to France's—bomb and its ability to mass destruct.
Therefore we believe that more pressure needs to be placed on China, because of its arrogant disregard for world opinion and its refusal to sign any world moratorium.

Contrary to your government's opinion we feel that East Turkistan's independence is crucial to world peace. China exploits East Turkistan's mineral resources and land to make and test the bomb which will help in its territorial expansion. East Turkistan's independence would put an end to that exploitation and expansion.
East Turkistan is a Chinese occupied territory similar to Tibet, but it does not even receive any vocal support.
On Saturday 30th, September 1995 the Australian East Turkistani community along with their supporters from Islamic and other religious and non religious groups will hold a demonstration in Adelaide—

SPEECH.PARA: if I could interpolate there, this was the demonstration at which I addressed the gathering—
to bring to Australian people's attention the above issues and to show their dissatisfaction with the Australian government's treatment of these issues.

PARA.TAB: Therefore we call on you, Senator Evans, to reconsider your position and to review government policy on the issue of continuing Chinese nuclear tests in Lop Nor. To assist you we have attached extra information along with this letter. We also call the Australian government to support the East Turkistani people's rightful struggle for democracy, human rights and independence in East Turkistan.

SPEECH.PARA: It is signed by the Australian Turkistan Association Inc. and dated 25 September 1995. I will give a copy of the letter to Hansard tonight but tomorrow I intend to present a copy of this letter personally to Senator Gareth Evans.

The following answers to questions were circulated:

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications and the Arts, upon notice, on 24 July 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) What is the estimated annual loss incurred by Australia Post in meeting its statutory community service obligations in rural and remote areas.
(2)(a) What is the average total cost incurred by Australia Post in the sale of a 45 cent postage stamp; and (b) can a breakdown of the major elements of this total cost be provided.

(3) In relation to each of the following services provided by Australia Post: (a) Is the service currently profitable or not; and (b) what is the total revenue derived from and the percentage profit or loss of the service: (i) standard letter delivery (ii) bulk mail (iii) express post (iv) print post (v) EDI Post (vi) parcel post (vii) advertising mail (viii) international post (ix) philately (x) retail services generally and (xi) complementary products.

(4) Can Australia Post provide an assurance that its `postal' services (and in particular its reserved services) do not in any way subsidise its complementary products such as greeting cards, packaging and wrapping paper.
(5) Specifically, how does Australia Post ensure that there is strict financial and structural separation of its core postal activities from its complementary products.
(6) Can Australia Post provide an assurance that it pays normal commercial rates for all the inputs entailed in producing, marketing and retailing its complementary products.
(7)(a) How does Australia Post measure the staffing and building costs entailed in producing, marketing and retailing its complementary products; and (b) who pays these costs, and to whom.

(8)(a) From what capital sources are any expenditures entailed in producing, marketing and retailing its complementary products derived; and (b) if any capital is borrowed, is it borrowed at normal commercial rates, and from whom.

(9)(a) Who provides the administrative back-up services entailed in producing, marketing and retailing its complementary products; and (b) if it is provided by Australia Post, how are such services charged and are they charged at normal commercial rates.

(10)(a) Did Australia Post make a profit from its complementary products in the 1993-94 financial year; if so, what was the amount and percentage net profit or loss made or incurred; and (b) if Australia Post made a loss from its complementary products, how is it meeting that loss.

(11) What, if any, problems does Australia Post envisage could result from having to comply with a competition policy rule whereby government business enterprises would not be able to use profits from activities in restricted markets to subsidise activities in contestable market sectors.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question based on advice from Australia Post:

PARA.TAB: (1) The loss attributed to community service obligations (CSOs) applies to the whole nation. In 1993/94, it was calculated at $62 million.

The CSO cost is measured using government determined and approved methodology which uses a model for this calculation based on long-term avoidable cost calculated after deduction of the charge made for the service (ie the net cost).

The methodology provides for costs to be measured for each "mail path" (ie from the point at which a letter enters the network to the point of its delivery). The Australia Post network has 150,000,000 national "mail paths". The CSO costs are calculated from a model which reduces these to a more manageable 350,000 "mail paths". The model provides for the total cost of maintaining the letter service to be distributed over the total number of letters carried on the 350,000 "mail paths". Where the cost per letter on a "mail path" exceeds the revenue it generates, the whole of the "mail path" contributes to the CSO cost.
The approved methodology does not directly attribute costs calculated this way to a "rural and remote CSO" or to a "non rural and remote CSO" because each "mail path" has an origin and destination.

As well as non rural and remote "mail paths" where the net cost exceeds the price charged, the model includes inbound international mail which Australia Post is obliged to deliver under international agreements where the revenue paid for delivery does not meet costs.
Finally, the model also includes other long mail paths with origins and destinations in "non rural and remote areas" (eg Perth to Brisbane). The cost

ANSWER.PARA: of these exceeds the revenue generated, and the net loss is attributed to Australia Post's total CSO cost.

PARA.TAB: (2)(a) Australia Post estimates that the average cost of selling a 45 cent stamp is 4.5 cents.
(b) The major elements of this average cost of selling a 45 cent stamp are:

ANSWER.PARA: Cents
Serving & Backup (1) at Staffed Outlets 1.6
Payment to Licensed Post Office Agents 1.3
Accommodation 0.2
Indirect Costs (2) & Overheads 1.4

PARA.TAB: (1) This includes the cost of time required "behind the counter" for such things as stock requisitioning and checking, balancing, banking, training, etc.
(2) Includes such costs as equipment and software, material purchases, uniforms, etc.
(3) With the exception of `(i) standard letter delivery' all of the services listed are, or include, an element of non-reserved services provided by

ANSWER.PARA: Australia Post in open competition with commercial businesses. Australia Post is unable to make public information which competitors could use to their commercial advantage.

PARA.TAB: Australia Post provides aggregate information on revenue and profit/loss for its `reserved' services, and those services which it provides in competition with other businesses, in its annual report. This information from the 1993/94 annual report follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Reserved Non Reserved
Percentage of Total Revenue 61.5% 38.5%
Operating Profit $142.2M $141.7M
Return on Revenue 9.0% 14.3%

PARA.TAB: Putting `(x) retail services generally' aside, all the services listed in the question with the exception of `(v) EDI Post' are covering all their direct and indirect costs and making a contribution to overheads and profit. `(v) EDI Post', is still a developing service carrying significant "start-up" costs. Nevertheless, it is currently meeting all of its direct costs and is expected to meet all its other costs and make a contribution to overheads and profit during the 1996/97 financial year.

`(x) retail services generally' includes a range of activities, not a discrete service or set of services priced separately. Services provided through the retail network and priced individually cover their direct and indirect costs and make a contribution to overheads and profit.
In respect of (i) standard letter delivery, (a) yes it is profitable and (b) the estimated total revenue for 1993/94 was $816M with profit being 6% of revenue.

(4) Australia Post is keenly aware of its responsibilities regarding fair competition. Its pricing practices recognise fully the cost of each product or service offered to the public. This enables identification of cross subsidies between products and services. In recent years, the Prices Surveillance Authority and the Australian National Audit Office have each examined Australia Post's product costing methods and application thoroughly, and endorse its practices. Australia Post assures me that prices of its complementary products, such as greeting cards, packaging and wrapping paper, are not cross-subsidised by its `reserved' services.
(5) Australia Post has a sophisticated product costing system which accurately matches the revenues and expenditures of all its products and services.
Australia Post's established policy on costing products and services is that all expenditures recorded in the financial accounts are fully distributed to the products and services.

Results, by product, are closely monitored to ensure there is no cross subsidisation of established products and services. It is possible in the starting phases of a new product or service, eg EDI Post, that positive results are not achieved until target volumes are reached but this outcome never persists for a protracted length of time. In this, Australia Post is no different to any other trading enterprise which introduces a product or service.

Financial separation between reserved and non reserved services, of which complementary services form part, is maintained. This is evidenced at page 73 of Australia Post's 1993/94 Annual Report as indicated in the answer to question (3).
Structural separation between reserved and non reserved service is impractical, and would be detrimental to postal customers who value, and benefit from, the integrated services currently provided.

(6) Australia Post performs its functions, as far as practicable, in accordance with sound commercial practice. In doing so, it purchases goods and services from a range of suppliers, on a strict commercial basis. It enjoys no special advantage in the form of exemption from taxes of any sort, or exemption from State or other laws. Similarly, retail complementary products are marketed and retailed on the open market on a truly "competitively neutral" basis.

(7)(a) Complementary products are costed on a normal commercial basis, using Australia Post's product costing system (see (5) above). This includes an appropriate allocation of staffing and building costs.
(b) All costs are met by Australia Post. Recipients are suppliers of services and goods under normal commercial arrangements and Post's own staff and licensees.

(8)(a) Australia Post's trading in complementary products is funded from the Corporation's working capital. That working capital is managed on a strictly commercial basis, and in this respect Australia Post enjoys no special advantage over its private sector competitors.

(b) Australia Post's borrowings are raised in the open market, at strictly commercial rates. In the last published accounts which relate to the year ended 30 June 1994, Australia Post's borrowings of $235 million had been raised through an unsecured floating rate note (FRN) facility (term expiring in 1999). As an outcome of an open tender process the Commonwealth Bank was awarded a contract to manage and underwrite the FRN issue.

(9)(a) Complementary products are retailed as part of the range of services available through Australia Post's national network of outlets. All of these activities are managed commercially, in accordance with existing legislation, and complementary products share the administrative back up services provided for the other retailing activities of Australia Post.

(b) Australia Post's product costing system (see (5) above) is used to measure the cost of products and processes based on the goods and services purchased. Those goods and services are purchased commercially in the market place, and all of the Corporation's products and services, including complementary products, are costed consistently on this basis.

(10) As indicated in the answer to question (3), this service is one of the non-reserved services which are traded by Australia Post in open competition with other producers. Australia Post does not propose to make public information which they could use to their commercial advantage. However, as also indicated in the answer to question (3), all services provided through the retail network and priced individually cover their direct and indirect costs and make a contribution to overheads and profit.

(11) Australia Post does not apply profits from activities in reserved services to subsidise activities in contestable market sectors, nor does it intend to do so in the future. As shown in the answer to question (3), Australia Post derives about half of its profit from competitive products and services sold in contestable markets. This is adequate to fund development of new commercial initiatives.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Housing and Regional Development has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The cost of producing Volume 1 number 1 of the Regional Leader was $15,781.75.

unions
individuals and associations in business and industry; and

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Immigration and Ethnic Affairs: New South Wales Office

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 22 August 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is the department proposing, or has it implemented, any changes to its Chatswood, New South Wales office; if so, can details be provided.
(2) In the context of any changes, will there be any impact on the compliance functions of that office.
(3) Is the department proposing any restructure of its State Headquarters.
(4) Is the department proposing to transfer any responsibilities from the State headquarters to regional managers; if so, can details be provided.
(5) What are the financial implications involved at the Federal, State and regional and/or local office levels.

(6) Has the department responded to correspondence from the Community and Public Sector Union (CPSU) concerning the department restructuring from branch secretary Ms Vicki Telfer, as advised to CPSU members on 9 June 1995; if so, can details of such a response be provided.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) No. However, the Department does periodically review organisational settings to ensure its offices are appropriately structured to deliver efficient services to clients.

(3) Following the Central Office restructure active consideration has been given about how best to realign the management role of the organisation in NSW more closely with the Corporate Plan. Consultation with staff and their CPSU representatives has formed part of the process. No decision has yet been made.
(4) See answer to question 3.
(5) Any management realignment will be largely cost neutral.
(6) The NSW State Executive has responded through consultations with CPSU representatives, consistent with the answer to question 3.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 29 August 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Was the Under Secretary for Lands and Immigration in Western Australia, in 1947, delegated powers of guardianship of unaccepted child immigrants pursuant to the Immigration (Guardianship of Children) Act 1946?

(2) Did that delegation include the power to have police `thumbprint' such children, as indicated by question on notice no. 8 of 10 May 1994 in the Western Australian Legislative Council; if so, in which other States were unaccompanied immigrant children, as defined by the Immigration (Guardianship of Children) Act 1946, thumbprinted/fingerprinted?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes

(2) Not specifically. If unaccompanied immigrant children were thumbprinted/fingerprinted, it would have been pursuant to the provisions of relevant State Child Welfare legislation. I am unable to provide information as to in which States, if any, such thumbprinting/fingerprinting took place.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 29 August 1995:

PARA.TAB: Can full details be provided of expenditure on the fitout and furnishing of the Department's offices in Perth.
