ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Royal Singaporean Air Force: Use of RAAF Base Amberley

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 30 August 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has the Federal Government granted final approval to relocate a detachment of the Royal Singaporean Air Force (RSAF) jets to the Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) base, Amberley.
(2) If approval has been granted, then what are the terms of the contract/agreement between the Australian and Singaporean Governments.
(3) If approval has not been granted, will the local community be provided with an opportunity to provide input into this proposal.
(4) Is the Federal Government considering conducting an investigation into the impact such a proposal would have on the local community.

(5) (a) Is it the case that the RSAF will be using A4 Skyhawk aircraft; (b) are the A4 Skyhawk aircraft considered in aeronautical terms to be noisier than current RAAF aircraft; (c) if the A4 Skyhawk will not be used: (i) what sort of aircraft will be in use by the RSAF; (ii) what is the noise level of the aircraft; and (d) will the RSAF be using the A4 Skyhawk jets to train pilots.
(6) (a) Is there a curfew imposed on the RAAF; and (b) will a curfew be imposed on operations by the RSAF.
(7) Can press statements which indicate that there is a possibility that the RAAF base at Amberley will be used by commercial aircraft as a second airport for the Brisbane region be confirmed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) No. Negotiations are continuing with the Singaporean Government over a draft Memorandum of Agreement. It is unlikely that final agreement on the relocation will be reached before the end of 1995.
(2) Refer to answer to Q(1).

(3) Local community input has been addressed from the outset through representation by the Ipswich City Council at the initial fact-finding briefing to the Republic of Singapore Air Force (RSAF) in September 1994. Since that time, there have been ongoing discussions with local government officials.
Articles have appeared in the `Queensland Times' and the `Sunday Mail'. There have also been various items reported in the local press.

Wider consultation on the proposal has been achieved by briefings from senior executives from RAAF Base Amberley at monthly meetings of the Ipswich Regional Development Corporation comprising Federal, State and Local Government representatives and members of State and local business organisations. Briefings have also been made to the Ipswich-based Amberley Support Group.
At the Federal level, I have written to the local member and the Premier of Queensland.

In April 1995, the RAAF hosted an RSAF domestic fact-finding team at Amberley. Six local community figures were invited to the base for briefings and discussions to ensure the community was involved in issues relating to education, health, housing, services and the cost of living.
Consultations will continue with local community representatives and State and Federal members.

(4) State and Local Government leaders have been alerted to the scope of the proposal, the benefits to the community and the possible demand on local resources. Minimisation of aircraft noise has been one of the key issues in the negotiations to date. A Noise Exposure Forecast has been developed which includes the RSAF operations.
(5)(a) Yes.

(b) Preliminary results of a noise assessment conducted at Amberley indicate that the RSAF A4 Skyhawk is, at some points of its take-off profile, no noisier to a ground observer than current RAAF fighter aircraft, whilst at other points of the profile the noise level is higher.
(c) (i), (ii) Refer to answers to Q (5)(a) and (b).

(d) Yes. The RSAF will be using A4 aircraft for the advanced phase of pilot training. These pilots will have already undergone the basic phase of their training before coming to Amberley. The unit will also train graduate pilots who have been selected for conversion to fast jet combat aircraft.

(6)(a) No. However, the RAAF does impose a voluntary curfew on its own aircraft. All flights into and out of Amberley are flown within promulgated airfield operating hours, unless operational requirements demand otherwise.
(b) As the RSAF will only use Amberley for training purposes, no reasons can be foreseen for it to operate outside promulgated airfield operating hours.

(7) The proposal recently announced proposes that limited use of the airfield at Amberley will be made by regional airlines on chartered or scheduled services to meet the air transport requirements of Ipswich and the surrounding region.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 6 September 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) What is the current specified total amount which is the effective tax-free threshold for pensioners taking into account pensioner rebates and other benefits and non-pension income.
(2) What benefits, pension and non-pension income has been included in this calculation.

(3) What would have been the actual cost for the 1994-95 financial year and the estimated cost per annum for the 1995-96 and 1996-97 financial years of changing the tax-free threshold for self-funded retirees to a figure equal to the answer to paragraph (1).
(4) Can the figures used to calculate the answer to paragraph (3) be provided.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) and (2) The Government provides a number of different types of pensions, including, for example, age pension and service (age) pension, disability support pension and sole parent pension. The levels of pension and supplementary benefits vary according to the status of the pensioner (ie. whether single, married, or married but living apart due to illness or infirmity). The Department of Social Security releases a guide to Social Security payments on a quarterly basis. The Department of Veterans' Affairs also releases similar information.

All recipients of taxable pensions face exactly the same income tax rates as other individual taxpayers, including a tax free threshold of $5,400. Recipients of taxable pensions also have access to the pensioner rebate at a level determined by their taxable income. These rebates are a means of providing assistance through the tax system to people who are in the most relative need. The pensioner rebate is available to people who receive either a full-rate or part-rate pension, ensuring that full-rate pensioners (including those who earn non-pension income not in excess of the income test free amount) do not pay tax, and that most part-rate pensioners have a reduced tax liability.

Pensions are generally reduced at the rate of 50 cents in the dollar for each dollar of non-pension income earned in excess of the pension income test free area. The pensioner tax rebate also shades out, at the rate of 12.5 cents in the dollar, for each dollar of taxable income in excess of the relevant rebate threshold (ie. full rate pension income plus the pension income test free area).

The pensioner tax rebate has the effect of providing pensioners with a more progressive tax scale compared to other taxpayers. The Government justifies this approach on the grounds of social equity in that pensioners are one of the poorest groups in society.

The Government chose to assist age pensioners with a tax rebate rather than an increase in the tax free threshold because raising the tax threshold would also assist high income earners and those with substantial assets at a significant cost to revenue and encourage the practice of income splitting, which would also add to the cost to the Government.
The pensioner rebate may be transferred between couples. That is, any unused rebate of a pensioner may be added to the rebate of the spouse where the spouse has, or would have, a tax liability.

The levels of the pensioner tax rebate for 1994-95, and the associated thresholds at which the rebate begins to shade out, are set out below. The rebate levels are calculated annually, following the release of the December quarter CPI figures. For example, the shade-out threshold for a single age pensioner in 1994-95 has been calculated taking into account a basic pension income of $8,380 plus social security income test free non-pension income of $2,340.

PARA.TAB: Because of the phasing out of the age pension and pension tax rebate, the disposable income of those in receipt of an age pension will be lower than that of retirees who do not receive the pension, except for those persons who fail to meet the age, residency or assets test requirements for the age pension.

Where applicable, pensioners and other low income earners, including many non-pensioner retirees, also have access to the $150 low income tax rebate. That rebate begins to shade out at a rate of 4 cents in the dollar, once taxable income exceeds $20,700, so that it cuts out at a taxable income of $24,450.

Certain amounts supplementary to the pension are tax exempt, ie. any part of a payment that represents: (a) rent assistance, (b) an increase in rate of pension calculated by reference to other persons, or (c) remote area allowance. Payments of pharmaceutical allowance and telephone allowance are also non-taxable, as are some bereavement payments. Such supplementary payments are tax exempt because the payments are meant to cover specific purposes (rather than being a primary source of income), and the Government intends that the full amounts be made available for such purposes. None of these amounts, however, are included in the calculation of the pensioner rebate or shade-out threshold.

(3) As noted above, pensioners and non-pensioner retirees face the same tax-free threshold of $5,400. Pensioners receive a pensioner rebate which operates to extinguish tax liability on the pension plus non-pension income up to a specified total amount. In July 1994 Treasury provided the honourable Senator with an estimate of the cost of extending the rebate for age pensioners to non-pensioner retirees. That is, the cost of extending the pensioner rebate to female non-pensioner taxpayers aged 60 years or over and male non-pensioner taxpayers aged 65 years or over, who have income below the level where the pensioner rebate shades out but who do not receive the age pension, was estimated to be in the order of $70 million for the 1993-94 income year. While the cost of such a measure has not been re-estimated, I understand the estimate would not have changed significantly since that time.
(4) No. See (3) above.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the following question of the President of the Senate, on notice, on 3 October 1995:

PARA.TAB: With reference to Joint and Senate select, references and legislation committees:
(1)(a) How many committees are currently operating; and (b) how many inquiries are being undertaken by these committees.
(2) What is the estimated or actual cost of each inquiry.
(3)(a) How many committees have employed consultants; (b) what is the cost per committee; and (c) what is the total cost of these consultants.
(4) How many extensions have been granted to reporting dates since the new committee structure was adopted in October 1994.
(5) How does the workload of the existing committee structure compare with the workload, over a twelve month period, under the old committee structure in the last Parliament.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beahan Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1)(a) At 3 October 1995 there are 25 joint, select, references and legislation committees supported by the Department of the Senate, comprising 8 references committees, 8 legislation committees, 6 select committees and 3 joint statutory committees. Nine other joint committees on which senators serve are administered by the Department of the House of Representatives.

(b) The 25 committees administered by the Department of the Senate have 52 current inquiries listed in the Notice Paper. These do not include the statutory monitoring functions of the joint statutory committees (7 ongoing functions), the examination of annual reports by legislation committees or the examination of budget and additional estimates by the legislation committees. Over the financial year 1994-95 these committees, together with other select committees in operation during that year, received 157 references from the Senate, not including estimates and annual reports (Source: Department of the Senate Annual Report 1994-95, pp. 103-104).

(2) Inquiry costs vary according to the type and duration of an inquiry. References and select committee inquiries cost considerably more than legislation and estimates inquiries, in both staff costs and administrative expenses. The Senate Committee Office Review of Resources, tabled in the Senate on 27 September 1995, estimated that a typical references committee inquiry would cost $15,000 in administrative expenses (advertising, postage, printing and photocopying, consultants, venue hire, staff travel, witness expenses), while a typical legislation inquiry would cost around $2,000. Including staff salaries, which is the largest component of Committee Office costs, and senators' travel allowance in association with committee meetings, the 157 inquiries undertaken during the 1994-95 financial year cost an average of $30,800 each.

(b) 1994-95—$4,500 (two discussion papers) and $2,000 (legal advice); 1993-94—$8,323 (specialised research assistance with an inquiry), $6,248 (translation services) and $9,519 (legal advice); 1992-93—$19 899 (legal advice), $4000 (expert advice), $0 (translation services—paid in next financial year)
If a committee wishes to engage a consultant, the approval of the President of the Senate is required.

(5) The workload of Senate committees has been steadily growing as committees have become capable of performing any of the functions of the Senate, including its primary legislative function of considering proposed laws, scrutiny of the conduct of public administration and consideration of policy issues. The restructuring of legislative and general purpose standing committees added no new functions to committees but reorganised existing functions into the different structure of references and legislation committees. New functions had been added in 1989 with the referral of annual reports to committees for biannual reporting and the referral of bills to committees, and in 1993 with the introduction of supplementary estimates hearings to replace consideration of the Appropriation Bills in committee of the whole.

The new structure has been in operation for slightly under twelve months. It is difficult to compare the past twelve months with twelve months from the previous Parliament because committee functions were different. It is clear, however, that the high levels of activity reached in
